dict.string: A request meaning Let me know that you have received my message.
A request meaning Tell me what you plan to do.
The term used by ATC for yes.
A statement meaning that adherence to previously imposed altitude restriction is no longer required during a climb or descent.
A phrase used to prefix a message of noncontrol information when it is relayed to an aircraft by other than an air traffic controller.
A phrase used to prefix an ATC clearance when it is relayed to an aircraft by other than an air traffic controller.
A phrase used to prefix an ATC request when it is relayed to an aircraft by other than an air traffic controller.
The phrase used to indicate that a radio transmission has been distorted or interrupted due to multiple simultaneous radio transmissions.
A phrase used by ATC to inform the pilot that he must circle to land because the runway in use is other than the runway aligned with the instrument approach procedure.
A phrase used by ATC to advise an aircraft that the departure clearance is automatically cancelled if takeoff is not made prior to a specific time.
Clearance Void If Not Off By (Time)
ATC authorization for an aircraft to execute a specific instrument approach to an airport.
ATC authorization for an aircraft to execute any standard or special instrument approach for that airport.
ATC authorization for an aircraft to depart.
ATC authorization for an aircraft to make a touch-and-go, low approach, missed approach, stop-and-go, or full-stop landing at the discretion of the pilot.
ATC authorization aircraft to make intermediate stops at specified airports without refilling a flight plan while enroute to the clearance limit.
ATC authorization for an aircraft to land.
ATC authorization for an aircraft to climb to VFR conditions within a control zone when the only weather limitation is restricted visibility.
A phrase used by ATC when a specific altitude restriction at a specified fix is required.
A phrase used by ATC when an altitude restriction at a specified fix is required.
A phrase used by ATC when a maximum crossing altitude at a specific fix is required.
A phrase used by ATC to inform a pilot when an accurate estimate of the delay time and the reason for the delay cannot immediately be determined.
Delay Indefinite (Reason, If Known) Expect Further Clearance Time

An instruction issued to a pilot on an instrument approach, directing him to continue inbound to the missed-approach point and then to execute the missed-approach point and then to execute the missed-approach procedure, as described on the Instrument Approach Procedure Chart or as previously assigned by ACT.
A portion of an instrument departure clearance, to provide a pilot with an altitude to be used in the event of two-way radio communication failure.
The time an operator can expect a gate release.
The time a pilot can expect to receive clearance beyond a clearance limit.
This phrase is used by air traffic controllers to inform a pilot of the routing he may expect if any part of the route beyond a short range clearance limit differs from that filed.
Expect Further Clearances Via (Airways, Routes, Or Fixes)
A warning used by air traffic controllers when prompt compliance is required in order to avoid the development of an imminent situation.
A call-sign prefix used by FAA aircraft engaged inspection/certification of navigational aids and flight procedures.
Instructions issued by ATC to a pilot directing him to turn to and continue in a specific compass direction.
A phrase used by either pilots or controllers that relates to the fuel remaining on board until actual fuel exhaustion.
Information provided by ATC to a pilot making a PAR (precision approach radar) approach regarding the position of the aircraft relative to the descent profile.
The phrase used by air traffic controllers meaning proceed with your message (not to be used for any other purpose.
Instructions for a pilot to abandon his approach to landing.
A phrase used by pilots to inform ATC that they have received runway, wind, and altimeter information only.
A phrase used by ATC to delay a aircraft for traffic management reasons; I.e., weather, traffic, volume, etc..
A phrase used by ATC in radar approaches to prefix procedures which should be followed by the pilot in event of lost communications.
A term used by ATC when such action compliance is required to avoid an imminent situation.
When used as part of an ATC clearance, this means aircraft whose altitude, position, and intentions are known to ATC.
A phrase used by ATC to inform a pilot to alter his traffic pattern so as to make a short final approach.
A statement indicating that an aircraft's fuel supply has reached a state where, upon reaching the destination, it can accept little or no delay.
A term used by pilots to inform ATC that the previously issued traffic is not in sight, or they are unable to contact ATC on a particular frequency.
A term used by ATC to mean no, or permission not granted, or that is not correct.
A term used in air traffic control to indicate that the conversation is ended and no response is expected.
A term used in air traffic control to indicate My transmission is ended; I expect a response.

A phrase that, when used in conjunction with altitude assignments, means that ATC has offered the pilot the option of starting climb or descent whenever he wishes and conducting the climb or descent at any rate he wishes.
A phrase used by AATC to inform a pilot that radar data used to determine the aircraft's position is no longer being received or is no longer reliable, and radar service is no longer being provided.
A phrase used by ATC to mean repeat my message back to me.
A term used by ATC to instruct pilots to advise ATC of specific information, such as Report passing Hamilton VOR.
A phrase used by ATC to advise that previously issued speed control (controller assigned or as part of a published procedure) restrictions are deleted.
A phrase used by ATC to advise a pilot to resume his own navigation responsibility.
A phrase used by ATC to request a repeat of the last transmission.
A phrase used by ATC to ascertain an aircraft's specific altitude or flight level.
A phrase used by ATC to request an aircraft heading.
A phrase used by ATC to request a pilot to activate the ident feature on the aircraft transponder.
A term used by ATC to request a pilot to activate specific modes, codes, or functions on the aircraft transponder.
A phrase used by ATC meaning that the controller or pilot must pause for a few seconds, usually to attend to other duties of a higher priority.
A phrase used by ATC to inform a pilot to turn off the automatic altitude reporting feature of his transponder.
A phrase used by ATC to inform a pilot to taxi onto the departure runway in takeoff position and hold.
A phrase used in conjunction with ATC instructions that gives the pilot latitude to delay compliance until a condition or event has been reconciled.
A form of backup brake system used in some large aircraft multiple-disk power brake installations..
A person who holds an aircraft mechanic certificate with both the airframe and powerplant ratings..
A missile carried on an aircraft for use against other aircraft..
A dying of a dynamic input parameters specifying the number of arriving aircraft which an airport or airspace can accept from the ARTCC per hour..
A service provided by FAA flight service stations located at airports not served by a power control..
A basic unit of electrical current in the electromagnetic-centimeter-gram-second system..
A dry-cell battery used in vacuum tube radios to supply power to the heaters, or filaments, of the tubes..
An authorization by ATC requiring pilots to submit only that information needed for the purpose of separation and control..
A basic unit of electrical charge in the electromagnetic-centimeter-gram-second system. .
A relative location approximately at right angles to the longitudinal axis of an aircraft..
A basic unit of electrical capacitance in the electromagnetic-centimeter-gram-second system..
A basic unit of electrical inductance in the electromagnetic-centimeter-gram-second system..
A basic unit of electrical conductance in the electromagnetic-centimeter-gram-second system..
To terminate an operation prematurely when it is seen that the desired results will not be obtained..
Termination of the start procedures in a gas turbine engine when it is seen that normal combustion has not taken place within the prescribed time limits..
A takeoff terminated prematurely when it is determined that some condition exists which makes take off further flight dangerous..
A general term for a knife-edge seal inside a gas turbine engine that wears away (abrades) slightly to produce an extremely close fit between a rotating and a stationary part of the engine..
A special shroud ring built into the outer turbine case of the gas turbine engine..
A strip of material in the compressor housing of some axial-flow gas turbine engines..
The tip of some axial-flow compressor blades made in such a way that it will abrade, or wear away, when it contacts the compressor housing. .
To wear away a surface or a part by mechanical or chemical action..
A form of damage to a surface made by roughening or wearing it away with scratches or gouges..
The ability of the material to resist damage by abrasion..
A material containing minute particles of a hard substance used to wear away a softer surface..
A method of removing carbon and other contaminants from machine parts.
A turbine blade with a hardened insert at the tip that is able to cut into the turbine shroud ring..
A coordinate representing the distance from the Y-, or vertical, axis in a plane Cartesian coordinate system. .
An electronic altimeter used to indicate the exact height of an aircraft above the terrain.
The actual distance between an actual aircraft and the terrain over which it is flying.
The maximum height above sea level at which an aircraft can maintain flight under standard atmospheric conditions.
The actual amount of water vapor present in a specific volume of air.

The state of a layer of air within the atmosphere in which the vertical distribution of temperature is such that a parcel of air, if given an upward or downward push, will move away from its initial level without further outside force being applied.
Pressure measured relative to zero pressure, or a vacuum.
A type of turbocharger controller which limits the maximum discharge pressure the turbocharger compressor can produce while the aircraft is flying below its critical altitude.
A pressure measuring instrument that measures pressure referenced from a vacuum.
A regulator valve at the compressor inlet in an aircraft high-pressure pneumatic system.
Temperature referenced from absolute zero, the temperature at which all molecular movement has ceased.
The numerical valve of a number without considering whether its sign is a plus or minus.
The swirling motion, or vorticity, imparted to the atmosphere by the combination of the rotation of the earth and the circulation of the air relative to the earth.
The temperature at which all molecular movement inside a material stops .
The ratio of the total unabsorbed radiation to the total amount of radiation falling on the object whose absorptance is being measured.
A basic unit of electromotive force in the electromagnetic-centimeter-gram-second system.
Information published by the FAA explaining the Federal Aviation Regulations and describing methods of performing certain maintenance and inspection procedures .
Electrical current in which the electrons continually change their rate of flow and periodically reverse their direction.
An advisory circular in book form issued by the Federal Aviation Administration, giving examples of acceptable methods, techniques, and practices for aircraft inspection and repair.
An advisory circular issued by the Federal Aviation Administration, giving examples of acceptable methods, techniques, and practices for aircraft alterations.
A series of flare-type fittings used in some of the older aircraft hydraulic systems.
The ratio of a small change in the plate voltage to the small change in the plates current it causes.
Electrical components that can operate equally well on alternating current or direct current.
A two-way communication link between an airliner in flight and the airline's main ground facilities.
A system for controlling the clearance between tips of the compressor or turbine blades and the case of high-performance turbofan engines .
To increase the speed of an object, or make it move faster.
A form of operational test of a system or component in which unusual conditions are used to cause a premature failure.
The length of runway needed for an aircraft to accelerate to a specified speed, and then, in case of engine failure, be able to stop on the runway.
A component of substance used to hasten a chemical action or change .
A small pump in a carburetor used to produce a momentarily rich fuel-air mixture to the engine when the throttle is suddenly opened.
The amount the velocity of an object, measured in feet per second, is increased by a force during each second it is acted upon by that force.
The acceleration of a freely falling body caused by the pull of gravity.

A maintenance check of a gas turbine engine in which the time required for the engine to accelerate from idle RPM to its rated-power RPM is compared with the time specified for this acceleration by the engine manufacturer.
The section and a turbine engine fuel control that schedules the rate of increase of the field to the nozzles when the engine controls call for acceleration.
An error in the indication of the magnetic compass that shows up when the aircraft accelerates or decelerates while flying on an easterly or westerly heading.
A switch in a piece of airborne electronic equipment actuated by an abnormal acceleration.
An enlarged annulus around the discharge nozzle of some float-type carburetors.
A substance added to a catalyzed resin to shorten the time needed for the resin to cure.
A system in an aircraft carburetor used to supply additional fuel to the engine when the throttle is suddenly opened.
A series winding on the voltage regulator coil in a vibrator-type generator control unit.
A sensitive instrument that measures the amount of force exerted on an object because of its acceleration.
Data found in such aviation maintenance documents as manufacturer's maintenance manuals, service bulletins, and letters, and AC 43.13-1 and 43.13-2.
A test made by a person who buys equipment to be sure the equipment is exactly as specified in the purchase contract.
An atom of a chemical element alloyed with silicon or germanium to give the material a deficiency of electrons, making the material into a P-type material.
A trivalent chemical element alloyed with a semiconductor material to produce atoms that accept free electrons to complete their covalent bond.
A door which provides access to the inside of an aircraft structure.
An easily removable panel that allows access to some portion of an aircraft structure for inspection and maintenance.
Devices used with an aircraft engine that are not parts of the engine itself.
A portion of an aircraft engine containing the drive years to operate such accessories as fuel pumps, air pumps, and generators.
A shaft to use in some gas turbine engines to drive the accessory gearbox.
The end of a reciprocating engine away from the propeller on which many of the accessories are mounted.
A group of gears that drive an accessory from the crankshaft of a reciprocating engine or from the compressor drive shaft of a gas turbine engine.
The portion of an aircraft engine crankcase on which such accessories as magnetos, carburetors, generators, fuel pumps, and hydraulic pumps are mounted.
An event that happens by chance or from some unknown cause.
The sum of all the errors occurring in the operation of the system or in the manufacture of a part.
A device in a digital computer that stores a number and, upon the receipt of the second number, adds the two and stores the sum.
A component in a hydraulic system that allows a non-compressible of all fluid, such as oil, to be stored under pressure.
The charge of compressed air or nitrogen in one side of an accumulator.
A measure of the amount of error, or difference between an actual value and its indicated value.
Free from error, or conforming exactly to a standard or pattern.
And FAA field office staffed with Flight Standards personnel.
A term used in warfare to identify a pilot who has downed five or more enemy aircraft.
A flammable liquid ketone used as a solvent and as an ingredient in many types of aircraft finishes.
A colorless, non-toxic flammable gas generated when calcium carbide is dissolved in water.
A single-or two-speech pressure regulator that is used to decrease the pressure of acetylene gas to a value that is appropriate for the torch being used.
A chemical substance that contains hydrogen, has a characteristically sour taste, and is prone to react with a base, or alkali, to form a salt and to accept electrons from the alkali.
A component in a wash primer used to mildly etch the surface of the metal being primed.
A paint used on the portion of an aircraft structure near the battery box.
The frozen calculated landing time of a flight.
A nut with a domed top.
Sound absorbing liners used in an engine nacelle or around the tail pipe to reduce the amount of noise produced by the engine.
The science of the production, transmission, reception, and effects of sound.
An airplane certified under 14 CFR Part 23 for flight without restrictions other than those shown to be necessary as a result of a required flight test.
An intentional maneuver involving an abrupt change in an aircraft's altitude, and abnormal altitude, or abnormal acceleration not necessary for normal flight.
And aircraft finishing material consisting of an acrylic resin vehicle and certain volatile solvents.
A transparent, thermoplastic material used for aircraft windshields and side windows.
A radioactive chemical element found in uranium ores.
An electrical component that can control current or voltage for switching or amplification.
The current in an AC circuit in phase with the voltage.
Radar, radio, and sonar systems that require the transmission of energy.
The method of detection in which a beam of infrared rays its transmitted toward a suspected target.
Any runway or runways currently being used for takeoff or landing.
A cylinder and piston arrangement used to convert hydraulic or pneumatic fluid pressure into work.
Levers attached to aircraft control surfaces to which control cables are connected to move the surfaces.
A device which transforms fluid pressure into mechanical force.
The section and a turbine engine fuel control that schedules the rate of increase of the field to the nozzles when the engine controls call for acceleration.

A regulatory notice sent out by the FAA to the registered owner of an aircraft informing him or her of the discovery of a condition that prevents the aircraft from continuing to meet its conditions for airworthiness.
A mineral-based lubricating oil used in reciprocating engines.
An apparatus that modifies a device so some component can be attached to it.
An electronic computer in an aircraft that senses pitot pressure, static pressure, and total air temperature.
A type of directional radio transmitting antenna made of two vertical conductors from which electromagnetic energy radiates.
And arrangement of logic gates in a computer that adds two bits (binary digits) and produces a sum and a carry bit.
The process of computing with sets of numbers to find their sum.
A chemical added to an engine lubricating oil to alter its basic characteristics.
Primary colors which can be mixed to produce other colors, but which cannot be formed by the mixing of colors.
A binary numerical word used to designate a specific location in a computer memory where data is located.
The registered trade name for a cushioned clamp used to attach fluid lines and wire bundles to an aircraft structure.
A piece of electronic navigation equipment which operates in the low-and medium-frequency bands.
The surface to which an adhesive adheres.
The tendency caused by intermolecular forces for matter to cling together.
A material used to provide a bond between two surfaces by chemical means.
A mixture of water and methanol, which is injected into the carburetor of an aircraft reciprocating engine to prevent detonation when the engine is producing its maximum power.
A system used with some of the large reciprocating engines in which a mixture of water and alcohol is sprayed into the engine with the fuel when operating at extremely high power.
A physical change taking place within a material in which heat energy is neither added to the material nor taken from it.
The rate at which air cools as it is forced upward or warms as it sinks, if no heat energy is added to it and none is taken from it.
The process by which fixed relationships are maintained during changes in temperature, volume, and pressure in a body of air when heat is neither added to nor removed from it.
Airspace over land or water, extending upward from the surface, within which the ready identification, the location, and the control of aircraft are required in the interest of national security.
The two sides of a triangle that have a common angle.
To change any condition to make it more satisfactory or to make it operate better.
A tool used for cutting external threats on round stock.
A horizontal stabilizer that can be adjusted in flight to trim the airplane, so it will fly hands-off at any given airspeed.
An aircraft propeller which has provisions for adjusting the pitch of the blades on the ground when the engine is not running.
The politically appointed head of the Federal Aviation Administration.
The ease with which alternating current can flow in a circuit.
High-strength structural materials made by encapsulating a fibrous material in a resin matrix.
Timing of the ignition of the fuel-air mixture in the cylinders of a reciprocating engine, so the mixture is completely burned by the time the piston reaches the top of its stroke.
The blade in a helicopter rotor system moving in the same direction the helicopter is traveling.
A method of heat transfer by horizontal movement of fluid.
Currents of air moving horizontally over a surface.
Fogs that forms when moist air moves horizontally across a surface cold enough to cool the air to a temperature below its dew point.
A flight condition at the beginning of a turn in which the nose of an airplane starts to move in the direction opposite the direction the turn is being made.
Advice and information provided by an FAA facility to assist pilots in the safe conduct of flight and aircraft movement.
The process of mixing air in a liquid.
A term having to do with the air or with aircraft.
A term used for a radio antenna.
The business of taking pictures from aircraft in flight.
A method used to extend the range of military aircraft by refueling them in the air.
A defined area on land or water intended to be used either wholly or in part for the arrival, departure, and movement of aircraft.
The name given by Dr. Samuel P. Langley to the flying machines built under his supervision between the years of 1891 and 1903.
An aeronautical beacon used to aid in locating an aerodrome from the air.
Air traffic control service for aerodrome traffic.
A unit established to provide air traffic control service to aerodrome traffic.
The elevation of the highest point of the landing area.
The specified path to be flown by aircraft operating in the vicinity of an aerodrome.
The portion of a control surface on an airplane extending ahead of the hinge line.
A form of thrust reverser used on turbojet or turbofan engines.
The use of reverse thrust from propeller or a gas turbine engine to produce a great deal of aerodynamic drag.
The point along the chord of an airfoil where all changes in lift effectively take place.
Nondimensional coefficients for aerodynamic forces and moments..
The total resistance to the movement of an object through the air.
The basic forces acting on an aircraft in flight that are caused by the movement of air over the surfaces.
The temperature rise caused by the friction of high-speed air flowing over a surface.
A force produced by air moving by air moving over a specially shaped surface called an airfoil.
The shape of an object with reference to the airflow over it.
The design of an aerodynamic surface whose strength and stiffness are matched to the aerodynamic loads imposed upon it.
The aerodynamic force that acts on a rotating propeller blade to increase its blade angle..
The branch of science that deals with the forces produced by air flowing over specially shaped surfaces called airfoils.
The registered trade name for a form of microfiche used in the aircraft industry.
A patented propeller that has counterweights around the blade shanks and the blades angled back from the hub to increase the effects of aerodynamic and centrifugal twisting forces.
A visual navigational aid displaying flashes of white and/or colored light.
A map used in air navigation containing all or part of the following: topographic features, hazards sand obstructions, navigation aids, navigation routes, designated .
A primary FAA publication whose purpose is to instruct airmen about operating in the National Airspace System of the U.S..
The branch of science that deals with flight and with the operation of all types of aircraft.
A liquid or solid that is divided into extremely fine particles and dispersed into the air.
The branch of science and technology that deals with travel in the space above the surface of the earth.
A flight vehicle capable of flight in both the atmosphere surrounding the earth and in the space beyond the atmosphere.
A device supported in the air by displacing more than its weight of air.
The branch of science that deals with the flight of lighter-than-air vehicles, such as balloons, dirigibles, or blimps.
The full system of automatic flight control which includes the autopilot, flight director, horizontal situation indicator, air data sensors, and other avionics inputs.
The direction toward the rear of the aircraft.
The rearmost section of a triple-slotted, segmented wing flap.

The position of the piston in the cylinder of a reciprocating engine after the crankshaft, turning in its normal direction of rotation, has caused the piston to pass the bottom of its stroke and start back up.
After Bottom Center (Reciprocating Engine Piston Position)

The position of the piston in the cylinder of a reciprocating engine after the crankshaft, turning in its normal direction of rotation, has caused the piston to pass the top of its stroke and start back down..
After Top Center (Reciprocating Engine Piston Position)
The rearward portion of an engine nacelle or pod.
A device in the exhaust system of a turbojet or turbofan engine, used to increase the thrust for takeoff and for special flight conditions.
A condition that can exist in a reciprocating engine when an excessive amount of fuel is taken into the cylinders.
Fire that continues in the combustor after the engine is shut down.
The light or glow, remaining on the phosphorescent screen of a cathode-ray tube after the electron beam passes.
A turbofan engine with the fan constructed as an extension of some of the turbine blades, rather than as an extension of the compressor blades.
The process of increasing the strength and hardness of aluminum alloy after it has been solution heat-treated.
A change in the characteristics of a material that takes place over a period of time under specified environmental conditions.
To stir something or to shake it up to mix its components.
Altitude, expressed in feet measured above ground level.
An irregular imaginary line across the surface of the earth along which the magnetic and geographic poles are in alignment and along which there is no variation error.
Aircraft especially designed and built for use in agriculture.
A primary flight control surface mounted on the trailing edge of an airplane wing, near the tip.
The angle of deflection of an aileron from its neutral, or trailing, position.
A short partial spar in the wing of an airplane that serves as a point of attachment for the aileron hinges.
Reference locations along the span of an aileron.
A primary FAA publication whose purpose is to instruct airmen about operating in the National Airspace System of the U.S..
A physical mixture of gases that make up the atmosphere of the earth.
A component in a centrifugal-compressor gas turbine engine.
A small hole in the fuel passage between the float between the float bowl and the discharge nozzle of a float carburetor.
A device that can be extended from the structure of an airplane to produce a large amount of parasite drag.
An organization or person involved in the business of transporting people or cargo by air for compensation or hire.
A check valve used in the oil tank of some aircraft reciprocating engines equipped with dry-sump lubrication systems..
Air Carrier District Office. See ACDO
The portion of the transportation industry that deals with the carriage of people or cargo by air for compensation or hire.
The process of treating the air in a building or compartment to control its temperature, humidity, cleanliness, and velocity of its movement.
The removal of unwanted heat by transferring it directly into the air that flows over the component.
An electronic computer in an aircraft that senses pitot pressure, static pressure, and total air temperature.
A military emergency condition declared by a designated authority.
Airspace over land or water, extending upward from the surface, within which the ready identification, the location, and the control of aircraft are required in the interest of national security.
The mass of air in a given volume.
A filter through which air entering the induction system of a reciprocating engine must pass.
A fault resembling haze in an enamel or lacquer finish of an aircraft.
A type of starter used on some gas turbine engines in which a stream of high-pressure compressed air is directed onto the blades of the compressor or turbine to rotate ether engine for starting.
Air Impingement Starter (Gas Turbine Engine Starter)
The portion of the aircraft ahead of the engine compartment that takes the air into the aircraft and directs it into the engine at the correct speed and direction.
A pocket of air trapped in a line which carries a liquid.
An extensive body of air within which the conditions of temperature and moisture in a horizontal plane are essentially uniform.
A system used to identify and characterize the different air masses according to a basic scheme.
The force used in pressure carburetors and certain fuel injection systems to determine the amount of fuel to be metered into the engine.
Any facility used, available for use, or designated for use as an aid in air navigation.
Air route traffic control center radar used primarily to detect and display an aircraft's position while enroute between terminal areas.
A hooded opening used to direct outside air into an aircraft structure in flight..
A seal around a rotating shaft, used to keep air from passing out of the housing holding the shaft..
The process of starting an aircraft engine in flight with the engine rotated by aerodynamic forces acting on the propeller or compressor blades..
Movement of a helicopter above the surface but at an altitude of less than 100 feet above ground level..
Aircraft operating in the air or on an airport surface, exclusive of loading ramps and parking areas..
An authorization by air traffic control, for the purpose of preventing collision between known aircraft, for an aircraft to proceed under specified traffic conditions within controlled airspace..
The control of aircraft traffic from the ground.
A person authorized by the FAA to provide air traffic control service.
Air Traffic Control System Command Center (see ATCCC).
Air Traffic Control System Command Center

A generic term meaning flight information service, alerting service, air traffic advisory service, and air traffic control service, including area control service, approach control service, and airport control service..
The standardized format for aircraft maintenance manuals developed by the ATA.
The business of moving people, mail, or cargo by air.
An air-driven turbine used to spin the engine compressor through a system of reduction gears..
Air Turbine Starter (Gas Turbine Engine Starter)
The condition of an aircraft when it is off the ground and supported in the air by aerodynamic or aerostatic forces.
The amount of delay to be encountered in airborne holding.
A short-range airborne radar system carried in fighter and attach aircraft to locate and track their targets.
A type of airborne radar that filters out stationary objects and displays only moving targets.
An engine that requires an intake of air to supply the oxygen it needs to operate.
A capacitor that uses air as the dielectric.
A reciprocating engine whose excess heat is removed by transferring it directly into the air flowing over the engine.
An oil-to-air heat exchanger in the lubrication system of an aircraft engine.
Hollow blades on the turbine wheel of certain high-power gas turbine engines.
A transformer containing two or more coils wound on a core of paper or other nonmagnetic material.
Any weight-carrying device designed to be supported by the air.
Any damage or injury that occurs when an aircraft is moving with the intention of flight.
The modification of an aircraft, its structure, or its components which changes the physical or flight characteristics of the aircraft.
A grouping of aircraft based on a speed of 1.3 times their stall speed in the landing configuration at maximum gross landing weight.
The basic weight of an aircraft, including the crew, ready for flight but without payload and fuel.
A source of electrical energy for an aircraft that may be used for starting the engine and as an auxiliary electrical power when the engine-driven generator is not operating.
For the purpose of wake turbulence separation minimums, ATC has classified aircraft as heavy, large, and small.
Classification of aircraft according to their maximum certificated gross weight.
Stranded steel cable used to actuate the controls of an aircraft.
An engine that is used or intended to be used for propelling aircraft..
A systematic check of an aircraft and its components.

Information sheets, published by the Federal Aviation Administration, that contain pertinent specifications for certificated aircraft of which there are fewer than fifty of that model still registered.
Aircraft records containing the operational or maintenance history of the aircraft.
The hoses, tubing, fittings, and connections used for carrying fluids through an aircraft.
A term used to indicate that a particular piece of equipment or material meets the rigid standards established by the military services or by an aircraft manufacturer for use in an aircraft.
Documentation of the flight time and the maintenance that has been performed on an aircraft, its engines, or its components.
Restoration of an aircraft and/or its components to a condition of airworthiness after a failure or the occurrence of damage or wear.
The final adjustment and alignment of the various component parts of an aircraft to give It the proper aerodynamic characteristics.
A computer system that receives radar track data from all 20 Continental U.S. air route traffic control centers and organizes data in a mosaic display to present it on a computer screen.
Documentation that includes the pertinent specifications for aircraft certificated under the Civil Air Regulations (CARs).
A system for cooling the air in the cabin of a turbine-powered aircraft.
The component in an air-cycle cooling system that includes the expansion turbine and the compressor.
To remove moisture from a material by exposing it to the air.
Any area in which aircraft may land, take off, and park.
Any surface designed to obtain a useful reaction, or lift, from air passing over it.

A set of curves for an airfoil section plotted from wind tunnel data that shows the effect of angle of attack on the coefficient of lift, coefficient of drag, lift over drag ratio, and the movement of the center of pressure.
The outline of an airfoil section.
The fuselage, booms, nacelles, cowlings, fairings, airfoil surfaces (including rotors but not excluding propellers and rotating airfoils of engines..
A person holding a certificate issued by the Federal Aviation Administration that authorizes him or her to perform maintenance and inspections on the airframe of FAA-certificated aircraft.
The ratio of the weight of the air to that of the fuel in the mixture being fed into the cylinders of a reciprocating engine.
A company or organization that operates aircraft for the transportation of persons or cargo for compensation or hire.
A large transport-type aircraft used in air commerce for the transportation of passengers and/or cargo.
A patented form of cowling fastener in which the actual locking is done by rotating a steel cross-pin in a spring-steel receptacle.
A person involved in flying, maintaining, or operating aircraft.
The certificate issued by the Federal Aviation Administration authorizing a person to perform certain aviation-related matters.

An inflight weather advisory message issued only to amend an area forecast concerning weather phenomena of operational interest to all aircraft and potentially hazardous to aircraft having limited capability because of lack of equipment, instrumentation, or pilot qualifications.
A heat exchanger that uses a flow of ambient air to remove heat from engine lubricating oil.
A component in a turbine engine lubrication system that removes the air from the scavenged oil before the oil is returned to the tank.

The process of electrically connecting all isolated components to the aircraft structure.
The method of joining parts by using chemical adhesives, rather than any form of mechanical fastener.
An adhesive used to bond together materials used in aircraft construction.
A low-resistance wire or metal strap used to connect a structural component or an electrical component to the basic structure of an aircraft.
A system of mathematical logic used to permit computations to be performed by binary electrical circuits.
A term for manifold pressure which has been increased above atmospheric pressure by a supercharger.
A constant-voltage charge given to a partially discharged storage battery for a short period of time.
An electrically driven centrifugal pump mounted in the bottom of the fuel tanks in large aircraft.
A form of power brake which uses hydraulic system pressure to help the pilot apply force to the brake master cylinder.
Flight controls of large, high-performance aircraft actuated by hydraulic cylinders.
An induction coil excited by pulsating DC supplied by the aircraft battery and a vibrator.
A small, auxiliary, hand-cranked magneto used with some of the older aircraft engines to provide a hot, retarded spark for starting the engine.
A small, auxiliary venturi whose discharge is located in the throat of a larger venturi.
The diameter of a round hole.
The diameter of the inside of the cylinder of a reciprocating engine.
An instrument used to examine the inside of a structure through a very small hole.
A white crystal (H3BO3) that can be dissolved in water to make a weak acid solution.
A method of increasing the size of a hole in a piece of material by cutting it with a rotary cutting tool.
A soft, brown, nonmetallic, trivalent chemical element.
An enlarged area in a casting or machined part.
Any gas stored in heavy steel containers, with the gas kept under pressure.
A condition in the installation of a propeller on a splined shaft when either the front or rear cone contacts an obstruction that prevents the cone seating properly inside the propeller hub.
The position of the piston in a reciprocating engine cylinder when the piston is at the bottom of its stroke and the wrist pin, crank pin, and center of the crankshaft are all in line.
A reamer used to smooth and enlarge blind holes.
A tool used to cut threads all the way to the bottom of a hole.
The layer of air that flows next to an aerodynamic surface.
A method of decreasing aerodynamic drag caused by the turbulent flow of the boundary layer.
The measuring element used in certain types of pressure-measuring instruments.
The weight of an aircraft, including the crew, ready for flight but without payload and fuel.
A shock wave which forms when an aircraft is flying at a speed faster than the speed of sound, a speed greater than Mach one.
A form of control system which uses a spring steel wire, enclosed inside a helically wound wire casing.
A handy knot used for such aeronautical purposes as securing an aircraft to prevent wind damage.
The main spanwise structural member of a wing made in the form of a box.
A metal-forming machine similar to a leaf, or cornice, brake.
A wrench with an enclosed end shaped with six, eight, or twelve points to fit a square- or hexagonal-head bolt or nut.
A mixing procedure in which the pigment in a can of paint is thoroughly mixed with the vehicle.
One of the basic gas laws, which states that the produce found by multiplying the pressure of a gas by its volume is always constant.
A part of a structure that supports or strengthens the main load-carrying portion of the structure.
A thin wire nail with a small-diameter, barrel-shaped head.
A special drill used for drilling cured Kevlar-reinforced composite materials.
A woven metal tube used to encases a wire carrying alternating current.
A mechanism inside an aircraft wheel used to apply friction to the wheel to slow or stop its rotation.
A metalworking tool used to make straight bends across sheets of metal.
A floating plate in an energizing-type brake to which the wheel cylinder and the brake shoes attach.
A hydraulically operated clamp that holds the brake linings on either side eof a brake disk.
The horsepower actually delivered to the output shaft of a rotating machine.
A material with a high coefficient of friction and the ability to maintain its friction and strength when it is hot.
The average pressure which, if imposed on the pistons uniformly from the top to the bottom of each power stroke, would produce the measured (brake) power output.
A measure of the amount of fuel used for a given amount of power developed by a heat engine.
A condition noted in an ATIS broadcast when the tower has received a runway braking action report of poor or nil>.
A report of conditions on the airport movement area providing a pilot with a degree/quality of braking that he might expect.
A condition of wood which causes it to have low shock resistance so that it fails abruptly when it is bent.
An alloy of copper and zinc made up of approximately 67% copper and 33% zinc.
A method of joining pieces of metal by wetting their surfaces with a molten brass alloy.
A thin protruding-head rivet that was at one time popular for aircraft sheet metal construction.
A method of joining metals by allowing capillary action to pull molten, nonferrous filler metal between close-fitting parts.
A device for building experimental electric circuits that allows the components to be temporarily connected into the circuit, making it easy to exchange components.
A wavy line or a line containing a series of zip-sags, used to show that part of the component has been left off drawing.
A form of double-throw switch that breaks one circuit before it makes contact with the other circuit.
The voltage that must be placed across the dielectric in an electrical or electronic component to cause the dielectric to break down and conduct current.
Electrical contacts in the primary circuit of an aircraft magneto that are opened by a cam turned by the engine.
A condition in which the breaker points in an aircraft magneto bounce open, rather than remaining closed when the cam follower moves off of the cam lobe.
Layers of reinforcing fabric (cords) in an aircraft tire between the casing plies and the tread rubber.
A technique used to direct aircraft out of the approach stream.
A hand-held drill motor used to drill relatively large holes in wood or metal.
A vent line in an aircraft engine that allows the air pressure inside the engine crankcase to be the same as the pressure of the surrounding air.
An aneroid-operated valve ohm the overboard vent line of the lubrication system of some turbine engines.
A locking chamber in a cartridge starter that holds a pyrotechnic cartridge (a power charge).
A reactor that produces fissionable material as well as consuming it.
The constant-pressure cycle of energy release used to describe the action of a gas turbine engine.
An electrical circuit containing four impedances connected in such a way that their schematic diagram forms a square.
An electrical rectifier circuit using four diodes to change alternating current into full-wave rectified direct current.
A narrow, intense echo on the range-height indicator scope resulting from water covered ice particles of high reflectivity at the melting level.
A solution of salt (sodium chloride) and water, used as a quenching medium in the heat treatment of metal.
A method of measuring the hardness of metal.
A form of damage to the hardened surface of a bearing roller or race caused by excessive radial loads on the bearings.
A physical characteristic of a material that causes it to break, or fracture, without bending or distorting in any appreciable amount.
The process of removing excess metal by pushing or pulling a cutting tool through a hole or the inside of a cylinder.
A radio antenna capable of receiving or transmitting a broad band of frequencies.
The transmission of information not addressed to a specific station or person, and for which no acknowledgment is expected.
A transmission of information not addressed to a specific station or person, and for which no acknowledgment is expected.
A type of graph used to show the way values change.
A heavy, volatile, corrosive, reddish-brown, nonmetallic, liquid chemical element.
A copper alloy containing tin and sometimes small amounts of zinc and phosphorus.
The component in an electric motor or generator through which current flows into and out of the armature.
A device used to apply paint to a surface.
A protective frame at the tail of a single-rotor helicopter used to protect the tail rotor from damage during ground operation.
A measure of the amount of fuel used for a given amount of power developed by a heat engine.
The position of the piston in the cylinder of a reciprocating engine as the piston is moving upward, toward the top of its stroke, with the crankshaft turning in the direction of normal rotation.
A small volume of gas entrapped in a liquid.
A method of digital data storage in which individual bits (0s and 1s) are stored in the form of extremely small localized magnetic fields in a thin film of magnetic crystalline material.
A type of celestial navigation instrument.
Colloquial, or informal, term for a turbine blade.
A turbine wheel in a turbosupercharger or in a gas turbine engine.
The portions of air-fan blades that are in the exhaust of the core engine.
The process in which a shop head is formed on a solid aircraft rivet.
A heavy steel block or bar with smooth, hardened surfaces, or faces.
A voltage used to oppose another voltage.
A wrinkle or kind in the surface of sheet metal aircraft structure caused by an excessive bending or compressive load on the structure.
A digital electronic component that has one input and one output, with the output having the same condition as the input.
An amplifier used to isolate one circuit from another circuit.
Turbulent movement of the air over an aerodynamic surface.
A movable marker on a flight instrument that may be set to reference a particular indication of the instrument.
A commonly used term for anything that prevents a system or component functioning as it should.
A handy tool for rough troubleshooting an aircraft electrical system.
A manually operated valve on a liquid-oxygen converter used to control the amount of pressure inside the converter.
An L-shaped extrusion having an enlarged, rounded edge that resembles a bulb on one of its legs.
A rounded end on a turbine blade that mates with a rounded hole in the periphery of the turbine disk, or wheel.
Cargo capable of being stacked on the floor of the aircraft carrying it.
A structural partition that divides the fuselage of an aircraft into compartments or bays.
A method of shrinking or stretching sheet metal into compound curves by hand-hammering it into a sandbag or into or around wood or metal forming blocks.
An electrical cable made up of individually insulated wires.
An elastic cord made of a series of small strips of rubber or rubber bands.
The uplifting force produced on an object when it is placed in a fluid.
Turbulence which forms on an airfoil surface when the angle of attack becomes so great that the air no longer flows smoothly over the surface but breaks away.
The angle of attack at which air flowing over an aerodynamic surface no longer flows smoothly, but breaks away and forms a turbulent flow (it burbles).
A coat of lacquer or dope in which some of the thinner is replaced with an equal amount of retarder.
The section of a gas turbine engine in which the fuel is injected, mixed with air and burned.
The portion of an engine pod or nacelle of a turbojet-powered aircraft that houses the burner section of the engine.
The static pressure inside the combustors, or burners, of a gas turbine engine.
Individual combustion chambers of a gas turbine engine.
The process in which a material is consumed by fire.
A process in the manufacture of sensitive electronic equipment in which the equipment is operated for a specified period of time.
The lowest temperature at which a petroleum product in an open container will continue to burn when it is ignited by an open flame held near its surface.
To smooth the surface of metal that has been damaged by a deep scratch or gouge.
A sharp, rough edge of a piece of metal left when the metal is sheared, punched, or drilled.
The compressor speed of an engine at which the centrifugal loads are so high the compressor will fly apart.
A point within an electrical system from which the individual circuits get their power.
A power distribution point in an aircraft electrical system.
A circuit breaker used to connect two electrical bus bars.
A type of friction bearing consisting of a removable cylinder made of some material, such as bronze, that has a low coefficient of friction.
A method of joining two pieces of thermoplastic material.
A type of welded joint in which the pieces of metal to be joined are placed so their edges touch, but do not overlap.
The rib at the inboard end of a wing panel.
A type of tail configuration used on some models of the Beech Bonanza.
A flat, disk-shaped valve used to control the flow of fluid in a round pipe or tube.
A line used to locate a position to the right or left of the center line of an aircraft structure.
The trade name for a synthetic rubber product made by the polymerization of isobutylene.
An aircraft finishing product having a film base of cellulose fibers dissolved in a mixture of acetic and butyric acids.
A law of meteorology that helps understand the circulation of the wind.
A capacitor that provides a low-impedance path for alternating current to flow around, or bypass, a circuit component which is being used to produce a DC voltage drop.
A gas turbine engine in which a portion of the air moved by the first stages of the compressor bypasses the combustion chambers of the engine and mixed with the hot gases in the tail pipe.
The ratio of the mass airflow, in pounds per second, through the fan section of a turbofan engine to the mass airflow that passes through the gas generator portion of the engine.
A valve used to maintain a specific pressure in a fluid power system by bypassing some of the fluid back to the inlet of the system-pressure pump.
A group of binary digits (bits) operated on as a unit.
An arrangement of struts or other supporting structure that holds the wing of an airplane above the fuselage.
The portion of an aircraft structure in which the passengers ride.
The equivalent altitude at which the cabin pressure of a pressurized aircraft is maintained.
The difference in the pressure inside the cabin of a pressurized aircraft and the pressure of the air outside of the cabin.
The regulator in an aircraft pressurization system that controls the position of the outflow valve to maintain the air in the cabin at the desired pressure.
An air compressor which supplies compressed air to pressurize the cabin of an aircraft.
A coarse file with one flat face and one convex, or rounded, face.
A piece of stranded wire or a number of individually insulated wires enclosed in single bundle or group.
A pin in a control-cable pulley bracket that prevents the cable moving out of the pulley groove when the cable tension is loosened.
A chart, normally included in an aircraft maintenance manual, that shows the proper control cable tension for any given ambient air temperature.
A silvery-white, malleeable, ductile, metallic chemical element.
A type of electrical standard cell which produces an accurate reference voltage for use when making precision electrical measurements.
A form of corrosion protection for steel parts.
The procedure of locking the gimbals of a gyroscopic instrument so it will not be damaged by abrupt flight maneuvers of rough handling.
A mechanism inside a gyroscopic instrument that locks the gimbals in a rigid position and holds the gyro so it cannot tumble if the aircraft maneuvers exceed the tumble limits of the gyro.
A silvery, moderately hard, metallic chemical element.
A compound of calcium and carbon which decomposes, or breaks down, in water to produce acetylene gas.
A term that may be used in place of tentative or actual calculated landing time, whichever applies.
To pass fabric through a series of heated rollers to give it a smooth and shiny surface.
A period of time used by the FAA for inspection and certification purposes.
A measure of the speed at which an aircraft is moving through the air.
An orifice, or hole, having a specific diameter, length, and approach and departure angles.
The procedure in which the indication of an instrument is compared with a standard value.
A card usually mounted near an instrument to how the amount of error in the instrument.
A curve plotted to show the instrument errors at different points on the scale.
A radioactive, synthetic chemical element produced by bombarding curium with helium isotopes.
Any combination of letters or numbers that identifies a communications facility.
Numbers and names used to identify components or parts in an aircraft drawing.
The initial voice contact between a facility and an aircraft.
The absence of wind or apparent motion of the air.
The unit of heat energy in the centimeter-gram-second system of measurements.
An instrument used to measure quantities of heat released or absorbed during chemical reactions or physical changes of state.
An eccentric, or lobe, on a rotating shaft that changes rotary motion into linear motion.
The number of degrees a cam rotates during the time the object controlled by the cam does not move.
A reciprocating engine with axial cylinders arranged around a central shaft.
An eccentric used to change rotary motion into linear motion.
The peak, or highest point, on a cam.
A device that allows a wheel to turn in one direction, but prevents its turning in the opposite direction.
A ring or plate with lobes ground around its periphery.
The amount of curve of an airfoil section.
The amount the wheels of an aircraft are inclined, or tilted, from the vertical.
A specially shaped piston used in an aircraft reciprocating engine.
A straight, gear-driven shaft that contains lobes used to operate the intake and the exhaust valves.
A valve attached to a sealed can of liquid refrigerant that controls the flow of refrigerant into an aircraft vapor-cycle cooling system.
A type of combustor used in some of the large turbojet and turbofan engines.
A type of combustor used in some of the large turbojet and turbofan engines.
A horizontal control surface mounted ahead of the main wings to provide longitudinal stability and control.
A horizontal control surface mounted ahead of the main wing to provide longitudinal stability and control.
A type of airplane in which the horizontal auxiliary control is mounted ahead of the main lifting plane.
A configuration in which the span of the forward wing is substantially less than that of the main wing..
A measurement of luminous intensity in the International System of measurements.
To take serviceable components from one unit and use them on another.
The transparent enclosure that covers an aircraft cockpit.
The fabric body of a parachute.
The wall of a compartment in an aircraft that, because of structural reasons, is not straight up and down.
A rate gyro whose gimbal axis is tilted so it can sense rotation of the aircraft about its roll axis as well as its yaw axis.
A beam with all of its support inside the beam itself.
A wing with no external bracing, since all of the strength of the wing is inside its structure.
A combustor, or burner section of a gas turbine engine made up of several individual burner cans.
A heavy, tightly woven cloth made of cotton.
A standing, or stationary, cap-like cloud crowning a mountain summit.
A threaded fastener whose shank passes through a clear hole in one piece of material and screws into threads cut into the second piece.
The main top and bottom members of a wing rib.
The amount of electrical charge that can be stored in a capacitor under a given amount of electrical pressure (voltage).
The continuation of the spark across the gap in a shielded spark plug after the fuel-air mixture in the cylinder is ignited.
A piece of electrical test equipment made up of a number of capacitors and selector switches.
A piece of precision electrical test equipment used to measure capacitance..
A type of fuel quantity indicating system that shows the amount of fuel in the tanks of an aircraft.
A method of joining stages of electronic circuits with capacitors.
A process in which part of the energy in the output of an electronic circuit is fed back to the input through a capacitor.
An electrical load that produces more capacitive reactance than inductive reactance in the circuit.
Opposition to the flow of alternating current caused by capacitance in the circuit.
The amount of time, measured in seconds, needed for the voltage across a capacitor to rise to 63.2% of the source voltage.
An electrical component made of two conductors separated by an insulator, or dielectric.
A type of high-energy ignition system that produces a hot spark for starting a gas turbine engine.
A type of electrical filtered used to smooth the pulsations in the output of an electronic power supply.
An AC motor whose rotor is excited by voltage induced into it from the stator windings.
The total amount of current available in a battery or electrical cell.
A narrow-blade cold chisel with either a single or double bevel.
The action that causes a liquid to climb the walls of a container or to be drawn up into extremely tiny tubes or between close-fitting parts.
A metal or glass tube with such a small inside diameter that capillary action causes liquid to move in the tube.
A device in the control system of an aircraft that allows the automatic pilot to move the control surfaces.
A form of machine screw whose head has several radial holes, holes that go across the head, through it.
A flat container made of thin disks of corrugated metal soldered together and used to sense changing pressure.
A lighter-than-air device anchored to the ground with a steel cable.
A screw that has a section of the threads on its shank next to its head cut away.
A chemical compound of carbon and a metallic element.
A metal-cutting machine tool whose cutting faces are surfaced with tungsten carbide, tantalum carbide, or titanium carbide.
The registered trade name for certain cutting tools and dies that have tungsten carbide bonded to their cutting or wearing surfaces.
An abundant, nonmetallic chemical element that occurs in all organic compounds and in many inorganic compounds.
An electric arc produced when current flows through ionized air from the tip of one carbon rod to the tip of another.
A form of soft and fluffy carbon.
A special multiple-disk brake using pure carbon for both rotating and stationary disks.
A colorless, odorless, and tasteless gas that is about 1.5 times as heavy as air.
A fire extinguisher that holds carbon dioxide gas under a pressure of about 800 to 900 pounds per inch.
The knocking sound made in a reciprocating engine by detonation that follows preignition.
A type of microphone used in a telephone and with some types of radio transmitters.
A colorless, odorless gas that forms from incomplete combustion of an organic fuel.
A packed of chemical crystals mounted in the aircraft cockpit or cabin where they are easily visible.
A type of variable resistor used in some electrical equipment.
A voltage regulator used with some high-output DC generators in which a stack of pure carbon disks acts as the resistance element in the field circuit.
A component used to insert a controlled amount of resistance into an electrical circuit.
A rubbing seal in a gas turbine engine between a rotating shaft and a fixed housing.
Steel in which carbon is the chief, pr principal, alloying agent.
A colorless, dense, liquid halogenated hydrocarbon that has, in the past, been used as a fire extinguishing agent and as a cleaning fluid for clothing.
An ignition system malfunction caused by a fine track of carbon deposited inside the distributor of an aircraft magneto.
An electrical resistor made by vacuum-depositing a thin film of carbon on a ceramic cylinder.
An electrochemical cell that changes chemical energy into electrical energy.
The registered trade name for several types of man-made abrasives.
A type of fuel metering system used on some reciprocating engines.
A sheet metal jacket surrounding part of the engine exhaust system.
The temperature of the air as it enters the carburetor.
Ice that forms inside the throat of a carburetor installed on an aircraft reciprocating engine.
A form of heat treatment of steel in which the surface absorbs extra carbon and becomes hard and brittle, while the center of the steel remains relatively soft and tough.
A flame produced by an oxy-acetylene torch when there is too much acetylene gas for the amount of oxygen being metered by the torch.
The layers of rubberized fabric that make up the body of an aircraft tire.
Odd or even thousand-foot altitudes or flight levels.
The heading of an aircraft along any of the four cardinal directions shown on a compass.
A microphone that is directional in its ability to pick up sounds, picking up sounds in front of it while rejecting sounds behind it.
A small inverted V (^) used to show the new location of the decimal in multiplication and division problems using decimal fractions.
An ideal reversible, but unattainable, cycle of energy transformation that explains the operation of a perfect heat engine.
A round-headed bolt with a square section of the shank just below the head.
The frequency of the alternating current carrier that produces the electromagnetic waves which radiate from a radio transmitting antenna.
A type of fuse used to protect an electrical circuit from an excess of current.
A type of starter used on some large aircraft reciprocating engines.
A pneumatic starter for a gas turbine engine that uses gas pressure produced when powder in a cartridge burns in the breech of the starter.
A disposable filter element used in an aircraft fuel or lubrication system.
A measure of the speed at which an aircraft is moving through the air.
A method of connecting multiple stages of electrical circuits so the output of one stage feeds the input of the next stage.
The cumulative effect that occurs when the output of one series of components serves as the input to the next series.
A device that can be used in an electrical circuit to get a high voltage.
Vanes in an aerodynamic blockage-type thrust reverser used to turn the stream of exhaust gases to produce a reverse thrust.
A method of heat treatment of steel in which the surface of the metal is hardened while its inside stays comparatively soft and tough.
A relatively low pressure maintained inside the bearing cavities of an engine-driven hydraulic pump.
A form of powdered glue made from milk.
The rubber and fabric body of a pneumatic tire.
A form of wire nail made of smaller gage wire than that used for a common nail of the same length.
Iron that contains carbon and silicon.
A form of hexagonal nut (a six-sided nut) that has slots cut across its end.
A method of forming an object by pouring molten metal or liquid plastic resin into a mold.
Extreme turbulence found at high altitude.
A substance used to change the speed or rate of a chemical action without being chemically changed itself.
A method of refining petroleum products.
A mechanism used to hurl, or launch, an object at a high rate of speed.

(1) As used with respect to the certification , ratings, privileges, and limitations of airmen, means a broad classification of aircraft. (2) As used with respect to the certification of aircraft, means a grouping of aircraft based upon intended use or operating limitations..

With respect to transport category rotorcraft, means multiengine rotorcraft designed with engine and system isolation features specified in Part 29 and utilizing scheduled takeoff and landing operations under a critical engine failure concept which assures adequate designated surface area and adequate performance capability for continued safe flight in the event of engine failure..
With respect to transport category rotorcraft, means single-engine or multiengine rotorcraft which do not fully meet all Category A standards..

With respect to the operation of aircraft, means a straight-in ILS approach to the runway of an airport under a Category II ILS instrument approach procedure issued by the Administrator or other appropriate authority..

With respect to the operation of aircraft, means an ILS approach to and landing on, the runway of an airport using a Category III ILS approach procedure issued by the Administrator or other appropriate authority..
A curve formed by a flexible cable suspended between two points at the same level.
Negative dihedral. The wings of an airplane, as they are viewed from the front, are not usually straight; they normally angle upward from the center (called positive dihedral).
The end of a semiconductor diode made of N-type material.
The active element in an electrochemical cell that is reduced, or loses oxygen in the chemical action which causes electrons to flow.
Streams of electrons emitted by the cathode in a special form of electron tube called a cathode-ray tube (CRT).
A display tube used in oscilloscopes, digital computers, and television receivers.
An area within a piece of metal to which electrons from the anodic area have migrated.
A positive ion that moves toward the cathode in the process of electrolysis.
A narrow walkway inside a structure that allows a person to move through an area that is otherwise inaccessible.
Any material that can eat away another material by chemical action.
A common name for sodium hydroxide, NaOH.
A condition that exists in a fluid pump when there is not enough pressure in the reservoir to force fluid to the inlet of the pump.
A small, low-voltage battery used in some of the older, battery-powered, tube-type radios to provide a grid bias voltage for some of the vacuum tubes.
A classification of maintenance inspections or checks used in airline operation.
The lowest level at which condensation will occur as a result of convection due to surface heating.
A screw-type clamp made in the shape of letter C.
A duct that has a decreasing cross section in the direction of flow (convergent) until a minimum area is reached.
An indicator used with VOR, LORAN, or GPS navigation systems to indicate the direction and relative amount of deviation from the desired course.
A component in a flight management computer system that contains a cathode-ray tube and a keyboard with alphanumeric keys and mode-select and line-select keys.
The registered trade name for an inorganic aircraft fabric woven of polyester fibers.
The height above the earth's surface of the lowest layer of cloud or obscuring phenomena reported as 'broken,' 'overcast,' or 'obscuration, and not classified as 'thin' or 'partial.'.
A small, black, helium-filled balloon used to find the height of a base of clouds.
A light used by weather observers to measure the height of the bottom of a layer of clouds at night.
A form of navigation used by airplanes and ships.
An electrochemical device consisting of two electrodes surrounded by an electrolyte.
The registered trade name for one of the early thermoplastic materials.
A material obtained from natural fibrous plants such as cotton and kapok.
A form of finishing material for fabric-covered aircraft made of a cellulose fiber dissolved in nitric and sulfuric acids.
Temperature measured on a scale that sets the freezing point of water at 0o and its boiling point at 100o.
A voltage produced in the armature of an electric motor as the armature windings cut across the fixed magnetic field .
A point within an object that is the same distance from all points on the surface of the object.
A cutting tool which combines a twist drill and a 60o countersink.
A thin line consisting of alternate long and short dashes used in an aircraft drawing to show the center of a part.
The point in an object at which all of the weight is considered to be concentrated.

An envelope drawn on a graph included in aircraft Type Certificate Data Sheets and aircraft flight operations manuals showing the center of gravity limits for all weights up to the maximum allowable gross weight of the aircraft.
Center Of Gravity Envelope (A/C Weight And Balance)
The specified forward and aft points beyond which the CG must not be located during flight.
Center Of Gravity Limits (A/C Eight And Balance)
The distance in inches between the forward allowable center of gravity and the rearward allowable center of gravity .
Center Of Gravity Range (A/C Weight And Balance)
The location along the chord line of an airfoil at which all the lift forces produced by the airfoil are considered to be concentrated.
The location within a body at which its entire mass is considered to be balanced.
The point on the chord line of an airfoil (a line through the airfoil that joins the leading edge and the trailing edge) where all the aerodynamic forces are considered to be concentrated.
The distance between the leading edge of an airfoil and the location of the center of pressure expressed as a ratio of this distance to the length of the airfoil chord line.
A small, metalworking punch used to make an impression in a piece of metal to hold the point of a twist drill so it can start cutting without walking over the surface of the metal.
A computer program developed to provide a backup system for airport surveillance radar in the event of a failure or malfunction.
An unscheduled weather advisory issued by center weather service unit meteorologists for ATC use to alert pilots of existing or anticipated adverse weather conditions within the next two hours.
A cam on the shock strut of a retractable nose gear that aligns the wheel when there is no weight on the landing gear, so it will fit into the nose wheel well.
Cones installed on a splined propeller shaft to hold the propeller hub centered.
A twin-engine airplane with both engines mounted in the fuselage.
Specified airspace within which an air traffic control center (ATC) provides air traffic control and advisory service.
A winding on an electrical transformer that has a tap, or connection, located in its electrical center.
The name formerly used door Celsius temperature.
The system of metric measurement in which the centimeter is the basic unit of linear measurement, the gram is the basic unit of mass, and the second is the basic unit of time; know as cgs system.
The portion of a computer that contains the main storage, the arithmetic-logic-unit, or ALU, and special register groups.
A type of fuel system used in large aircraft that allows all the fuel tanks to be fueled from a single point, usually under the wing.
A friction brake used on a hoist drum.
A form of friction clutch that engages when the drive wheel reaches a certain speed.
A compressor in a gas turbine engine that uses a scroll-type impeller.
A filter that separates contaminants from a fluid by centrifugal action.
A force that acts outwardly on any body moving in a curved path.
A force which tries to cause rotation.
A variable displacement pump which moves fluid by taking it into the center of a scroll-type impeller and slinging it outward by centrifugal action.
An electrical switch actuated by centrifugal force and mounted inside of a piece of rotating machinery.
A type of mechanical tachometer used to measure the speed of rotation of a shaft or wheel.
The force acting about the longitudinal axis of a propeller blade which tries to rotate the blade to a low-pitch angle. See CTM.
The force moment, acting about the longitudinal axis of a propeller blade, which tries to rotate the blade toward a low-pitch angle.
A device used to separate a liquid mixture or suspension into its various components which have different specific gravities.
A large machine having a long motor-driven arm which moves a vehicle in a circular path at various rotational speeds.
A method of separating liquids which have different densities by spinning them in a centrifuge.
The force within a body that opposes centrifugal force as the body rotates or spins.
The center of mass of a body.
Any of several hard, brittle, heat-resistant, noncorrosive materials made by shaping and then firing a mineral, such as clay, at a high temperature.
A permanent magnet made by pressing together a mixture of ceramic material and sintered magnetic particles.
An air traffic control facility which combines the function of an air route traffic control center (ARTCC) and a radar approach control facility.

(1) For turbine enginepowered airplanes certificated after August 29, 1959, an area beyond the runway, not less than 500 feet wide, centrally located about the extended centerline of the runway, and under the control of the airport authorities..(2) For turbine engine powered airplanes certificated after September 30, 1958, but before August 30, 1959, an area beyond the takeoff runway extending no less than 300 feet on either side of the extended centerline of the runway, at an elevation no higher than the elevation of the end of the runway, clear of all fixed obstacles, and under the control of the airport authorities..
A patented spring-type fastener used to hold metal sheets until they can be permanently riveted together.

Two or more shafts that have the same axis - they are concentric with each other.

Anyone, except an air carrier, who engages in the carriage of persons or property in an aircraft for compensation.

The direction to which the magnets in an aircraft compass actually point.

A maintenance procedure that corrects a magnetic compass for deviation error.
