Lines which have the same center.
The process in which a material is changed from one form, or state, into a denser state.
The height at which a rising parcel or layer of air would become saturated if it were lifted adiabatically - lifted with heat neither added to it nor taken from it.
Small particles in the air on which water vapor condenses or sublimates.
Cloud-like streamers often seen behind aircraft flying in clear, cold air.
The component in a vapor-cycle air conditioning system in which the refrigerant gives up the heat it picked up as it passed through the evaporator.
An old term for a capacitor.
The British name for a convergent-divergent duct.
An engine control used with a turboprop engine to control the pitch of the propeller for the flight operating range, the alpha range, of operation.
Unsaturated air that will be unstable if it becomes saturated.
A measure of the ability of a device to conduct electricity.
A method of heat transfer by direct contact in which heat energy moves from a higher energy level to a lower level by direct contact.
A finish applied to a nonconductive material to lower the electrical resistance of its surface.
The ability of a material to allow electrons to move freely between its atoms.
A material whose outer shell (valence shell) electrons are held in the atom with a weak force and are therefore able to be moved from one atom to another with a small amount of electrical pressure.
A material that is able to transfer heat easily and directly to another material by conduction.
A tube or duct used to enclose a protect electrical wiring.
A solid shape formed by rotating a right triangle about one of the legs which forms the right angle.
A condition in the installation of a propeller on a splined shaft when either the front or rear cone contacts an obstruction that prevents the cone seating properly inside the propeller hub.
A type of clutch used to engage and disengage a component from a drive unit.
A location directly above the antenna of a four-course, low-frequency radio range in which the signals from the antennas cancel and no signal is received.
The function of an automated air traffic control system which alerts radar controllers of existing or pending situations which the program recognizes as requiring immediate attention and/or action.
The resolution of potential conflicts between aircraft that are radar identified and in communication with ATC by ensuring that radar targets do not touch.
To change from a freely flowing liquid into a liquid too viscous, or stiff, to flow.
Oil that has become too viscous, or thick, to flow because of its low temperature or because of contamination.
The angle formed between the plane of rotation of a helicopter rotor blade when it is producing lift, and a line perpendicular to the rotor shaft.
To steer or control the direction of a ship or aircraft.
The rigid rod that connects the pistons in a reciprocating engine to the throws of the crankshaft.
The law of conservation of energy that energy can neither be created nor destroyed, but it can be changed from one form into another.
A low-frequency, long-distance navigational aid used principally for transoceanic navigation.
The portion of the cockpit of an aircraft in which many of the operating controls are located.
A number or symbol that has a fixed value for a given condition.
The mode of pressurization in which the cabin pressure is maintained a constant amount higher than the outside air pressure.
A copper-nickel alloy used as the negative lead of a thermocouple for measuring cylinder head temperature in a reciprocating engine.

A method of restoring the charge to a storage battery by connecting it across a source of direct current that can be maintained at a constant value by varying the voltage as the state of charge progresses.
A pump that moves a constant volume of fluid with each rotation.
A form of helical coil spring wound in such a way that it always produces a constant restorative force, regardless of the amount it is displaced.
A weather chart showing a constant-pressure surface.
The cycle of energy transformation used by a gas turbine engine (See Brayton cycle).
A component used with either aircraft gas turbine or reciprocating engines to drive AC generators.
A type of propeller used on an airplane to hold the engine at a constant RPM as the air load on the propeller changes.
A method of charging aircraft batteries in which a constant voltage is placed across the battery while it is being charged.
A regulated power supply that maintains a constant output voltage as the electrical load varies.
The cycle of energy transformation used by a reciprocating engine.
A type of igniter used in a gas turbine engine ignition system.
The term used between a person hand-propping an aircraft engine and the person in the cockpit.

An approach in which an aircraft on an IFR flight plan, having an air traffic control authorization, operating clear of clouds with at least one mile flight visibility and a reasonable expectation of continuing to the destination airport in those conditions, may deviate from the instrument approach procedure and proceed to the destination airport by visual reference to the surface.
A type of adhesive that is spread on two surfaces to be joined and allowed to dry and bond together.
Flight in which the altitude of the aircraft is maintained and its navigation is done by visual reference to the horizon and to the ground over which the aircraft is flying.
A heavy-duty, remotely operated switch used to control electrical circuits carrying large amounts of current.
A runway is considered contaminated whenever standing water, ice, snow, slush, frost in any form, heavy rubber, or other substances are present.
The polluting of a substance by an impurity.
The 48 adjoining states and the District of Columbia. These states are also called the contiguous United States.

The airspace of the 48 contiguous states, the District of Columbia, and Alaska, excluding the Alaska peninsula west of Long, 160p 00' 00 W, and above 14,500 feet MSL, but not including: 1. Airspace less than 1,500 feet above the surface of the earth, or, 2. Prohibited and restricted areas other than the restricted areas listed in 14 CFR Part 71.
The 49 states located on the continent of North America and the District of Columbia.
A condition in which something is complete or unbroken.
A simple piece of test equipment used to check an electrical circuit for continuity.

An inspection program that is part of a continuous airworthiness maintenance program approved for certain large airplanes (to which 14 CFR Part 125 is not applicable), turbojet multiengine airplanes, turbopropeller-powered multiengine airplanes, and turbine-powered rotorcraft.
A method of casting metal in which the ingot is continuously cooled and pulled as it is being poured.
A brace made of thin plywood used to reinforce the glue joints of all the upright and diagonal braces used in a wooden wing rib.
A method of magnetic particle inspection in which the part is inspected while the magnetizing current is flowing either through the material or through a coil, or solenoid around the part.
A method of transmitting radio-frequency electro-magnetic energy in the form of long and short spurts that may be considered to be dashes and dots.
A type of secondary ignition system for a gas turbine engine.
The rating of an electrical machine which specifies the amount of electrical load the machine can carry for an indefinite period of time.
A solenoid-type switch designed to be kept energized by current flowing through its coil for an indefinite period of time.
A fire and overheat detection system in which a gas-releasing element and a pressure switch are sealed in a stainless steel tube installed so it surrounds the compartment being protected.
A system of aviation breathing oxygen in which a metered amount of oxygen flows continuously into the mask.
A type of fire detection system which used two conductors, separated by a thermistor material, formed into a continuous loop that surrounds the area being protected.
A line drawing on a constant-pressure chart to show the pattern of points of equal pressure.
A line on a radar scope that shows the areas of equal radar echo intensity.
A map of a geographical area which has lines drawn on it that connect points of equal elevation.
A circuit which displays multiple contours of echo intensity simultaneously on the plan position indicator or range-height indicator scope.
The long visible trail resembling a cloud left behind some airplanes as they fly at high altitude.
Two propellers mounted on concentric shafts and turning in opposite directions.
A mechanism or system used to regulate or guide the operation of a machine or organization.

Airspace designated as Colored Federal Airways, VOR Federal Airways, control areas associated with jet routes outside the continental control area (14 CFR 71.161), additional control areas (14 CFR 71.163), control area extensions (14 CFR 71.165), and area low routes.
A steel cable used to connect the cockpit control to the flight control surfaces of an aircraft.
An electrical circuit used to control other circuits in an electrical device or system.
The control in the cockpit of an airplane on which the control wheel is mounted.
A component in a flight management computer system that contains a cathode-ray tube and a keyboard with alphanumeric keys and mode-select and line-select keys.
The grid in an electron tube to which the signal to be amplified is applied.
The arm on a control surface to which the control cable or push-pull rod attaches to move the surface.
A device used to lock the flight-control surfaces of an aircraft in their neutral position when the aircraft is on the ground.
The panel in an aircraft cockpit that contains the flight and engine instruments and switches for the operation of the aircraft systems.
A rigid rod normally made of aluminum alloy tubing used to actuate flight control from the cockpit.
A rod used to control the amount of activity in a nuclear reactor.

An airspace area of defined horizontal and vertical dimensions for which a controller or group of controllers has air traffic control responsibility, normally within an air route traffic control center or an approach control facility.
A radar beacon slash representing the actual position of the associated aircraft.
A device in a hydraulically boosted aircraft control system that cushions the movement of a control at the end of its travel.
A vertical stick in the cockpit of an airplane with which the pilot operates the ailerons and elevators.
Aerodynamic surfaces which can be moved from the cockpit of an airplane to cause the airplane to rotate about its three axes.
A wheel-like control in an airplane cockpit used by the pilot to move the ailerons and elevators.
The movable column on which an airplane control wheel is mounted.
Controlled airspace which extends upward from the surface and terminates at the base of the continental control area.
The characteristic of an aircraft that allows it to change its flight attitude in response to the pilot's movement of the cockpit controls.
A propeller whose blade pitch angle can be changed in flight.

Airspace designated as a continental control area, control area, control zone, terminal control area, transition area, or positive control area within which some or all aircraft may be subject to air traffic control.
The flow control process in which aircraft are held on the ground at the departure airport when delays are projected to occur in either the enroute system or the terminal of intended landing.
A design of compressor blade used in some of the modern axial-flow gas turbine engines.
A reverse-blocking triode thyristor that can be triggered into conduction in only one direction.
The original estimated time of arrival adjusted by the air traffic control system command center ground delay factor.
A method of heat transfer within a fluid by means of vertical currents.
Predominantly vertical movement of the atmosphere that results in mixing the atmospheric properties.
The vertical movement of molecules of a fluid in a container that is being heated.
The lowest level at which condensation will occur as a result of convection due to surface heating.

The state of an unsaturated layer of air whose lapse rates of temperature and moisture are such that, when the air is lifted adiabatically until the layer becomes saturated, spontaneous convection will occur.
A weather advisory concerning convective weather significant to the safety of all aircraft.
An imaginary flow of electricity said to go from the positive terminal of an electrical source to its negative terminal.
The type of airplane landing gear with the main wheels ahead of the center of gravity and a small wheel supporting the tail when the airplane is on the ground.
To draw closer together and eventually to meet.
The condition which exists when the distribution of winds within a given area is such that there is a net horizontal inflow of air into the area.
A duct, or passage, whose cross-sectional area decreases in the direction of fluid flow.
A duct that has a decreasing cross section in the direction of flow (convergent) until a minimum area is reached.
An exhaust duct used on the engine of a supersonic aircraft.
A form of duct, or passage, used for the inlet air to supersonic airplane engines.
A chemical solution used to form an airtight oxide or phosphate film on the surface of aluminum or magnesium parts.
A type of heavier-than-air aircraft able to rise and descend vertically.
A rotating electrical machine that changes, or converts, alternating current into direct current.
a surface that is curved outward with its outer edges lower than the center.
A fluid used to remove heat from a component or a system.
Thin ribs that extend outward from a surface to carry heat from the surface into the air flowing through the fins.
Time corrected for the seasonal variations in the earth's rotation about the sun.
The intersection of lines of reference, usually expressed in degrees/minutes/seconds of latitude and longitude, used to determine a position or location.
The fix in relation to the facilities which will hand off, transfer control of an aircraft, or coordinate flight progress data.
Hard, natural resins that come from trees grown in the East Indies, South America, and Africa .
A person who assists the pilot in flying an aircraft, but is not in command of the aircraft.
A small, wood-cutting handsaw that uses a replaceable blade only about 1/8 inch wide.
A ductile, malleable, reddish-brown, metallic chemical element.
A method of brazing in which copper is used as the filler metal.
A copper gasket used to form a leakproof seal between components that operate at a high temperature.
Energy loss caused by heat produced when current flows through the windings of an electric motor.
A thermocouple combination used to measure temperatures up to about 300o C.
A rectifier that allows electrons to pass in one direction, but opposes their flow in the opposite direction.
A high-strength electrical conductor made by plating a steel wire with copper.
The gas generator portion of a gas turbine engine.
The tachometer used to measure the speed of the high-pressure compressor (N2) of a two-spool gas turbine engine.
The change in rotor blade velocity to compensate for a change in the distance between the center of mass of the rotor blade and the axis of rotation of the blade as the blades flap in flight.
A force which acts on a particle while it is moving along a path in a plane that is being rotated.
The touch, resilient, lightweight bark of the cork oak tree.
A large shop tool used to make straight bends across a sheet of metal.
A discharge of electricity that appears as a bluish-purple glow on the surface of a conductor when the voltage on the conductor exceeds a certain critical value.
A prismatically colored circle or arc of a circle with the sun or moon at its center.
Power loss caused by ionization of the gases surrounding the conductor.
Another name for saint Elmo's fire.
Indicated altitude shown on an aircraft altimeter corrected for nonstandard temperature of the air.
A component in the reciprocating engine controls for a helicopter that automatically increases and decreases the amount of throttle opening as the collective pitch control is raised or lowered.
An electrolytic action which takes place inside a metal or on its surface.
A primer which prevents, or at least slows, the formation of corrosion in the metal it covers.
A material used to stop or slow the action of corrosion.
A special oil that has little tendency to run off of a surface on which it is sprayed.
Steel alloyed with nickel and chromium, to increase its resistance to corrosion or rust.
To form ridges or waves in a piece of material to increase its rigidity.
A small strip of corrugated steel ground on one edge to form a series of sharp points.
Sheets of metal that have been made more rigid by forming a series of parallel ridges or waves in their surfaces.
The trigonometric function which is the ratio of the length of the hypotenuse of a right triangle to the length of the side opposite an acute angle.
The trigonometric function which is the ratio of the length of the side adjacent to an acute angle in a right triangle to the length of the hypotenuse.
A stream of electrons and hydrogen atom nuclei that comes from outer space, penetrates the earth's atmosphere, and strikes the earth from all directions.
The trigonometric function which is the ratio of the length of the side adjacent to an acute angle in a right triangle to the length of the side opposite the angle.
A split metal pin used to safety a castellated or slotted nut to a bolt.
A fabric tube made of loosely woven cotton thread.
A unit of electrical charge equal to 6.28 billion billion (6.28 x 1018 or 6,280,000,000,000,000,000) electrons.
A special cutting tool used to enlarge the diameter of a hole for a certain depth.
A voltage produced in the armature of an electric motor as the armature windings cut across the fixed magnetic field .
Propellers on wing-mounted engines that turn in opposite directions.
A metal-cutting tool used to chamfer (bevel) the edges of a hole so the head of a countersunk rivet will be flush, or even, with the surface of the metal.
To prepare a rivet hole for a flush rivet by beveling the edges of the holes with a cutter of the correct angle.
A rivet whose cone-shaped head fits into a beveled hole in the metal.
A concentrated mass used to balance a weight or a load.
A heavy weight fastened to one of the throws of a crankshaft to balance the assembly of the crankshaft, connecting rods, and pistons.
An instrument approach performed by the aircraft autopilot which is receiving position information and/or steering commands from on-board navigation equipment.
The intended direction of flight, measured in the horizontal plane in degrees clockwise from north.
An indicator used with VOR, LORAN, or GPS navigation systems to indicate the direction and relative amount of deviation from the desired course.
A type of linkage between atoms in a chemical compound in which an electron is shared by two atoms.
The registered trade name for a small surface-type bimetallic thermometer used to calibrate the temperature of an iron used to heat-shrink polyester fabrics.
Movable flaps located at the exit of the cowling that houses an air-cooled aircraft engine.
The removable cover which encloses an aircraft engine.
The portion of a computer that contains the main storage, the arithmetic-logic-unit, or ALU, and special register groups.
Aircraft flight in which the nose of the aircraft is pointed into the wind, while the flight path over the ground is partially across the wind.
A partial separation in a piece of material caused by vibration, overloading, or internal stresses.
A small hole drilled in the end of a crack to prevent the crack continuing.
A hydrocarbon fuel (gasoline) manufactured by heating crude petroleum products under pressure, usually in the presence of a catalyst.
A supporting fixture used to hold an aircraft structure while it is being repaired or stored.
The housing which encloses the crankshaft, camshaft, and many of the accessory drive gears of a reciprocating engine.
The portion of a crankshaft to which the connecting rod is attached.
The central component of a reciprocating engine, a high-strength, alloy steel shaft with hardened and polished bearing surfaces that ride in bearings in the crankcase.
The amount of a crankshaft is bent.
A recess, or dip, in the puddle of molten metal in the flame of a gas welding torch or in the arc used for electric welding.
A form of heat damage that occurs in a transparent thermoplastic material.
A condition of permanent elongation of a turbine blade.
A flat board with low wheels on it.
A form of paper tape which is crinkled, with one side coated with a pressure-sensitive adhesive.
The registered trade name for an adjustable open-end wrench.
A person aboard an aircraft for the purpose of operating the aircraft in flight.
Shortening a piece of sheet metal by forming small pleats or corrugations in its surface.
A special tool used to install crimp-on terminals on the ends of electrical wires.
Terminals which are attached to the end of an electrical wire for the purpose of connecting the wire to a terminal strip or component, or for splicing the wires.
A type of finish formed by a special paint in which the surface dries in a series of wrinkles.
The maximum altitude under standard atmospheric conditions at which an aircraft reciprocating engine can deliver its rated horsepower.
The highest angle of attack at which air passes over an airfoil in a smooth flow.
The lowest compression ratio of a compressing-ignition engine that allows a specific fuel to be ignited by compression ignition.
The coupling between the windings of a transformer that transfer the maximum amount of energy.
The engine of a multi-engine airplane which would cause the most difficulty in maintaining control if it failed in a critical condition of flight, such as a takeoff.
The flight Mach number at which there is the first indication of air flowing over any part of the structure at a speed of Mach one, the local speed of sound.
The part in an assembly or component whose failure would prevent the assembly or component functioning as it should.
The highest pressure of the fuel-air mixture inside the cylinder of a reciprocating engine that allows the mixture to burn evenly, rather than explode, or detonate.
A range of engine RPM in which the natural vibratory frequency of the engine-propeller combination is excited.
An area in an aircraft structure that either has been exposed to an excess of stress or would cause the maximum amount of strength loss if it were damaged.
The temperature inside the cylinder of a reciprocating engine that will cause the fuel to explode, rather than burn evenly when it is ignited.
The temperature at which the internal structure of a metal takes on a crystalline form.
Critical Temperature Of A Metal (Heat Treatment)
An abrasive cloth that has a fine, dark red iron oxide bonded to its surface.
Instructions from ATC for an aircraft operating under instrument flight rules to cross a specified fix at a specified altitude.
A double coat of aircraft finishing material in which the second coat is sprayed over the first coat at right angles to it, before the solvents in the first coat have evaporated from it.
An auxiliary member of a primary aircraft structure.
An undesirable condition, also known as cross modulation, in which the output from one system or part of a system is fed over into another system.
An air ducting system used in a multi-engine turbojet airplane in which compressor bleed air from one engine can be directed to another engine where it can be used to operate its air starter.
Flying from one airport to another over a distance that is long enough to require the use of some sort of navigation.
A form of wood saw having short, sharp, knife-like teeth.
An arrangement of the fuel system plumbing of a multiengine aircraft that allows any of the engines to operate from any of its fuel tanks.
A valve in a fuel system that allows any engine of a multiengine aircraft to draw fuel from any fuel tank.
A method of cutting metal with a file in which the file is moved endwise over the work.
A malfunction in which high voltage in the distributor jumps between the terminals and causes the wrong spark plug to fire.
An automatic flow-control valve installed between the gear-up and gear-down lines of the landing germ of some large airplanes.
A method of using angled, parallel lines to show that a section of a drawing has been cut away.
A condition in which helicopter rotor blades track on the ground and in a hover, but one blade flies higher than the other in flight.
A small tube that connects the burner cans in a multiple-can combustor.
An auxiliary view of an aircraft drawing used to show the cross-sectional shape or the construction of a part of a structure or component.
A wind blowing across the flight path of an aircraft.
The wind component, measured in knots, at 90o to the longitudinal axis of a runway.
A landing made in a direction across, or nearly perpendicular to, the direction from which the wind is blowing.
A type of landing gear installed on some tail wheel airplanes to make crosswind landings easier for the pilot.
A very short open-end or box-end wrench with a square drive hole that allows it to be mounted on an extension which may be turned by a flex, or breakover, handle.
A display tube used in oscilloscopes, digital computers, and television receivers.
A container made of a material that can be heated to a very high temperature.
A high grade of steel produced by melting scraps of iron and steel in a graphite crucible and adding the correct amounts of alloying elements and fluxes.
Petroleum in the condition it is when taken from the ground.
A flight condition that allows and aircraft to operate smoothly and efficiently for a long period of time.
When used in an ATC clearance, the term cruise means that the pilot may conduct flight at any altitude from the minimum IFR altitude up to and including the altitude specified in the clearance.
A climb technique employed by aircraft usually at a constant power setting, resulting in an increase of altitude as the aircraft weight decreases.
An altitude or flight level maintained during enroute level flight.
A level maintained during a significant portion of a flight.
A form of gasket made of thin copper, formed around a core of asbestos.
A form of gyroscope which uses a spherical rotor made of niobium.
A liquid which boils at temperatures of less than about 110o K ) - 163o C) at normal atmospheric pressures.
The branch of science or engineering that deals with technical operations involving very low temperatures; temperatures near zero.
A piece of quartz or Rochelle salt which has piezoelectric characteristics.
A form of electronic check valve.
Earphones in which alternating current distorts a piezoelectric crystal.
An electronic filter which opposes a certain band of frequencies, but allows all frequencies on either side of the band to pass.
A microphone used for aircraft radio transmissions in which sound pressure waves distort a piece of piezoelectric crystal.
An electronic oscillator which produces alternating current from direct current.
A device inside a piece of sensitive electronic equipment that holds the temperature of a frequency-controlling crystal constant.
A device that uses a piezoelectric crystal to change mechanical pressure or vibrations into electrical signals.
An electronic oscillator which produces alternating current from direct current.
A type of molecular structure in which the molecules of a material are arranged in a definite pattern throughout the material.
A component used with either aircraft gas turbine or reciprocating engines to drive AC generators.
A frequency designated for the purpose of carrying out airport advisory practices while operating to or from an uncontrolled airport.
The force acting about the longitudinal axis of a propeller blade which tries to rotate the blade to a low-pitch angle. See CTM.
The force moment, acting about the longitudinal axis of a propeller blade, which tries to rotate the blade toward a low-pitch angle.
A solid geometric figure which has six square sides.
The third power of the number. It is the value obtained when the number is multiplied by itself two times.
The inverse of the cube of a number.
A thin, sheet metal, airfoil-shaped covering over the shank of a propeller blade.
Specifically shaped pieces of sheet metal attached to the leading edge of the wing to increase the camber, or curvature, of the airfoil to improve the slow-flight characteristics of the wing.
A term used to describe all convective clouds which exhibit vertical development.
Heavy, dense cumuliform clouds with considerable vertical development in the form of massive towers.
A cumulonimbus cloud having protuberance-like pouches, or udders, handing on their underside.
A cloud in the form of individual detached, dense, and well-defined domes or towers.
The registered trade name for a type of edge filter used in aircraft engines and hydraulic systems.
The end of a threaded fastener made in the form of an open cup.
A form of lock washer made of spring steel formed into the shape of a cup.
A step in the manufacture of parts made from plastic resins.
The amount of time needed for a plastic resin to change from a liquid into a solid.
A slivery, metallic, synthetic, radioactive chemical element. Curium's symbol is Cm, and its atomic number is 96.
A term used to describe the flow of electricity.
An electronic amplifier in which the current in its output circuit is greater than the current in its input circuit.
The ratio found by dividing the total amount of current flowing through a conductor, in amperes, by the cross-sectional area of the conductor, in square inches.
The form of electricity which makes use of the heat and/or the magnetic field produced when electrons flow in a conductor.
The flight plan including changes, if any, brought about by subsequent clearances.
A device in the control system of a DC generator which reduces the output voltage or removes the generator from the electrical system any time it produces more than its rated current.
A device or circuit in the output of an electrical power source that maintains a constant output current.
An electrical transformer used for measuring or control purposes.
A center-fed radio transmitting antenna that is half a wavelength long.
A resistor used to limit the maximum amount of current allowed to flow in a circuit.
A World War I training airplane powered by a Curtiss OX-5 engine.
A type of coupling used to join a series of axial-flow compressor disks or axial turbine wheels to each other.
Air bled from one of the stages of the engine compressor and used for some function other than the operation of the engine.
Threads that have been formed on a rod by removing part of the metal with a cutting tool.
A drawing which shows the inside construction or contents of an object, as well as the outside of the object.
The point in which a system ceases to operate because a defined cutoff condition has been reached.
A switch inside a piece of electrical equipment that opens the circuit when a certain operating condition is reached.
A fluid, often an emulsion of oil and water, poured over a metal while it is being drilled or turned on a lathe.
A line on a mechanical drawing used to indicate the location from which an auxiliary view is made.
The speed of the relative motion between a cutting tool and the work being cut.
An oxy-gas torch which has a preheating flame to get the metal red-hot before it Is cut.
An approach authorized for a radar-controlled aircraft on an IFR flight plan, but operating in VFR conditions.
A method of transmitting radio-frequency electro-magnetic energy in the form of long and short spurts that may be considered to be dashes and dots.
Any of the various salts of hydrogen cyanide which contain a CN (carbon and nitrogen) group.
A type of case hardening of steel done by heating the metal in a bath of molten cyanide salts.
The science of systems and controls as they pertain to the relationship between living beings and automatic machines.
A complete series of events or operations that recur regularly.
A measure of frequency of a recurring event.
The control in a helicopter that allows the pilot to change the pitch of the rotor blades individually, at a specific point in their rotation.
Operating a device or a system through its entire range of actuation several times.
Any development or strengthening of cyclonic circulation in the atmosphere.
An area of low atmospheric pressure which has a closed circulation.
An accelerator in which positively charged particles such as protons and deuterons are accelerated by a constant-frequency alternating electric field synchronized with their movement.
A solid form whose ends are circular and whose sides are parallel.
The component in a reciprocating engine which houses the piston and valves.
Thin sheet metal covers fastened around the fins on the cylinders of an air-cooled engine.
The high-strength steel tube in which the piston moves up and down in a reciprocating engine.
The inside diameter of the cylinder barrel.
A heavy flange machined around the base of an air-cooled cylinder barrel, slightly below the bottom cooling fin.
The part of a reciprocating engine cylinder that forms the combustion chamber.
The temperature of the cylinder head of an air-cooled reciprocating engine.
The portion of the crankcase of a reciprocating engine to which the cylinders bolt.
The portion of the cylinder of an aircraft engine that protrudes into the crankcase.
The registered trade name for polyester fibers manufactured by the E. I. DuPont de Nemours & Company.
A multibladed circular saw having two blades mounted on an arbor with a chipper between them.
A hand plane with a narrow blade.
The gas law which states that there will always be the same number of molecules of gas in a container when the gas is held at a uniform pressure and temperature.
To decrease the amplitude of an oscillating or reciprocating motion.
Oscillations whose amplitude decreases with time.
A butterfly-type valve in an air duct.
A device used to dampen vibrations or oscillations or to ring a vibrating body to a stop with a minimum of oscillations.
An automatic valve that closes off the air supply to a combustion heater if a fire or over-temperature condition occurs.
An airspace of defined dimensions within which activities dangerous to the flight of aircraft may exist at specified times.
A form of standard cell used for measuring voltage by comparison.
The current which flows in a photoelectric device, such as a photodiode or phototransistor, when no light is falling on the light-sensitive junction.
A type of transistor amplifier in which two bipolar transistors are connected in such a way that the emitter of the input transistor is connected directly to the base of the output transistor.
One of the most widely used types of direct-current measuring instruments.
A pneumatic or hydraulic dampener used to cushion or slow down mechanical movements.
A term that refers to all the facts available about a situation or project.
The body of information available on any particular subject.
A wire or group of wires used to move data within a computer system.
Performance specification of a gas turbine engine that were determined in the manufacturer's test cell when the engine was calibrated.
A reference from which measurements are made.
An imaginary vertical reference plane or line chosen by the aircraft manufacturer from which all arms used for weight and balance computation are measured.
A relatively thick, narrow-chord wing used on some airplanes.
The electrical generation device that has replaced the generator on practically all modern automobiles and light airplanes.
An electronic amplifier which can amplify direct-current signals and alternating current signals having a very low frequency.
Electricity in which the electrons flow in the same direction all of the time.
An electrical machine that converts mechanical energy into DC electricity.
An electric motor that operates on direct current.
The product of current and voltage.
A classification of maintenance inspections or checks used in airline operation.
A term used in technology to mean the absence of motion.
A pointed device mounted in the tailstock of a lathe.
An engine which has been shut down in flight and is no longer operating.
A method of navigating an aircraft in which the direction and speed of movement of the aircraft are determined by graphically computing the effect of the wind on the aircraft.
A room or chamber used to test acoustic devices.
A short circuit in an electrical device in which there is an ab solute minimum of resistance across the source of electrical energy.
The condition of a free-swinging device when it comes to rest without overshooting its at-rest position.
The position of the piston in a reciprocating engine in which the wrist pin, the crank pin, and the center of the crankshaft are all in a straight line.

to separate into basic components, or elements.

A colored substance used to add a more or less permanent color to another object.
A method of nondestructive inspection used to detect surface defects in metal or plastic parts.
A special type of mount for an aircraft engine in which straight lines that pass through the engine mount bolts intersect at the center of gravity of the engine and propeller assembly.
Continuous review, evaluation, and change to meet demands.
The balance of a rotating object, such as a wheel or propeller spinner.

A type of microphone in which sound pressure vibrates a cone on which is mounted a coil of wire.
The pressure a moving fluid would have if it were stopped.
Those restrictions imposed by the local facility on an as needed basis to manage unpredictable fluctuations in traffic demands.
The stability that causes an aircraft to return to a condition of straight and level flight after it has been disturbed from this condition.
An explosive made by mixing nitroglycerine with a material such as sawdust, flour, or starch, and some type of oxygen-supplying salt.
An electrical measuring instrument that measures current and voltage at the same time and displays the results as electrical power.
A device used to measure the amount of torque being produced by a rotating machine.
An electrical machine that converts low-voltage DC into high-voltage DC.
A unit of force in the centimeter-gram-second system of units.
A soft, silvery, rare-earth metallic chemical element. Dysprosium's symbol is Dy, its atomic number is 66, and its atomic weight is 162.50.
A patented fastener used to secure aircraft cowling and inspection plates.

A colored multifunction display flight instrument that shows pitch and roll attitude indications along with flight director commands, localizer and glide slope indications, selected airspeed, ground speed, automatic flight control system and autothrottle modes, and decision height.
Long-range radar that scans the sky in all directions to detect enemy aircraft and/or missiles.
A device made of rubber or some type of soft plastic worn in the ear canal to prevent loud noises damaging the delicate mechanism in the ear.
Earth is the term used in the United Kingdom for the electrical reference called ground in the United States.
An electrical connection to a metal cold-water pipe or metal rod driven into the ground.
A form of navigation instrument which gets its directional reference from lines of magnetic flux of the earth cutting across the windings of a flux valve mounted in the aircraft.
The magnetic lines of flux that leave the north magnetic pole and travel over the surface of the earth and re-enter it at the south magnetic pole.
An automated radar and radar beacon tracking system.
The registered trade name for a type of screw extractor.
An electronic instrument system that monitors the functions of the entire aircraft and displays the information on two color multifunction displays in the aircraft cockpit.
Two or more circular objects turning in the same plane, but having different centers.

A circular cam mounted on a shaft, with its center different from the center of the shaft.
Tactics used in military aircraft to reduce the effectiveness of the countermeasures used by the enemy against electronic countermeasures.
An image formed on a radarscope by energy reflected or scattered from a target.
Tactics used in military aircraft to evade or deceive enemy radar.
The system in a carburetor or fuel injection system that meters additional fuel to the engine when the throttle is wide open.

A local irregularity of wind in a larger scale wind flow.

Decreasing the amplitude of oscillations by the interaction of magnetic fields.

Wood that has been sawed from the tree in such a way that the edges of its grain are visible in the wide part of the plank.

A form of jet pump used to pick up one liquid and mix it with another.
An electronic fuel control for a gas turbine engine.
The actual distance a propeller moves through the air in one revolution.
The value of sine wave alternating current needed to produce the same amount of heat as this value of direct current.
A measure of the effectiveness of a system or device.
A complete electronic flight instrumentation system that includes the EICAS (engine indicating and crew alerting system) and the ECAM (electronic centralized monitoring) system. See EICAS and ECAM.
The position of the rotating magnet in a magneto when the breaker points are timed open.
The temperature of the gases as they leave the cylinder of a reciprocating engine or the turbine of a gas turbine engine.

A thermocouple-type instrument that shows the temperature of the gas leaving the exhaust valve of a reciprocating engine or in the tail cone of a turbine engine.
An electronic flight instrument that displays navigation information on a multicolor display.
An electronic instrument system for modern turbine-powered aircraft that senses engine parameters and displays them on one of two multicolor display units on the instrument panel.

A synthetic, radioactive chemical element produced by neutron bombardment of uranium in cyclotrons.
A type of seat installed in a military aircraft that may be shot out of the aircraft with a powder charge in the event of an inflight emergency.
A form of jet pump used to pick up a liquid and move it to another location.
The maximum amount of tensile load, in pounds per square inch, material is able to withstand without being permanently deformed.
The registered trade name of a special type of self-locking nut.
The ability of a material to be elongated, or stretched, by pulling on it, and to return to its original size and configuration after the force causing the elongation is removed.
A material, such as synthetic rubber, that can be stretched at room temperature to at least twice its original length.
A type of bearing used for oscillating loads where complete rotation is not needed.
An ionized layer of the atmosphere existing at an altitude of between 60 and 75 miles (100 to 120 kilometers) above the earth .
A type of fitting used to join two pieces of tubing at an angle of 90o.
The registered trade name for a special type of connector used to connect a high-output battery to an aircraft electrical system.
A dielectric insulating material that is permanently polarized.
An acoustic transducer, a device that changes sound pressure into an electrical signal.
A series-wound, alternating-current motor used to drive a chuck which holds a twist drill.
A type of starter for large aircraft reciprocating engines.
The process of connecting the structural parts of an aircraft together with conductors to keep them all at the same electrical potential.
A distribution point in an electrical system to which the battery and generator are connected, and from which the electrical loads receive their power.
Electrical energy stored on the surface of an object.
A line drawing using schematic symbols to show the relationship of all the components in an electrical system.
Energy possessed by a material or device because of an unequal distribution of electrons.
A machine that converts mechanical energy into electrical energy.
A material that offers a large amount of opposition to the low of electrons.
The electrical force caused by a deficiency of electrons in one location and an excess of electrons in another.
A method of welding thin sheets of metal by clamping them tightly together and passing electric current through them.
A housing made of a conductive material such as copper or aluminum that encloses an electrical circuit.
An unwanted connection that provides a low-resistance path across an electrical circuit.
An alloy of low-carbon steel that contains up to 5% silicon.
A device used to measure the amount of physical strain (deformation caused by a stress) in a piece of material.
The maximum amount of electrical pressure (voltage) that can be placed across an insulator before it breaks down and allows electrons to flow through it.
Standardized graphic symbols that have been agreed upon as representing various components in electrical schematic diagrams.
A specific position of the rotor inside the stator of a synchro 9a remotely controlled position indicating system).

A force caused by electrons moving from one atom to another.
A device that changes either variations in sound pressure into variations of electrical pressure (voltage), or variations in voltage into variations of sound pressure.
A list of metals arranged according to their electrode potential.
The aspects of chemistry that deal with electron potentials within the different chemical elements.
A conductor, or part of an electrical component through which electrons flow to or from an external circuit.
A voltage existing within an alloy of metals or in any type of electrochemical cell.
The aspect of electricity that deals with electrons in motion.
The decreasing amplitude of pointer oscillation of an electrical meter caused by the generation of a voltage in the moving coil as it oscillates back and forth in the field of a permanent magnet.
The process of electrolytically depositing a layer of zinc on sheets of steel.
The emission of light caused by the application of a strong electrical field to certain materials.
The process in which the chemical composition of a material is changed by passing electrical current through it.
A chemical solution, either a liquid or a gas, that conducts electrical current by releasing ions (unbalanced atoms) that unite with oppositely charged ions on the electrodes.
A capacitor that uses metal foil for the electrodes and an extremely thin film of metallic oxide, a nonconductor, as the dielectric.
The reduction of certain chemical compounds into their composite elements by passing electricity through them.
A magnet produced by electrical current flowing through a coil of wire.
The radiation of electromagnetic energy for communications.
The transfer of electrical energy from one conductor to another that is not electrically connected.
Interference of radio reception by the radiation of electromagnetic energy from a piece of electronic equipment, or from conductors carrying high-frequency alternating current.
One method by which energy is transmitted from one location to another.
A device that interrupts a flow of direct current and changes it into pulsating DC.
Vibrations of electric and magnetic fields that move at the speed of light.
The magnetic field surrounding a current-carrying conductor.
A type of instrument that uses the resonant frequency of a vibrating metal reed to measure the frequency of alternating current.
The force that causes electrons to move from one atom to another within an electrical circuit.
The negatively charged part of an atom of which all matter is made.
A thin stream of electrons all moving in he same direction under the influence of electrical or magnetic fields.
The movement of electrons through a circuit from the negative terminal of the power source to its positive terminal.
The relatively slow movement of individual electrons through a conductor.
The rotation of an electron about its own axis.
The length of time required for an electron to travel between two points in an electronic device.
The correct term for an electronic component which normally goes by the name of a vacuum tube or valve.
The unit of energy that is acquired by an electron when it passes through a potential difference of one volt in a vacuum .
A method of welding metal by head produced when a high speed stream of electrons strikes metal.
Relating to the application of the flow of free electrons through semiconductor devices and across a vacuum.
The discharge of electrons from a material.
An electronic oscillator whose frequency changes if refrigerant gas is picked up in its sensor tube.
An electronic circuit that converts DC electricity into AC electricity.
A special type of electronic instrument used to measure voltage.
The study and use of the movement of free electrons.
Bonding of the atoms within a crystal by the sharing of valence electrons.

The production of a smooth finish on a piece of metal by submerging it in a suitable electrolyte and making it the anode in an electrolytic process.
An electrical charge that can exist on the plates of a capacitor or on an insulated object.

Energy stored by an electric stress in the dielectric of a capacitor when two opposing electrical charges act across the dielectric.
The space between two bodies that have opposite electrical charges.
The aspect of electricity that deals with electrical charges caused by electrons that are stationary, not moving.
The horizontal, movable control surface in the tail section, or empennage, of an airplane .
A spring in the elevator control system that produces a mechanical force that tries to lower the elevator, and thus the nose of the airplane.
A figure formed when a plane cuts across the axis of a cylinder at an angle other than a right angle.

The force that causes electrons to move from one atom to another within an electrical circuit.
Interference of radio reception by the radiation of electromagnetic energy from a piece of electronic equipment, or from conductors carrying high-frequency alternating current.

The tail section of an airplane.
The weight of the airframe, engines, and all items of operating equipment that have fixed locations and are permanently installed in the aircraft.
The center of gravity of an aircraft when it contains only the items specified in aircraft empty weight.
The distance between the allowable forward and aft empty-weight CG limits.
A function of the NAS Stage A enroute computer.
A suspension of small globules of one material in another, when the two materials will not mix.
A chemical cleaner used to loosen dirt, grease, oxides, and carbon deposits from the surface of an aircraft.
A type of finishing material that flows out to form a smooth surface.
To completely cover, or encase, something.

The length of time and aircraft can remain in the air.

A single panel-mounted instrument case that contains three engine instruments.

To make a fuel-air mixture richer.

An automated radar and radar beacon tracking system.
Descent from enroute cruising altitude which takes place along the route of flight.

Aeronautical charts for enroute instrument navigation (IFR) in the low-altitude stratum.

A layer of semiconductor material whose crystalline orientation is the same as that of the substrate on which it is grown.

To chemically eat away part of a material.
The estimated flying time from departure point to destination (lift-off to touchdown).

A silvery-white, soft, malleable, rare-earth chemical element.
An alloy or solution whose composition gives it the lowest possible melting point.

A number written above and to the right of a mathematical expression, called the base.
To move something to the limit of its travel.

(1) With respect to aircraft other than helicopters, and operation over water at a horizontal distance of more than 50 nautical miles from the nearest shoreline; and (2) With respect to helicopters, an operation over water at a horizontal distance of more than 50 nautical miles from the nearest shoreline and more than 50 nautical miles from an offshore heliport structure..
Thin lines on an aircraft drawing that extend out from an object to show the location from which dimensions are taken.

Any cyclone that is not a tropical cyclone.

The division within the Department of Transportation of the United States government that has the responsibility of promoting safety in the air, by both regulation and education.
The Major Repair and Alteration form that must be completed when a major repair or major alteration has been completed on an FAA-certified aircraft or engine.

A term that means to build or to manufacture something.

Temperature measured on a scale that uses 32p as the point at which pure water freezes, and 212p as the point at which pure water boils under standard atmospheric pressure.

The division within the Department of Transportation of the United States government that has the responsibility of promoting safety in the air, by both regulation and education.

A governmental board whose responsibility is the regulation of all interstate electrical communications and all foreign electrical communications that originate in the United States.
