A space across which electrical lines of force exist.
Cleaning the compressor blades, casings, and inlet guide vanes of a turbojet engine by spraying them with an emulsion-type cleaner, followed by a rinse with distilled or demineralized water.
A coil of insulated wire wound around a laminated steel pole shoe in an electrical motor or generator.

A high-impedance semiconductor device in which the flow of load current between the source and drain is controlled by variations in voltage on the gate, rather than current, as is done with a bipolar transistor.
Direct current supplied to the field coils of a generator to produce the magnetic field in which the armature rotates.
The steel housing of a generator in which the field coils are mounted.
Maintenance performed on an aircraft when it is away from its regular maintenance base or out of the maintenance dock.
An electrical instrument used to measure the strength of the electromagnetic field radiated from a radio transmitting antenna.
A measure of altitude used by aircraft flying above 18,000 feet.
The heater in an electron tube.
A hand-held cutting tool used to remove a small amount of metal by pushing the tool across the metal surface.
A preplanned delay at points along thee route of a flight which requires special flight plan filing and handling techniques.
A component in a system that traps and holds contaminants carried in the fluid flowing through the system.
A thread-, or filament-like corrosion which forms on aluminum skins beneath a dense paint film.
Threads woven across the width of a piece of fabric, from one selvage edge to the other.
A material mixed into a plastic resin to give body to the resin.
A cylindrical tube extending from a fluid reservoir to a location that is convenient to fill the reservoir.
A plug of sheet metal installed in a flush-skin repair to bring the surface of the repair even with the skin being repaired.
Long pieces of wire that are melted into a weld to provide additional material to strengthen the weld.
A valve in an oxygen system through which oxygen from the storage bottles is put into the system.
A fairing used to give shape, but not strength, to an object.
An increase in the central pressure of a meteorological pressure system.
A machine screw whose head has a rounded top, straight sides, and a flat bearing surface.
The measure of the ability of a lubricant to maintain a continuous film without breaking down under mechanical pressure.
A tuned electrical circuit that will pass certain frequencies or bands of frequencies while attenuating others.
An electrolytic capacitor connected in parallel with the output of a DC power supply.
An iron-core inductor installed in series with the output of a DC power supply.
A fixed vertical aerodynamic surface used to provide directional stability to an aircraft.
The portion of an aircraft flight just before landing.
A straight-line extension of a localizer, a final approach radial, or a runway center line, all without regard to distance.
The fix from which the final approach (IFR) to an airport is executed and which identifies the beginning of the final approach segment.

The point, applicable only to a nonprecision approach with no depicted FAF (such as an on-airport VOR), where the aircraft is established inbound on final approach course from the procedure turn, and where the final approach descent may be commenced.

The flight path of an aircraft which is inbound to an airport on a final instrument approach course, beginning at the final approach point, and extending to the airport or the point where a circle-to-land maneuver or a missed approach is executed.
The controller providing information and final approach guidance during precision approach radar (PAR) and airport surveillance radar (ASR) approaches utilizing radar equipment.
A high-resolution color display that is equipped with the controller-alert system hardware/software which is used in the precision runway monitor (PRM) system.
The ratio of the length of a streamlined body to its maximum diameter.
A type of spark plug used in aircraft engines that have problems with lead fouling the plugs.
Another term for a box brake .
A type of patch welded over a cluster in a welded truss-type aircraft fuselage.
A course-mesh, small-diameter screen made in the shape of a finger.
A step in machining of a metal part in which the part is turned to its correct dimension and given its final smoothness.
A system in an aircraft that warns the flight crew of the presence of a fire in any of the engines, the cargo area, or the wheel wells.
A device, either hand held or installed in an aircraft, that directs a fire extinguishing agent onto a fire.
A chemical used to extinguish a fire.
The lowest temperature at which the fumes of a volatile liquid will ignite and continue to burn when a small flame is passed above its surface.

With respect to sheet or structural members means the capacity to withstand the heat associated with fire at least as well as aluminum alloy in dimensions appropriate for the purpose for which they are used; and (2) With respect to fluid-carrying lines, fluid system parts, wiring, air ducts, fittings, and powerplant controls, means the capacity to perform the intended functions under the heat and other conditions likely to occur when there is a fire at the place concerned..
A protective covering wrapped around flexible hoses installed in the engine compartment of an aircraft.
A graphic display of he three components that must be present for a fire.
An area in an aircraft designated by the aircraft manufacturer as requiring a fire detection and/or fire extinguishing system.

(1) With respect to materials and parts used to confine fire in a designated fire zone, means the capacity to withstand at least as well as steel in dimensions appropriate for the purpose for which they are used, the heat produced when there is a severe fire of extended duration in that zone, and (2) With respect to other materials and parts, means the capacity to withstand the heat associated with fire at least as well as steel in dimensions appropriate for the purpose for which they are used..
A structure built of noncombustible materials and designed so it cannot be destroyed by fire.
The handle in an aircraft cockpit that is pulled at the first indication of an engine fire.
A structure that is able to resist fire or exposure to high temperature for a specified period of time without being destroyed or structurally damaged.
A bulkhead made of a fireproof material used to separate the engine compartment from the rest of the aircraft.
A valve located on the airframe side of the engine firewall that will completely shut off the flow of fuel, oil, or hydraulic fluid to the engine in the case of an engine compartment fire.
The sequence in which the cylinders of a reciprocating engine fire in a normal cycle of operation.
A type of woodworking chisel having a thin, flat blade.
a computer program stored in read-only memory (ROM).
The leading edge of a spreading downdraft, called a plow wind, in front of an approaching thunderstorm.
A lever in which the fulcrum is located between the force and the weight.
A method of attaching turbine blades into the turbine wheel.
A type of finishing system defect in which small, local areas of the finish do not cure properly.

A type of splice used in a welded steel tubular structure, in which the end of a tube, whose inside diameter is the same as the outside diameter of the tube being spliced, and cut in the shape of a V, or fishmouth, and slipped over the smaller tube and weld.
A method of decreasing the speed of an airplane during its approach for landing.
The breaking apart of the nucleus of an atom by striking the nucleus with a neutron.
An attachment device that is used to connect components to an aircraft structure.
The ampere-hour rating of a battery when current is taken from it at such a rate that will discharge it in five hours.
The ampere-hour rating of a battery when current is taken from it at such a high rate that the battery will be discharged in five minutes.
A geographical position determined by visual references to the surface, by reference to one or more ratio navaids, by celestial plotting, or by other navigational methods.
A process whereby aircraft are evenly distributed over several available arrival fixes.
A fire-extinguishing system installed in an aircraft.
A type of propeller used on aircraft when low cost and simplicity are more important than efficient performance.
An airplane or glider whose wing is rigidly attached to the structure.

A warning device incorporated in certain airborne navigation and flight instruments indicating that instruments are inoperative or otherwise not operating satisfactorily, or that signal strength or quality of the received signal falls below acceptable values.
Not susceptible to combustion to the point of propagating a flame, beyond safe limits, after the ignition source is removed..
A process in which molten metal is deposited on a surface.
Small-diameter metal tubes that connect can-type combustors to carry the ignition flame to all of the combustion chambers.
A condition in the operation of a gas turbine engine in which the fire in the engine unintentionally goes out.
An approach normally conducted by a single-engine military aircraft experiencing loss or anticipated loss of engine power or control.
A liquid that gives off combustible vapors (vapors that are easily ignited).
A ridge that protrudes from a device and is used for attaching something to the device, or for connecting two objects together.
Up-and-down movement of the tip of a helicopter rotor blade.
The highest speed permissible with wing flaps in a prescribed extended position..
A valve in the flap system of an airplane that prevents the flaps being lowered at an airspeed which could cause structural damage.
Controls used on some swept wing airplanes that serve as both ailerons and wing flaps.
A form of hinged check valve that allows fluid to flow through it in one direction only.
The vertical movement of a helicopter rotor blade about its delta, or flapping, hinge.
The hinge with its axis parallel to the rotor plane of rotation.
Auxiliary controls built into the wings of an airplane.
The last flight maneuver made by an airplane in a successful landing.
A cone-shaped expansion on the end of a piece of rigid fluid line tubing.
A safety device that was at one time carried in most airplanes that flew at night.
A type of fitting used on a fluid line that forms its seal without being flared.
The raised line along the surface of a molded part caused by the molten material flowing into the space formed by the slightly rounded edges of the two halves of the mold.
The deposit of an extremely thin coating of metal on a surface.
The temperature to which a material must be raised for it to ignite, but not continue to burn, when a flame is passed above it.
Not susceptible to burning violently when ignited..
A problem in oxy-gas welding in which the flame burns back into the mixing chamber of the torch.
An automatic switch installed in a light system to turn the lights on and off in a definite sequence.
A step in the curing process of a finishing system.
A maintenance procedure for an aircraft generator that restores residual magnetism to the field frame.
An ignition system problem in which the high voltage in the magneto distributor jumps to the wrong terminal.
A common type of file used to smooth the edges or surface of a piece of metal or hard plastic.
Wood that has been sawed in such a way that the annual rings form an angle of less than 45o to the face of the piece.
A type of lacquer that dries with a flat, or nonglossy, surface.
The pattern for a sheet metal part that has the material used for each flat surface, and for all of the bends marked out with bend-tangent lines drawn between the flats and bend allowances.
An aircraft maneuver in which the aircraft is autorotating (being pulled around by aerodynamic forces) as it descends, with one wing flying, and the other actually stalled.
A disk of metal with a hole in its center.

A compound-wound generator (having a series and a parallel, or shunt, winding) in which the effect of the two fields are balanced so they hold the output voltage constant from a no-load condition to the maximum load the generator can produce.
A high-strength steel pin with a flat head on one end and a hole for a cotter pin on the other end.
An AN-442 rivet used on the inside of an aircraft structure where it is not exposed to the airflow.
A turboprop engine whose allowable output power is less than the engine is physically capable of producing.
An imperfection in a material, often concealed, that impairs soundness.
The average weight of aircraft of the same model that have the same equipment installed.
Place the fingers of the right hand around a current-carrying conductor in such a way that the thumb points in the direction of conventional current flow (from positive to negative).
Fleming'S Rule For Direction Of Magnetic Flux
This is the rule for determining the direction of current flow in a wire caused by the wire passing through a magnetic field.
The rule for determining the direction of movement of a current-carrying conductor in a magnetic field.
The characteristic of a material that allows it to be repeatedly bent within its elastic limits and still return to its original condition each time the bending force is removed.
A steel cable used to connect the cockpit controls to the control surfaces.
The command unit of an automatic pilot.
A sealed recording instrument installed in transport aircraft that makes a continuous record of the flight altitude, airspeed, heading, accelerations, and voices and noises heard on the flight deck.
The compartment in a large aircraft in which all the flight, engine, communications, and navigation controls are located.
An automatic flight control system in which the commands needed to fly the aircraft are computed by the system, shown on a flight instrument, and followed by the human pilot.
A flightcrew member of a large aircraft who is responsible for the mechanical operation of the aircraft and its engineers.
An engine speed that produces a minimum amount of flight thrust.
A service provided by the FAA for the purpose of giving advice and information useful for safe and efficient conduct of flights.
In-flight investigation and evaluation of navigational aids to determine whether they meet established tolerances.
The area of an airport in which aircraft are parked while they are being prepared for flight.
An arrival, departure, or approach procedure developed for use by aircraft with a slant (/)E or slant (/)F equipment suffix.
A computer system that uses a large data base to allow routes to be preprogrammed and fed into the system by means of a data loader.
An FAA-approved manual that must be in an aircraft any time it flies.
The line, course, or track along which an aircraft is flying or is intended to be flown.
Specific information related to the intended flight of an aircraft.

The geographical area assigned by regional air traffic divisions to a flight service station for the purpose of search and rescue for VFR aircraft, issuance of NOTAMs, pilot briefing, in-flight services, broadcast, emergency services, flight data processing, international operations, and aviation weather services.

Air traffic control facilities which provide the following services: pilot briefing, enroute communications, VFR search and rescue, Assistance to lost aircraft and aircraft in emergency situations, Relay ATC clearances, Originate Notices to Airmen, Broadcast aviation weather and NAS information, Receive and process IFR flight plans, Monitor navaids with some also providing Enroute Flight Advisory Service, Take weather observations, Issue airport advisories, and Advise Customs & Immigration of transborder flights.
A training device that duplicates the flight characteristics of an aircraft.

An FAA field office serving an assigned geographical area, staffed with Flight Standards personnel who serve the aviation industry and the general public on matters relating to the certification and operation of air carrier and general aviation aircraft.
Flight for the purpose of investigating the flight or operational characteristics of an aircraft or aircraft component, or evaluating an applicant for a pilot certificate or rating.
The time from the moment the aircraft first moves under its own power for the purpose of flight until the moment it comes to rest at the next point of landing. ('Block-to block' time)..

The average forward horizontal distance, from the cockpit of an aircraft in flight, at which prominent unlighted objects may be seen and identified by day and prominent lighted objects may be seen and identified by night..
A shortened term for use in air-ground contacts on the frequency of 122.0 MHz to identify the flight service station providing enroute flight advisory service (EFAS).
A pilot, flight engineer, or flight navigator assigned to duty in an aircraft during flight time..
A device used to light an oxy-gas welding torch.
A digital building block having two stable states, used to store information.
A storage battery permanently installed across the output of a generator.
An electrical reference point in a piece of equipment that is not connected to the earth ground.

A type of carburetor used on reciprocating engines in which the fuel-metering force is produced by a float-operated needle valve that keeps the fuel level a constant distance below the edge of he discharge nozzle.
Pulverized wool or cotton fibers mixed with an adhesive.

A reciprocating engine that has too much fuel in its cylinders for it to start, or a turbine engine that has so much fuel in its combustors that it would create a fire hazard or a hot start if the fuel were ignited.
A diagram that uses special symbols connected by arrows or lines to indicate the sequence of step-by-step procedures that must be followed to accomplish a given task.
Measures designed to adjust the flow of traffic into a given airspace, along a given route, or bound for a given airport in order to ensure the most effective utilization of the airspace.
The valve in a Precision Airmotive RSA fuel injection system that divides the fuel from the fuel control unit and distributes to all of the cylinders it equally.
A component in a turbine engine fuel system that routes all of the fuel to the primary nozzles or primary orifices when starting the engine and when the RPM is low.
An indicator visible to the wearer of an oxygen mask that shows when oxygen is flowing into the mask.
A fluid power valve that controls the direction or amount of fluid flow.
To swing back and forth or to shift a value between a high and a low limit.
A malfunction in an electric arc welding system that causes the arc to vary its intensity.
A form of material whose molecules are able to flow past one another without destroying the material.
The branch of science and technology that deals with forces produced by fluids, either gaseous or liquid.
A unit of liquid volume which is equal to 1/16-liquid pint, or 1.8 cubic inches.
The transmission of force by the movement of a fluid.
Mechanical systems that transfer energy from one location to another by the use of fluids.
The branch of technology that uses a flow of fluids through specially shaped ducts and nozzles to sense, measure, and control a physical condition.

The emission of electromagnetic radiation, especially in the frequency of visible light, stimulated in a substance by the absorption of incident radiation and persisting only so long as the stimulating radiation if continued.
A tubular electric lamp in which ionized mercury vapor causes a fluorescent coating inside the tube to glow.
A form of nondestructive inspection used to detect surface faults in either ferrous or nonferrous metals or in nonporous nonmetallic materials.
Pigment used in a paint which can absorb either visible or nonvisible electromagnetic radiation and release it as energy of the desired wavelength.
A pale yellow, highly corrosive, poisonous, gaseous, halogen chemical element.
An instrument used for nondestructive inspection.
A type of sheet metal repair that leaves a perfectly smooth surface.
An MS20426 aircraft solid rivet that has a counter-sunk head.
A groove cut into a cylindrical object.
Rapid and uncontrolled oscillation of a flight control surface on an aircraft caused by a dynamically unbalanced condition.
Lines of magnetic flux are the same as lines of magnetic force.
A material used to prepare a metal so it will accept solder.
The number of lines of magnetic flux in a unit of area.
A special transformer that receives a directional signal from the earth's magnetic field and directs it into an amplifier and then into a gyro-stabilized compass indicator.
A special transformer that receives a directional signal from the earth's magnetic field and directs it into an amplifier and then into a gyro-stabilized compass indicator.
An adjustable hole cutter turned in a drill press.

A method of control used by some modern aircraft in which control movement or pressures exerted by the pilot are directed into a digital computer where they are input into a program tailored to the flight characteristics of the aircraft.
An airplane whose fuselage is built in the form of a boat hull to allow it to land and takeoff from water.
A type of heavier-than-air aircraft that has no fuselage or tail surfaces.
Speed sensors used in many types of governors and speed-control devices.
A heavy wheel used to smooth the pulsations in a drive system.
One of the characteristics of an LC circuit, a circuit that contains both inductance and capacitance.
One method of putting an audio frequency signal on a radio frequency carrier.
A method of removing paint from an aircraft surface by dry-blasting it with tiny plastic beads.
An electronic flight instrumentation system that allows the flight crew to initiate and implement a given flight plan and monitor its execution.
A computer system that uses a large data base to allow routes to be preprogrammed and fed into the system by means of a data loader.
A form of rubber filled with millions of tiny air bubbles.
A synthetic resin filled with millions of tiny bubbles.
A condition in a lubrication system in which oil passing through the engine picks up air which causes thousands of tiny bubbles to form.
Damage to the components in the gas path of a turbine engine that is caused by ingesting objects that are not part of the engine.
Warm, dry downslope wind whose warmness and dryness is caused by adiabatic compression upon descent.
An obscuration to visibility caused by water droplets that are small enough to remain suspended in the air.
A form of metal rolled out into very thin sheets.
A type of machine-sewed seam in which the edges of the fabric are folded back and a double row of stitches used to form the seam.
A signal in an autopilot or system that nulls out the input signal to the servo when the correct amount of control surface deflection has been reached.
The amount of illumination on a surface when all points are one foot from a uniform light source of one candela, the amount of light produced by one international candle.
The basic measure of work in the English gravitational system.
The amount of torque produced when one pound of force is applied one foot from the point of rotation.
The basic measure of work in the English absolute system.
Energy brought to bear on an object that causes or tries to cause it to change its direction or speed of motion.
An unscheduled landing caused by a malfunction in an aircraft or engine, or by improper flight planning or operation.
A type of instrument or small tool used to grasp or hold objects.
Welding in which the torch is pointed in the direction the weld is progressing.
Any person other than a citizen of the United States, who undertakes directly, by lease or other arrangement, to engage in air transportation..

The carriage by aircraft of persons or property for compensation or hire, or the carriage of mail by aircraft, or the operation or navigation of aircraft in the conduct or furtherance of a business or vocation, in commerce between a place in the United States and any place outside thereof; whether such commerce moves wholly by aircraft or partly by aircraft and partly by other forms of transportation..

(2) The carriage by aircraft of persons or property as a common carrier for compensation or hire, or the carriage of mail by aircraft, in commerce between a place in the United States and any place outside of the United States, whether that commerce moves wholly by aircraft or partly by aircraft and partly by other forms of transportation..
A method of welding in which the two ends of the metal to be joined are heated until they are almost, but not quite, melted.
A method of forming metal parts by heating the metal to a plastic state (Nearly, but not quite melted) and hammering it to shape.
A self-propelled machine used to lift heavy weights and move them from one location to another.
Parasite drag that is caused by the form of the object passing through the air.
The ratio of the length of a coil of wire to its diameter.
Flight of more than one aircraft which, by prior arrangement between the pilots, operate as a single aircraft with regard to navigation and position reporting.
An aircraft structural member used to give a fuselage its shape.
A block of hardwood around which sheet metal parts are formed.

A condition of operation of a semiconductor device, such as a transistor or a diode, in which a positive voltage is connected to the P-type material, and a negative voltage is connected to the N-type material.
The most forward location on an aircraft allowed for its loaded center of gravity.
Current that flows across the junction in a semiconductor device when it is forward-biased.
The voltage drop across a semiconductor device when forward current is flowing through it.
A forward lifting surface of a canard configuration or tandem-wing configuration airplane. The surface may be a fixed, movable, or variable geometry surface, with or without control surfaces..
A turbofan engine with some of its low-pressure compressor blades extended.
A spark plug that is unable to fire because of contamination in its firing-end cavity.
A constant-volume cycle of energy transformation that has separate strokes for intake, compression, power, and exhaust.
A form of reciprocating engine which has an intake and an exhaust valve in each cylinder.
A type of wing flap which moves out of the trailing edge of a wing on tracks.
A chemical compound added to a liquid to lower its freezing temperature.
The procedure used for separating the various components from a physical mixture of liquids.
Clouds in the form of ragged, irregular shreds, appearing as if they were torn.
An extremely unstable, radioactive chemical element. Francium's symbol is Fr, and its atomic number is 87.
A lighter-than-air device that if free to rise in the air.
Electrons that are not bound to any particular atom.
A loose fit between moving parts, used when accuracy of movement is not important.
A turbine or stage of turbines in a gas turbine engine that is not used to drive the compressor in the gas-generator section of the engine.

A component part of the transmission or power train of a helicopter which automatically disconnects the main rotor from the engine when the engine stops or slows below the equivalent RPM of the rotor.
A form of oscillator that produces a square-wave output.
The process in which a liquid is changed into a solid by the removal of heat energy.
The level in the atmosphere at which the temperature is 0oC (32oF).
The temperature at which a liquid changes into a solid.
A type of machine-sewed seam in which the edges of the two pieces of fabric are folded together, and a double row of stitches passes through four thcknesses of the material.
The registered trade name for a fluorinated hydrocarbon compound used as a refrigerant and a fire extinguishing agent.
The number of complete cycles of a recurring event that take place in one unit of time.
A circuit which changes the frequency of alternating current.
An electronic circuit whose output has a frequency that is an exact divisor of the frequency at the input.
An electronic circuit whose output is resonant at the second harmonic of the input signal.
An electrical instrument that measures the frequency of an alternating current and shows this frequency directly on its dial.
One method of putting an audio frequency signal on a radio frequency carrier.
An electronic circuit whose output has a frequency that is a multiple of the frequency of the input signal.
An electronic circuit used to produce alternating current having an accurately controlled frequency.
A constant-voltage charge given to dry-charged batteries to get them ready for installation.
A type of mechanical damage to the surface of an object.
A form of corrosion between two surfaces which have a slight amount of relative motion between them.
Opposition to the relative movement between two objects.
A mechanism used with a rotating wheel or shaft in which friction is used to slow its rotation.
A device used to connect a motor to a mechanical load.
The error caused by friction in an instrument mechanism.
The amount of horsepower used to turn the crankshaft, pistons, gears and accessories in a reciprocating engine, and to compress the air in the cylinders.
The loss of mechanical energy in a mechanism caused by friction changing mechanical energy into heat.

A measurement of the friction characteristics of the runway pavement surface, using continuous self-watering friction measurement equipment in accordance with the specifications, procedures, and schedules contained in AC 150/5320-121, Measurement, Construction, and Maintenance of Skid-Resistance Airport Pavement Surfaces.
A type of electrical insulating tape that was commonly used in the past, but is being replaced by more effective types of tape.
A method of joining thermoplastic materials by rubbing the mating surfaces together while applying a large amount of pressure.
A type of aileron used for lateral control of an airplane.
A surface, interface, or transition zone of discontinuity between two adjacent air masses having different densities.
A front or zone with a marked increase-of-density gradient.
The initial formation of a frontal zone.
The dissipation of a front or frontal zone.
A mirror with the reflective material on its front surface, rather than on the back.
A rough measurement of the condition of a semiconductor diode.
Ice crystal deposits formed by sublimation when the temperature and dew point are below freezing.
The portion of a cone or a cone-shaped solid from which the top has been removed.

An FAA field office serving an assigned geographical area, staffed with Flight Standards personnel who serve the aviation industry and the general public on matters relating to the certification and operation of air carrier and general aviation aircraft.

Air traffic control facilities which provide the following services: pilot briefing, enroute communications, VFR search and rescue, Assistance to lost aircraft and aircraft in emergency situations, Relay ATC clearances, Originate Notices to Airmen, Broadcast aviation weather and NAS information, Receive and process IFR flight plans, Monitor navaids with some also providing Enroute Flight Advisory Service, Take weather observations, Issue airport advisories, and Advise Customs & Immigration of transborder flights.
Any material that can be burned to release its energy.

An auxiliary fuel pump used in an aircraft fuel system to provide fuel pressure for starting the engine, for use as an emergency backup in case the fuel pump fails, and to transfer fuel from one tank to another.
The fuel metering device for a gas turbine engine that senses the variables of power lever position, pressure, speed, and temperature in the engine.
A device in the fuel line between the engine-driven fuel pump and the carburetor that measures the rate of flow of the fuel.
An instrument used to show the rate of fuel flowing to an engine.
A form of fuel-air heat exchange in which heat is taken from the compressor bleed air and put into the fuel before it flows through the fuel filter.
The valve used in a reciprocating engine fuel injection system that takes fuel from the fuel control unit and distributes it to the various injection nozzles.
A form of fuel metering system for a reciprocating engine that injects the fuel directly into the cylinder, rather than mixing it with the air before it is taken in through the intake valve.
The portion of an aircraft fuel system that allows fuel to be dumped from the tanks to lower the landing weight so a safe landing can be made.
The expendable part of the load of the aircraft.
The nozzle in a gas turbine engine combustor through which the fuel is discharged.
Unintentional release of fuel from an aircraft, caused by overflow, puncture, loose tank caps, etc..
A fuel quantity indicator that gives the total amount of fuel remaining on board the aircraft on one instrument.
The ratio of the number of pounds of fuel to the number of pounds of air in the mixture burned, in an internal combustion engine.
A heat exchanger used on turbine engines to take heat from the engine oil and put it into the fuel.
The point about which a lever balances.
The position of the rotating magnet in an aircraft magneto in which the poles of the magnet are aligned with the pole shoes.
The position of the mixture control in the fuel metering system of a reciprocating engine that meters the maximum amount of fuel to the engine.
A drawing of a part drawn to the full size of the part.
A type of rectifier circuit used to change alternating current into direct current that uses both the positive and negative alternation of the AC.
A helicopter rotor whose blades are attached to the hub in such a way that they are free to flap, drag, and feather (see each of these terms).
A test given to a component or system to determine whether or not it functions as it should.
Vibration of a mechanical object that has the lowest frequency and the highest amplitude.
The length of the wave of the fundamental frequency of an electromagnetic radiation.
A paste containing an agent that kills the spores of fungus and mildew.
Any of several types of plant life that include yeasts, molds, and mildew.
A tornado, or vortex cloud, extending downward from the parent cloud, but not reaching the ground.
An electrical circuit protection device that consists of a strip of low-melting-point metal that will melt and open the circuit when an excessive amount of current flows through it.
A hydraulic flow control valve that automatically closes when a given amount of fluid has passed, or when an excessive pressure drop occurs across the valve.
A device that holds a tubular fuse and makes connections to both its ends.
A strip of low-melting-point metal used in an electrical fuse to protect a circuit.
The body, or central structural component of an airplane.
A line parallel to the longitudinal axis of an airplane that divides the fuselage into symmetrical halves.
The location along the longitudinal axis of an aircraft that is a given number of inches ahead of or behind the datum, or reference plane.
A safety plug used in an aircraft wheel that mounts a tubeless tire.
A nuclear reaction in which two or more atomic nuclei collide at very high speed and join to form a new type of atomic nucleus.

An FAA field office serving a designated geographical area, staffed with Flight Standards personnel who have responsibility for serving the aviation industry and the general public on all matters relating to the certification and operation of general aviation aircraft.
A silvery-white, malleable, ductile, metallic, rare-earth chemical element.
A gage (also spelled gauge) is a measuring instrument.
The distance between rows of rivets in a multirow seam.
A precision-ground block of hardened and polished steel used as the standard for precise linear measurements in most manufacturing processes, and to check the accuracy of micrometer calipers.
Pressure referenced from the existing atmospheric pressure.
An increase in the power of an electrical signal produced by an amplifier.
A bluish-gray crystal that is primarily lead sulfide (PbS).
A form of damage to the mating surfaces of moving metal parts.
A rare, metallic chemical element that melts at approximately 30oC. Gallium's symbol is Ga, its atomic number is 31, and its atomic weight is 69.72.
A unit of liquid measurement used in the United Kingdom.
A unit of liquid measurement used in the United States of America.
Electrical pressure within a substance which causes electron flow because of the difference of electrode potential within a material.
A form of corrosion that occurs between two metals having different locations in the electrolytic, or galvanic, series.
A pair of unlike metals that produce an electrical potential when they are covered with an electrolyte.
The production of electricity by chemical action.
The arrangement of metals in a series according to their electrode potential difference.
A list of metals arranged in the order of their chemical activity.
A form of corrosion protection for steel parts in which the surface of the steel is covered with a coating of zinc.
An instrument used to measure electrical current.
The molecular arrangement of iron at temperatures between 911oC and 1,392oC.
A form of electromagnetic radiation that results from nuclear fission.
An abrasive and polishing paper made by coating one side of a sheet of flexible paper with a layer of crushed garnet.

The branch of science or technology that deals with the forces produced by incompressible fluids in motion.

A watercraft with a conventional hull which supports it when it is still or moving at a slow speed, but when traveling at a high speed, hydrodynamic lift produced by hydrofoils below the hull lifts the vessel out of the water, greatly decreasing the drag and allowing the vessel to travel at a higher speed.
Flat or airfoil-shaped plates attached to struts below the hull of a hydrofoil watercraft.
A colorless, highly flammable, lighter-than-air, gaseous chemical element. Hydrogen's symbol is H, its atomic number is 1, and its atomic weight is 1.00797.
A nuclear weapon in which two light elements such as deuterium and tritium are forced together under extreme conditions of heat and pressure.
A form of brazing in which hydrogen is used as the fuel gas.
A condition in which certain types of metal become brittle from absorbing hydrogen while they are being electroplated.
A heavy, colorless, unstable liquid used as a bleaching agent, an antiseptic, and a fuel for liquid-propellant rocket engines.
The change in a chemical substance caused by water.
Any device that combines fluid pressures with mechanical actions to achieve a desired result.
A general term for particles of liquid water or ice, such as rain, fog, frost, etc., formed by modification of water vapor in the atmosphere.
An instrument used to measure the specific gravity of a liquid.
A condition that can exist when a high-speed airplane is landed on a water-covered runway.
Equipment that uses both hydraulic and pneumatic forces.
A hydrofoil mounted below the hull of a flying boat.
A type of test required for cylinders used to carry compressed gases.
A chemical compound consisting of a metal, usually a base, or a non-metal, usually an acid, and a negative hydroxyl ion (OH).
The record produced by a continuous recording hygrometer.
An instrument used to measure the amount of moisture in the air to determine its humidity.
A material that absorbs moisture from the air.
A series of experimental high-performance aircraft engines built with U.S. Army and Navy financing in the early 1930s.
A plane curve traced by a point that moves in such a way that the difference of its distance from two fixed points, called foci, remains constant.
A system of electronic navigation in which a master and a remotely located slave station transmit a signal simultaneously.
Flight at air speeds greater than five times the local speed of sound, more than Mach 5.0.
A breathing problem caused by too little carbon dioxide in the lungs.
The side of a right triangle opposite the right angle.
A physiological condition in which a person is deprived of the needed oxygen.
A condition in which a physical action lags behind its cause.
An instrument error that causes a difference in the readings of an instrument when the indicated values are increasing, compared with the readings at the same point when the values are decreasing.
A curve showing the way flux density in a magnetic material varies with the magnetizing force applied to it.
Electrical power dissipated in an electrical circuit computed by multiplying the square of the current by the circuit resistance.
The electric power lost in an electrical device, such as a transformer.
An authorization issued by the Federal Aviation Administration to certain licensed and experienced aviation maintenance technicians that allows the to perform annual and progressive inspections.
The fixes depicted on the instrument approach procedure charts that identify the beginning of the initial approach segment.
A series of predetermined maneuvers for the orderly transfer of an aircraft under instrument flight conditions from the beginning of the initial approach segment(s)).
The speed an aircraft is moving through the air as is shown on the air as is shown on the air-speed indicator, before any corrections for errors or non-standard conditions are made.
A piece of structural material having a cross-sectional shape that resembles the letter I.
A combination of electronic components built onto a single substrate of semiconductor material.

A specialized agency of the United Nations whose objective is to develop the principles and techniques of international air navigation and to foster planning and development of international civil air transport.
A spark plug failure that occurs when a reciprocating engine is started in extremely cold weather.
A type of precipitation composed of unbranched ice crystals in the form of needles, columns, or plates.
An obstruction to visibility caused by tiny ice crystals, rather than the tiny droplets of water that make up ordinary fog.
A light mounted on the fuselage of an airplane in such a way that it shines on the leading edge of the wing.
A long, thin ice crystal with a hexagonal cross section.
Small, transparent or translucent, round or irregularly shaped pellets.
A solid aircraft rivet made of 2017 or 2024 aluminum alloy.
Ice forming on an aircraft. Classifications of icing are: clear, rime, and glaze.
A request by ATC for a pilot to activate the radar beacon transponder identification feature.
The special feature in the Air Traffic Control Radar Beacon System (ATCRBS) equipment used to immediately distinguish one displayed beacon target from other beacon targets.

A warning light, whose proper name is nondiscrete indicator, used instead of an indicating instrument.
The position of the mixture control in a reciprocating engine fuel metering system that shuts off all fuel to the cylinders.

The lowest speed at which an engine operates smoothly when it is not carrying any type of mechanical load.
The thrust produced by an aircraft gas turbine engine when the power control lever is pulled back to the idle stop.
A gear used to reverse the direction of rotation of another gear without changing its speed of rotation.
A pulley in a belt-drive system used to adjust the tension on the belt that joins a drive pulley with a driven pulley.
Current flowing in an electronic circuit when there is no input signal requiring the system to act.

An electronic identification system that is the forerunner of the modern radar beacon transponder use by air traffic controllers to identify specific aircraft, IFF, developed in the latter part of World War II, is an electronic pulse system in which interrogation pulses of electrical energy are transmitted from a ground station and received to the aircraft.
A publication designed primarily as a pilot's preflight planning guide for flights into foreign airspace and for flights returning to the U.S. from foreign locations.
Rules and regulations established by the Federal Aviation Administration to govern flight under conditions in which flight by outside visual reference is not safe.
Weather conditions below the minimums allowed for flight under visual flight rules..

Routes used by the Department of Defense and associated Reserve and Air Guard units for the purpose of conducting low-altitude navigation and tactical training in both IFR and VFR weather conditions below 10,000 feet MSL at airspeeds in excess of 250 knots IAS.

With respect to the operation of aircraft, means the operation of an aircraft over-the-top on an IFR flight plan when cleared by air traffic control to maintain 'VFR conditions' or 'VFR conditions on top'..
Minimums listed in 14 CFR Part 91, prescribing standard takeoff rules for certain civil users.
IFR Takeoff Minimums And Departure Procedures (Atc)
A field-effect transistor whose gate is insulated from the channel by a layer of silicon oxide.
A component in a gas turbine engine used to ignite the fuel-air mixture when the engine is being started.
The procedure by which the temperature of a position of the fuel-air mixture in the engine is raised high enough for the hydrocarbon fuel to begin combining with the oxygen in the air .
The complete set of high-tension cables, terminals, and connectors used to carry high voltage from the magnetos to the various spark plugs in the engine.

The cylinder of a reciprocating engine with both the intake and exhaust valves mounted in the head.

An exploded view of an assembly in which all of the component parts are laid out so each can be identified.
A special type of electronic guidance system used to allow aircraft to land when the ceiling and visibility are too low for a safe visual approach to the runway.

Categories of instrument flight allowed at airports equipped with the following types of instrument landing systems: Cat I - ILS approach procedure which provides for approach to a height above touchdown of not less than 200 feet with runway visual range of not less than 1,800 feet; Cat II - ILS approach procedure which provides for approach to a height above touchdown of not less than 100 feet with runway visual range of not less than 1,200 feet; Cat IIIA - ILS approach procedure which provides approach without a decision height minimum and with runway visual range of not less than 700 feet; Cat IIIB - ILS approach procedure which provides for approach without a decision height minimum and with runway visual range of not l less than 150 feet; Cat IIIC - ILS procedure which provides for approach without a decision minimum and without runway visual range minimum .
Meteorological conditions expressed in terms of visibility, distance from cloud, and ceiling less than the minimums specified for visual meteorological conditions.
The average pressure existing inside the cylinder of a reciprocating engine during its power stroke.
An electrical heater used to heat liquids by immersing (submerging) the heater in the liquid.
A form of extrusion made by forcing cold metal through a die by striking it a hard blow.
Ice that forms on an aircraft flying through freezing rain or other visible moisture when the air temperature is in the freezing range (between 0o and -15oC).
Pressure resulting when moving air is stopped.
A power-driven tool used to install and remove nuts, bolts, and screws.
The total opposition to the flow of alternating current caused by the combined effect of resistance, capacitance, and inductance in a circuit.

The process of matching the impedance of a source of electrical power with the impedance of the load using the power.

A situation in which there is uncertainty as to the safety of an aircraft and its occupants.
A unit for measuring absolute pressure.
A measure of torque, or the rotation that is caused by a force of one pound acting one inch from the center of rotation.

Light that falls on a object after it has been reflected from a nonlight-producing object.

Frequencies of vibration lower than those in the audible range.

A type of vertical speed indicator that compensates for the lag inherent in these instruments.

A device using an internal mechanism to show visually or aurally the attitude, altitude, or operation of an aircraft or aircraft part. It includes electronic devices for automatically controlling an aircraft in flight..

A series of predetermined maneuvers for the orderly transfer of an aircraft under instrument flight conditions from the beginning of the initial approach to a landing or to a point from which a landing may be made visually.
Aeronautical charts that portray the aeronautical data required to execute an instrument approach to an airport.
A cylindrical metal clamp attached to the back of an instrument panel aligned with the hole through which an instrument fits.
A special type of electronic guidance system used to allow aircraft to land when the ceiling and visibility are too low for a safe visual approach to the runway.
Meteorological conditions expressed in terms of visibility, distance from cloud, and ceiling less than the minimums specified for visual meteorological conditions.
A panel in the cockpit of an aircraft that holds all the indicating instruments used to show the condition of the aircraft and its engines.
A runway equipped with electronic and visual navigation aids for which a precision or nonprecision approach having straight-in landing minimums has been approved.
An electrical shunt used with a milli-voltmeter to measure current.
An adhesive-backed flexible tape used as a temporary insulation over wire terminals and wire splices.

A measure of the amount of electrical stress an insulation can withstand before it breaks down and conducts.

A whole number, or counting number.

A tiny chip or wafer of silicon on which is etched, imprinted, or diffused electronic components such as transistors, diodes, capacitors and resistors with their interconnections.

A structural member used in a stressed-skin structure to stiffen the skin between the bulkheads or other major structural components.
Pieces of thin sheet metal installed between the cylinders of an air-cooled aircraft engine to force air to flow through the fins on the cylinders.

The difference between the angles at which the valve set and the valve face are ground.

A type of fit used when assembling certain mechanical devices.
A type of corrosion which forms along the boundaries of the grains inside a piece of metal alloy.

A form of heat engine in which the fuel and air mixture is burned inside the engine to heat and expand the air so it can perform work.
A device used to lock the flight controls of an aircraft so they cannot be damaged by the wind.
Opposition to the flow of current caused by the plates of a battery.
A gear-driven centrifugal air pump installed inside a reciprocating engine.
A pressure-operated valve in the bottom of the internal supercharger section of a reciprocating engine that is open when the pressures inside and outside the supercharger housing are the same.

Correctly meshing the gears and adjusting the breaker point clearance in an aircraft magneto so the breaker points begin to open when the rotating magnet is in the correct position relative to the pole shoes, in its E-gap position.
A special type of bolt having a large, cylindrical head with a flat top and a hexagonal socket cut into it.
An airport having customs service for passengers arriving from foreign countries.
A publication designed primarily as a pilot's preflight planning guide for flights into foreign airspace and for flights returning to the U.S. from foreign locations.
A group of dot and dash combinations which have been agreed upon internationally to represent the letters of the alphabet, numbers, and certain punctuation symbols.

A takeoff or proposed takeoff on a runway from an intersection.
A transformer used to couple two stages of an electronic device.

The carriage by aircraft of persons or property for compensation or hire, or the carriage of mail by aircraft, or the operation or navigation of aircraft in the conduct or furtherance of a business or vocation, in commerce between a place in any State of the United States, or the District of Columbia, and a place in any other State of the U.S. or the District of Columbia; or between places in the same State of the U.S. through the airspace over any place outside thereof; or between places in the same territory or possession of the U.S. or the District of Columbia..

The carriage by aircraft of persons or property as a common carrier for compensation or hire, or the carriage of mail by aircraft in commerce: (1) Between a place in a State or the D.of C. and another place in another State or the D.of C.; (2) Between places in the same State through the airspace over any place outside that State; or (3) Between places in the same possession of the United States; Whether that commerce moves wholly by aircraft or partially by aircraft and partly by other forms of transportation..
The boundary zone between the trade wind system of the northern and southern hemispheres.

The carriage of persons or property as a common carrier for compensation or hire, by turbojet-powered aircraft capable of carrying thirty or more persons, wholly within the same state of the United States..
The registered trade name for an alloy of 63.8% iron, 36% nickel, and 0.2% carbon.

A ratio of reciprocals of two quantities.
A law of physics that applies to several natural conditions, such as the strength of a magnetic field, the amount of light falling on a surface, and the intensity of sound pressure.

An increase in temperature with height.

An acrobatic flight maneuver in which and aircraft spins in an inverted attitude.
An electrical component which changes direct current into alternating current.
A logic device with one input and one output.

The decrease in electrical pressure caused by electrons flowing through a resistance.

A ballistic missile with a range of between 200 and 1,500 miles.

An uninterrupted descent (except where level flight is required for speed adjustment; e.g., 250 knots at 10,000 feet MSL) from cruising altitude or flight level to the interception of a glideslope or to a minimum altitude specified for the initial or intermediate approach segment of a nonprecision instrument approach.

With respect to rotorcraft turbine engines, means the approved brake horsepower developed under static conditions at specified altitudes and temperatures within the operating limitations established for the engine under Part 33 of this chapter, and limited in use to a period of not more than 2 1/2 minutes after the failure of one engine of a multiengine rotorcraft..

With respect to rotor-craft turbine engines, means the approved brake horsepower developed under static conditions at specified altitudes and temperatures within the operating limitations established for the engine under Part 33 of this chapter, and limited in use to a period of not more than 30 minutes after the failure of one engine of a multiengine rotorcraft..

With respect to rotor-craft turbine engines, means the approved brake horsepower developed under static conditions at specified altitudes and temperatures within the operating limitations established for the engine under Part 33 of this chapter, and limited in use to the time required to complete the flight after the failure of one engine of a multiengine rotorcraft..
Rated Continuous Oei (One Engine Inoperative) Power
The horsepower the engine manufacturer guarantees an engine will produce under specified conditions.

With respect to turbojet engine type certification, means the approved jet thrust that is developed statically or in flight, in standard atmosphere at a specified altitude, with fluid injection or with the burning of fuel in a separate combustion chamber, within the engine operating limitations established under Part 33 of this chapter, and approved for unrestricted periods of use..

With respect to reciprocating, turbopropeller, and turboshaft engines, means the approved brake horsepower that is developed statically or in flight, in standard atmosphere at a specified altitude, within the engine operating limitations established under Part 33, and approved for unrestricted periods of use..

With respect to turbojet engine type certification, means the approved jet thrust that is developed statically or in flight, in standard atmosphere at a specified altitude, without fluid injection and without the burning of fuel in a separate combustion chamber, within the engine operating limitations established under Part 33 of this chapter, and approved for unrestricted periods of use..

With respect to turbojet engine type certification, means the approved jet thrust that is developed statically under standard sea level conditions, with fluid injection or with the burning of fuel in a separate combustion chamber, within the engine operating limitations established under Part 33 of this chapter, and limited in use to periods of not over 5 minutes for takeoff operation..

With respect to reciprocating, turbopropeller, and turbo-shaft engine type certification, means the approved brake horsepower that is developed statically under standard sea level conditions, within the engine operating limitations established under Part 33, and limited in use to periods of not over 5 minutes for takeoff operation..

With respect to turbojet engine type certification, means the approved jet thrust that is developed statically under standard sea level conditions, without fluid injection and without the burning of fuel in a separate combustion chamber, within the engine operating limitations established under Part 33 of this chapter, and limited in use to periods of not over 5 minutes for takeoff operation..

Temperature of the air just above a runway, ideally at engine and/or wing height.

A red oxide that forms on ferrous metal (metal that contains iron).
A hard, white, acid-resistant, metallic chemical element.
An instrumentally derived horizontal distance a pilot should see down the runway from the approach end.
A form of corrosion in which an active material is used as the anode in the corrosion process to protect a less active material.
A piece of plywood glued to an aircraft structural member.
A type of lubricating oil tank used with a gas turbine engine.
A professional organization that formulates standards for the automotive and aviation industries.

An alert issued by ATC to aircraft under their control if ATC is aware that the aircraft is at an altitude which, in the controller's judgment, places it in unsafe proximity to terrain, obstructions, or other aircraft.
A belt installed in an aircraft to hold the occupants tight in their seat.
The ratio of the maximum load a structure is designed to support, to the maximum load it will ever be required to support.

A location inside a high-tension magneto in which a portion of the metal housing is close enough to the high-voltage terminal to prevent the secondary voltage building up high enough to damage the coil insulation.
A type of glass that does not leave jagged fragments when it breaks.
A pressure relief valve used on containers holding a compressible fluid under pressure.
Soft wire used to secure fasteners (bolts, pins, and clips) so they will not vibrate loose in operation.
A discharge of static electricity often seen on airplanes flying through stormy weather.
A name commonly used for ammonium chloride.
A field pole of an electrical generator or motor that has its own pole shoe protruding radially inward from the field frame.
A product of a chemical reaction in which a metal displaces the hydrogen in an acid.
A pale gray, rare-earth, metallic chemical element.
A method of casting metal parts in a mold made of sand .
A heavy canvas or leather bag filled with sand.
A coat of heavy-bodied surfacer material sprayed over a surface to be painted.
An abrasive paper made by bonding grains of sharp sand to the surface of a piece of paper.
A type of laminated structure used where high strength, light weight, and rigidity are required.
A hot, dry, foehn wind, generally from the northeast or east, occurring west of the Sierra Nevada Mountains, especially in the pass and river valley near Santa Ana, California.
An object that rotates in an orbit around a larger object.
Fabric in which the warp threads pass under one fill thread and over several more.
A type of electrical transformer whose core permeability is varied to control the current flowing in its secondary winding.
To combine to such an extend that there is no more tendency to combine.
The rate of decrease of temperature with altitude as saturated air is lifted with no gain or loss of heat from outside sources.
The condition of the vapor above a liquid that will not allow any more of the liquid to evaporate.
The condition of the atmosphere when the actual water vapor present in the air is the maximum the air can hold at the existing temperature.
The waveform of voltage produced by a relaxation oscillator.
A measure of the viscosity (resistance to flow) of a lubricating oil.
Radar that operates in the frequency band between 1,550 and 5,200 megahertz.
A copy of something made in the same proportions as the original, but of a smaller size.
A closed, three-sided, plane (flat) figure that has no two sides of the same length, nor are any of the angles the same.
A silvery-white, very lightweight, rare-earth, metallic chemical element. Its symbol is Se, its atomic number 21, and atomic weight is 44.956.
A joint in a wood structure in which the end to be joined are cut in a long taper, normally 12:1, and fastened together by gluing.
A type of patch made to a thin plywood structure.
The subsystem in the lubrication system of a gas turbine engine that collects the oil after it has lubricated the bearings and gears and returns it to the oil tank.
A pump in a dry sump lubrication system that picks up the oil after it passes through the engine and returns it to the oil tank.
A diagram of an electric or fluid power system in which the components are represented by symbols, rather than drawings or pictures of the actual devices.
A spring-loaded service valve used in an air conditioning system.
A mathematical time saver used when working with very large and very small numbers.
The shape of the blades of the propellers mounted on an unducted-fan engine.
A name commonly used for landing gear torque links.
A scratch across a piece of material made to cause the material to break along the line.
A reverse-blocking triode thyristor that can be triggered into conduction in only one direction.
A special type of ramjet engine whose fuel can be ignited while the vehicle is moving at a supersonic speed.
The bottom ring on a piston of a reciprocating engine.
A condition of combustion instability in a gas turbine engine or afterburner.
A tool used when working with plastic resins, to spread the resin evenly over a surface and level it.
The grid in an electron tube between the control grid and the plate (anode).
A hand tool used to install or remove screws.
A set of thin metal blades with a series of V-shaped notches cut along one edge of each blade.
A sharp-pointed tool used to scribe (mark) lines on metal.
A commonly used term for small patches of low clouds that often form below a heavy overcast.
A severe type of damage to moving parts caused when one metal part moves across another without sufficient lubricant between them.
A recess around the filler neck of an aircraft fuel tank.
An open-bottom canvas bucket towed behind a boat or seaplane in the water.
A coastal breeze blowing from sea to land.
A type of advection fog that forms when air that has been lying over a warm land surface moves over a colder water surface.
The average level of the surface of the sea.
A component used to prevent fluid leading between two surfaces.
A heavy liquid or paste spread between two surfaces to form a seal.
A reciprocating aircraft engine having a rated takeoff power that is producible only at sea level..
The atmospheric pressure that exists at mean (average) sea level.
A reciprocating engine that has had its sea-level rated horsepower increased by supercharging.
A form of electrical resistance welding in which small metal wheels are used as the electrodes.
An airplane that can operate from water, rather than land.
Lumber that has been dried, in a kiln or in some other way, and has had its moisture content reduced to a specified low amount.
The trigonometric function of a right triangle which is the ratio of the length of the hypotenuse to the length of the side adjacent to an acute angle.
One-sixtieth part of a minute of angular measurement.
The basic unit of time in both the English and the metric systems of measurement.
A pilot who is designated to be second in command on an aircraft during flight time..
A condition in which something has a level of importance just below that which is most important.
Air which has passed through a gas turbine engine compressor and is used for cooling.
A battery which can be recharged after it has been discharged.
A color produced by combining two primary colors in equal proportions.
Controls that modify the effect of the ailerons, rudder, and elevators of an airplane, and do not in themselves cause rotation of the airplane about any of its three axes.
Current that flows in the secondary winding of a transformer.
Emission of electrons in an electron tube from an electrode other than the cathode.
The main flow of fuel from the fuel nozzles inside a gas turbine engine.
Radar which responds to pulses of energy transmitted from an interrogator.
A unit of length, weight, voltage, capacitance, time, or other value that is compared with a primary standard to determine its accuracy.
The voltage in an alternating current circuit produced across the secondary winding of a transformer.
The transformer winding connected to the electrical load.
The winding in a magneto or ignition coil that connects to the distributor rotor.
A lever in which the fulcrum is at one end, and the lifting force is at the other.
An aeronautical chart drawn to a scale of 1:500,000 (one inch is equal to eight statute miles).
A detail view in an aircraft drawing that shows the inside of a part.
The use of cross-hatching to indicate the type of material used in a sectional view of a part on an aircraft drawing.
A part of a circle bounded by two radii and the arc that lies between them.
A piece of a gear wheel that contains the hub and a portion of the rim with the teeth.
Meteorology visibility within a specified sector of the horizon circle.
Contaminants that settle to the bottom of a reservoir or container.
Another name for a semirigid rotor (helicopter).
The part of the circle formed by a chord (a line passing across the circle and touching the circumference at two points) and the arc between the two points.
A visual indicator around a wind sock or tetrahedron designed to show the traffic pattern for each runway.
A heavy-duty, multiple-disk brake used on large, high-speed aircraft.
A type of equipment failure in which parts stick or jam because of friction, pressure, or excessive temperature.
A method of electroplating only a portion of a metal part.
The ability of a radio receiver to separate the signals it receives.
A multi-pole switch used to connect a single conductor to any one of several other conductors.

A flow control valve used in hydraulic systems to direct pressurized fluid into one side of an actuator, and at the same time direct return fluid from the other side of the actuator back to the reservoir.
A steel-gray, highly toxic, nonmetallic chemical element Its symbol is Se, atomic number is 34, and atomic weight is 78.96.
A type of rectifier using a cadmium and selenium junction to control the flow of electrons.
A type of bearing used on a control rod end that functions properly, even though the control rod does not move at right angles to the surface to which it is attached.
A type of chuck used on a drill motor or lathe that has all its jaws connected in such a way that they move together.
The process in which the magnetic fields surrounding a piece of magnetized material try to demagnetize it.
An electrical generator whose field coils are supplied with current produced in the armature.

A combustible material is said to be self-extinguishing if it burns when it is exposed to a flame or to a high temperature, but the burning process automatically stops as soon as the flame or source of high temperature is removed.
An electrolytic capacitor with the ability to automatically restore the oxide film dielectric to the plate if the film is ever punctured by too high a voltage.
The characteristic of an electrical conductor that causes a counter electromotive force (CEMF, or back voltage) to be built up in it by alternating current flowing through it.
A type of nut with a built-in locking device that makes the nut tightly grip the threads of the bolt.
A type of screw with sharp threads that cut their own matching threads when screwed into soft metal, wood, or plastic.
The registered trade name for a DC synchro system.
The woven edge of fabric used to prevent the material unraveling during normal handling.
A prefix meaning partially or part (usually half) of something.
An operation that is partially automatic.
A material whose electrical conductivity is between that of an insulator and a conductor.
A two element, solid-state electron check valve made of silicon or germanium, doped with appropriate impurities.
A complex electronic circuit made on a single chip of semiconductor material.
A computer memory in which data is stored in semiconductor devices, such as flip-flop circuits and capacitors.
A piezoelectric crystal that converts input energy of one form, such as pressure, into output energy of another, such as an electrical signal.
A form of stressed skin structure used in the construction of aircraft.
A type of helicopter rotor that allows the pitch of the blades to be changed by rotating the blades about their feather axis (the axis that extends along the length of the blade).
The part of a fuel quantity measuring system located at the tank to measure the level of the fuel in the tank.
A type of nondirectional radio antenna used with an automatic direction finder.
Heat energy added to a material that causes it to change its temperature, but not its physical state.
A form of multipointer pneumatic altimeter with an adjustable barometric scale that allows the reference pressure to be set to any desired level.
An electromagnetically operated switch whose operating coil requires very little current to close the switch contacts.
A measure of the signal strength needed to produce distortion-free output.
A radar circuit designed to correct for range attenuation so the echo intensity on the scope is proportional to reflectivity of the target regardless of range.
The component in a piece of automated equipment affected by some physical condition.
The spacing of aircraft to achieve their safe and orderly movement in flight and while landing and taking off.
A type of flow control valve that allows one system to fully operate before another system begins its operation.
Digital memory devices that have several inputs and several outputs.
Data transfer by moving bits sequentially, one at a time, rather than simultaneously, as is done by parallel operation.

A type of circuit in either an electrical or a fluid power system in which all of the components are connected in such a way that they provide only one path from the source of current or fluid flow, through all of the components, and back to the source.
A resonant AC electrical circuit that contains a capacitor and an inductor connector in series.
A type of electrical circuit in which some of the components are connected in series, and others are connected in parallel.
A form of electrical generator in which the field coils are connected in series with the armature.
A commutator-type electric motor that has the field coils connected in series with the armature.
A bulletin issued by the manufacturer of an aircraft, engine, or component that describes a service procedure the manufacturer recommends to make the device safer or to improve its service life.
The highest altitude at which an aircraft can maintain a steady rate of climb of 100 feet per minute.
The length of time a piece of equipment can reasonably be expected to operate in a satisfactory manner.
A manual written by the manufacturer of an aircraft, engine, or component that describes the way the device should be serviced and maintained.
The condition of a piece of equipment that allows it to be returned to service or to be installed in an operating aircraft.
One type of limits included in a reciprocating engine overhaul manual.
A component in an automatic flight control system that actually moves the flight control.
A type of pneumatic altimeter in which the bellows moves an electrical pickup whose signal is amplified enough for it to drive a servo motor.
An electronic amplifier in an autopilot system that increases the signal from the autopilot enough that it can operate the servos that move the control surfaces.
A type of wheel brake that uses the momentum of the aircraft to increase the friction applied by the brake.
A type of automatic control system in which part of the output is fed back into the input to help control the action.
A type of control system in which a small signal or small force is used to control a much larger force.
A small movable tab built into the trailing edge of an aircraft primary control surface.

A type of carburetor or continuous-flow injection system that uses the pressure drop across a servo bleed orifice (a metering jet) to control the amount of metered fuel allowed to flow to the cylinders.
A biplane in which one wing, usually the lower wing, has an area less than one half the area of the other wing.
A measurement used in sheet metal layout.
A headless screw used to prevent relative movement between a wheel and a shaft.
An operation of a helicopter in which the main rotor is operating in its own downwash.
An approved plan to minimize the effect of severe weather on traffic flows in impacted terminal and/or ARTCC areas.
A repair to a fabric-covered airplane wing in which a section of fabric extending from the leading edge to the trailing edge between two or more ribs is replaced by sewing new fabric to the old.
An optical instrument used in celestial navigation to measure the angle between the horizon and a line to one of the navigational stars.
A type of tester used to determine the condition of the fabric installed on an aircraft.
A type of alternating current induction motor used for light-duty, constant-speed loads, such as fans, blowers, and tape players.
The horsepower actually available at a rotating shaft.
The amount the end of the crankshaft of an aircraft reciprocating engine is bent.
Longitudinal cracks in a piece of wood, usually between two annual rings.
The smooth part of the body of a twist drill that fits into the drill chuck.
An operation in which thin layers of metal are removed from the outer surface of the device being shaved.
To cut by causing the parts to slide over each other.
The failure of a riveted or bolted joint in which the fastener, rather than the material being joined, fails.
A thin nut used on a clevis bolt to hold the bolt in place.
A pin used to protect a piece of equipment by intentionally shearing if the equipment should seize.
A necked-down section of an engine-driven pump shaft designed to shear if the pump should seize.
The strength of a riveted joint in a sheet metal structure in which the rivets shear before the metal tears at the rivet holes.
A type of stress that tries to slide an object apart.
A type of cutting tool used to cut sheet metal, paper, or cloth.
A grooved wheel used as a pulley.
Metal that has been rolled into sheets whose thickness is less than 0.25 inch.
The drawing or pattern used to cut a piece of sheet metal.
The normal length of time an object or material can be expected to keep its usable characteristics if it is stored and not used.
The outer structure of an atom formed by electrons having the same energy level as they spin around the nucleus.
A type of electrical transformer encased in a steel shell.
Electromagnetic energy with a frequency between 3 and 30 gigahertz (3-109 and 30-109 hertz).
Insulated electrical wire enclosed in a conducting braid, usually made of tinned copper.
A type of ignition cable used to carry high voltage from the magneto distributor to the spark plug.
A spark plug entirely enclosed in a steel housing.
Electrical wire enclosed in a braided metal jacket.
A form of arc welding in which the arc and the metal being welded are shielded, or covered, with an inert gas or with melted flux that keeps air away from the molten metal in the weld.
A metal braid that encloses wires which carry high-frequency alternating current or high-voltage DC that has radio-frequency energy superimposed on it.
A thin piece of material used to fill a space between two objects or to level an object.
Abnormal, and often violent, vibration of the nose wheel of an airplane.
A small hydraulic shock absorber installed between the nose wheel fork and the nose wheel cylinder which is attached to the aircraft structure.
A device in an aircraft landing gear that absorbs the shock which occurs when an aircraft touches down on landing.
A type of vibration isolator used between a moving vehicle and a component sensitive to vibration.
A type of stall that affects some airplanes as they fly in the transonic speed range.
A device in an aircraft landing gear that absorbs the shock which occurs when an aircraft touches down on landing.
A pressure wave formed in the air as an object, such as a flight vehicle, passes through the air at a speed greater than the speed at which sound can travel.
The head of a solid rivet which is formed when the shank is upset.
A form of hardness tester used to determine the hardness of material such as rubber, metal, or plastic .
An electrical circuit in which there is a fault that causes electrons to flow across a portion of the circuit that should act as an insulator.
The exhaust system of an aircraft reciprocating engine made of short pipes that direct the exhaust gases from each individual cylinder of the engine away from the aircraft.
Waves of electromagnetic radiation that are shorter than 60 meters, or about 197 feet.
A method of strengthening the surface of a metal part by blasting it with steel shot.
A special type of fastener used to prevent damage to a structure that could be caused by squeezing the surfaces together when the nut is tightened on the bolt.
A monoplane in which the wing is mounted near the top of the fuselage, but not on the top.
A term meaning to demonstrate, confirm, validate, or substantiate something.
The registered trade name for a type of magneto ignition system.
Shower Of Sparks Ignition System (Aircraft Reciprocating Engine)
A type of finish put on some aircraft that are built for show.
An interference fit between pieces of an assembly.
