A pair of wooden blocks used to clamp a sheet of metal to keep it from buckling when it is hammered with a mallet to shrink it.
A method used to protect products from damage while they are being displayed for sale.
A sheet-metal cover placed over an air-cooled engine to pick up and force cooling air through the cylinder fins to remove heat from the engine.
A type of turbine blade with a T-shaped tip.
A precision resistor installed to parallel with a voltage measuring instrument to measure the amount of current flowing in a circuit.
A parallel circuit, or a circuit to which there are more than one path for electrons to flow.
A type of ohmmeter used for measuring very low values of resistance.
Field coils in an electric motor or generator that are connected in parallel with the armature.
A commutator-type electric motor in which the field windings are connected in shunt (parallel) with the armature.
A valve used in a fluid power system to shut off the flow of fluid.
A type of automatic selector valve installed in a critical portion of a fluid power system.
The universal abbreviation for the International System of Units.
Aeronautical charts designed to expedite clearance delivery and facilitate transition between takeoff and enroute operations.
A flight maneuver in which the airplane is banked while the rudder keeps it on a straight heading.
The bands of frequencies on either side of the carrier frequency in amplitude modulated (AM) radio transmission.

A visual maneuver accomplished by a pilot at the completion of an instrument approach to permit a straight-in landing on a parallel runway not more than 1,200 feet to either side of the runway to which the instrument approach was conducted.
A cockpit flight control used on some of the fly-by-wire equipped airplanes.
The audio-frequency signal fed back from the microphone of a radio transmitter into the earphones connected to the radio receiver.
A small window in the high side of a vapor-cycle cooling system.
A transparent tube on the outside of a reservoir or tank connected to the bottom of the container.
A line, drawn on a sheet-metal layout, one bend radius from the bend tangent line.
A weather advisory issued concerning weather significant to the safety of all aircraft.
A piece of electronic test equipment that produces an electrical signal having a specified voltage, frequency, and waveform.
A piece of electronic test equipment used to trace a signal through each stage of a piece of electronic equipment.
A meter connected into the automatic volume control (AVC) circuit in a radio receiver.
The digits of a decimal number, beginning at the first nonzero digit and extending to the right to include all of the digits needed to give the required accuracy.
A weather advisory issued concerning weather significant to the safety of all aircraft.
Silicon dioxide (SiO2) as it occurs in nature.
A form of extremely porous silica used as a desiccant.
A dark brown, tetravalent (having four valence electrons), nonmetallic crystalline chemical element. Its symbol is Si, atomic number of 14, atomic weight is 28.086.
An abrasive that is often ground into small particles and bonded to sheets of paper or cloth or formed into grinding wheels for use on power grinders.
A form of contamination on aircraft spark plugs that can lead to engine failure.
A special type of semiconductor device made of P-type silicon doped with boron and N-type silicon doped with arsenic.
An alloy steel that contains between 0.5% and 4.5% silicon.
A group of semi-inorganic polymers that have good thermal stability, are chemically inert, water repellent, and are good lubricants .
An elastomeric material made from silicone elastomers.
A lustrous white, ductile, malleable, metallic chemical element. Its symbol of Ag, atomic number is 47, and atomic weight is 107.870.
A form of brazing in which the filler metal is a silver-base alloy.
An alloy of copper, silver, and zinc.
A high-voltage capacitor that uses thin sheets of mica as the dielectric.
A type of wing flap installed on some of the smaller airplanes.
A mathematical fraction with whole numbers for both its numerator and its denominator.
Any of the basic, or elementary, mechanical devices from which all machines are built.
Motion along a straight line, a circular path, or a helix.
A method of communications in which one station transmits while the other receives, then the second station transmits and the first receives.
A type of fuel nozzle in a gas turbine engine in which all of the fuel is fed to the nozzle through a single fuel manifold.
To copy something or to make something that represents or acts like something.
A device used for training or research that duplicates a piece of complex equipment.
The sine of an angle is the ratio of the length of the side of a right triangle opposite the angle, to the length of the hypotenuse (the side opposite the right angle).

The waveform of a periodically reversing vibration produced by a rotating machine in which the instantaneous values of the wave are the peak value multiplied by the sine of the angle through which the rotating element has turned.
Alternating current whose waveform is that produced by a rotary generator.
A flare made on a piece of rigid tubing in which there is only one thickness of the tubing material in the flare.
A method of adhesive application in which the adhesive is spread on only one of the two surfaces being joined.
A type of actuator in a fluid power system that uses fluid under pressure to move it in one direction, but a spring to return it.
A hand-operated fluid pump that moves fluid only during one stroke of the pump handle.
A simple automatic flight control system that controls the airplane only about its longitudinal, or roll, axis.
A file that has a single row of teeth extending across its face at an angle of between 65o and 85o to the length of the file.
An aircraft brake in which a single steel disk rotates with the wheel and rides between two or more pads, or linings.
The repair to a piece of laminated structural material in which the damage extends through only one face of the material and partly into the core.
A method of attaching the fabric to the wing of an airplane in which only one loop of rib-stitching cord passes around the rib in each stitch.
A method of filling multiple fuel tanks in large aircraft from a single fueling point.
A method of grounding an electrical circuit by connecting all of the wires that go to ground to a single point on the equipment chassis.
A type of brake installed on some aircraft that uses the momentum of the rotating wheel to wedge the brake shoe tightly against the brake drum when the aircraft is moving in a forward direction .
A turboprop engine in which the propeller reduction gears are driven by the same shaft which drives the compressor for the gas generator.
A joint in which the two sheets of metal are riveted together.
A type of radio transmission in which only one of the sidebands of the signal is transmitted.
A gas turbine engine that has only one rotating mass.
An electrical switch that has only two conditions, ON or OFF.
A type of molded metal in which powdered metal is heated but not quite melted and then squeezed together.

The waveform of a periodically reversing vibration produced by a rotating machine in which the instantaneous values of the wave are the peak value multiplied by the sine of the angle through which the rotating element has turned.
A device used to move a liquid from a container, over an edge higher than the level of the liquid, down to a lower level.
A tall, straight spruce tree that grows on the northern Pacific coast of North America.
A filler put into some types of fabric or paper to fill the pores and make the material smooth and stiff.
A rough drawing made to illustrate a part or principle.
An airplane whose wheeled landing gear has been replaced with skis so it can operate from snow or ice.
A flight maneuver in which the aircraft is turned without using a steep enough angle of bank.
A type of flush antenna (an antenna even with the surface of the aircraft skin).
The cause of the unequal distribution of radio-frequency alternating current throughout a conductor.
A type of aerodynamic drag caused by air flowing over the surface of the aircraft.
A type of radiator used on some of the liquid-cooled racing airplanes.
The distance from a radio transmitting antenna to the point on the surface of the earth the reflected sky wave first touches after it has been bounced off the ionosphere.
A method of welding thin material.
A small, conical, streamlined cover retained by a bracket attached to the hub of a fixed-pitch wood or metal propeller.
A section of an aircraft factory set aside for research and development of new aircraft.
The portion of an electromagnetic signal that radiates upward from the antenna until it strikes the ionosphere, then bounces back to earth.
The registered trade name of a synthetic hydraulic fluid used in most modern high-performance aircraft.
The hard, brittle, glass-like material that covers a weld bead that has been made with a coated welding rod.
Improper operation of the power control lever of a gas turbine engine in which the control is moved forward too quickly to allow the engine to accelerate as it should.
The actual distance between a ground-based radar antenna and an airborne target.
The distance an airborne observer can see and distinguish objects on the ground.
The actual distance between an aircraft and a ground radio facility.
A radar beacon reply displayed on a radar scope as an elongated target.
A secondary control on an airplane that allows the airplane to fly at a high angle of attack without stalling.
A gyro-stabilized direction indicator whose directional signals are produced by a flux valve.
A mechanical calculating device consisting of two side-by-side logarithmically graduated scales.
A type of electrical switch in which connections are made by sliding a conductor over fixed contacts.
A valve that opens or closes a port by sliding back and forth over it.
A form of variable resistor in which the amount of resistance used in a circuit is determined by the position of a contact along a length of resistance wire.
An instrument used to measure the relative humidity of the air.
A hollow metal ring mounted around the hub of a propeller so that it turns with it.
A maneuver in which the aircraft moves through the air side-ways, rather than straight ahead.
The difference between the synchronous speed of an induction motor (the speed of the rotating magnetic field in the stator) and the actual speed the rotor is turning.
Slip, with regard to an aircraft propeller, is the difference between the geometric pitch and the effective pitch.
A heavy spring-loaded mechanism built into an aircraft reciprocating engine starter that allows the starter drive to slip enough to take up the initial shock when the starter is engaged.
A type of connection used in the exhaust system of a reciprocating engine that provides for the expansion of the system components as they get hot.
Smooth, continuous rings of brass or copper mounted on the rotor shaft of an electrical generator or alternator.
A small painted between a wheel and a tube-type tire.
A type of sheet-metal shop tool used to form large-radius curves in sheets of metal.
A commonly used term for a slide rule.
The strong flow of air moved rearward by an airplane propeller.
For the purpose of rib stitch spacing, the slipstream area is considered to be the diameter of the propeller plus one wing rib on each side.
A rubbery sealant used to line the inside of built-up metal fuel tanks.
A fixed, nozzle-like opening near the leading edge of an airplane wing, ahead of the aileron.
A type of trailing-edge flap that forms a slot between its leading edge and the inside of the flap well in the wing.
A regular hexagon nut with slots cut across its top.
A screw having a single, straight slot cut across its head for the blade of a screwdriver to fit.
To taxi a float plane at low power or low RPM.
A special type of fuse that allows a large flow of current for a short period of time, but opens the circuit if current in excess of rating, flows for a longer period.
A heavy contaminant that forms in an aircraft engine lubricating oil because of oxidation and chemical decomposition of the oil.
Spool-shaped, sheet-metal plugs installed inside hollow crankshaft throws.
A small cylinder of either powdered iron or copper, placed in the center of a radio-frequency (RF) coil to vary its inductance.
A heavy ring of copper or other metal placed over a relay coil.
The unit of mass equal to that which experiences an acceleration of one foot per second when a force of one pound acts on it.
Aircraft of 12,500 pounds or less, maximum certificated take-off weight..
An integrated circuit chip that contains up to nine gates or gate-equivalent circuits.
A combination of smoke and haze similar to smog (smoke and fog) except it does not contain as much moisture.
A small curved dent in the sheet metal around a rivet head.
A mixture of smoke and fog.
Restriction to visibility caused by small particles of carbonaceous material suspended in the air.
A device that warns the flight crew of the presence of smoke in cargo and/or baggage compartments.
An electronic filter, usually made of capacitors and inductors.
A long, flexible extension with a round shank on one end and a drill chuck on the other.
A small, spring-steel ring that can be fitted into a groove in a shaft or in a groove cut into the walls of a hole.
An abrupt maneuver of an airplane in which the airplane does a single turn of a spin while flying in a horizontal direction.
A type of electrical switch whose contacts are mounted on a spring and held pressed together by the operating handle.
Hand-operated shears used for cutting sheet metal.
A type of precipitation that forms in the air when water vapor changes directly into crystals of ice.
A popular term for snow shower, particularly of very light and brief nature.
Precipitation of very small, white, opaque grains of ice, similar in structure to snow crystals.
Precipitation consisting of white, opaque ice particles that are approximately round or sometimes conical.
A component in a hydraulic or pneumatic actuator that slows the motion of the actuator piston.
A resistor fitting installed between an oil pressure gage and the pressure pump.
The procedure in which metal being heat-treated is held in an oven at an elevated temperature until it is heated uniformly throughout.
A material used for cleaning or as an emulsifier.
An oil analysis program in which a sample of oil is burned in an electric arc and an examination is made of the wavelength composition of the resulting light.
A type of test used to check for leaks in almost any kind of system in which a gas is held under pressure.
A soft, grayish-white stone composed of talc and chlorite, a mineral similar to mica.
A type of flight in which the aircraft, usually a glider or sailplane.
A type of wrench used to turn a nut or bolt.
A bolt with a socket, usually hexagon-shaped, formed in its head.
A soft, light, malleable, ductile, silvery-white, metallic chemical element that has a waxy feel. Sodium's symbol is Na, atomic number is 11, and atomic weight is 22.9898.
A white, powdery salt of sodium.
A hollow exhaust valve that is partially filled with metallic sodium.
A type of lamp used for outdoor lighting, especially along highways.
Ferromagnetic material that is easy to magnetize and demagnetize.
An alloy of tin and lead that melts at a temperature of less than 800oF (427oC).
A vacuum tube that is faulty because air has leaked into the tube envelope.
Low-powered X-rays that have comparatively long wavelengths.
A hammer whose head has one or more soft faces made of plastic, rubber, rawhide, or a soft metal such as lead or aluminum.
The package of instructions or programs used to control a computer.
A material used as a base for roads and airport runways.
A silicon semiconductor device that converts light energy directly into electrical energy.
Electromagnetic radiation emitted by the sun.
An alloy of tin and lead that melts at a temperature of less than 800oF (427oC).
A type of splice used for electrical wires in which the ends of the wires to be joined are twisted together to give them mechanical strength.
A method of thermally joined metal parts with a molten nonferrous alloy that melts at a temperature below 800oF (427oC).
A hand held tool used to melt solder.
A special type of hand-held tool used to melt solder.
A crimped-on connector used to fasten a terminal to an electrical wire.
An electromagnet with a movable iron core that can be pulled into the coil.
A material whose internal structure holds it tightly in its original shape and size.
An electrical conductor made of a single piece of material, usually wire.
Rocket fuel made of a mixture of solid materials that, when ignited, combine fast enough to produce a great amount of heat.
A uniform combination of the alloying elements in a base metal.
The ratio of the total blade area to the disk area.
An electronic component that controls the flow of electrons without the use of any heated filaments, vacuum spaces, or moving parts.
Flight of an aircraft when there is only one person in the aircraft.
The condition of a substance that can be dissolved in, or can form a solution with, another substance.
A homogeneous mixture (a mixture that is the same all the way through) of one or more materials dissolved in another.
A type of heat treatment in which the metal is heated in a furnace until its temperature is uniform throughout.
A liquid able to dissolve certain types of solids.
An electronic detection system used for locating objects in water.
A loud, explosive noise heard on the ground when an airplane passes overhead at a speed faster than the speed of sound.
A method of cleaning delicate mechanical parts.
Frequencies of mechanical vibrations that can be heard by the human ear.
A method of soldering metals, such as aluminum, that are normally difficult to solder because of the speed with which surface oxides build up.
A venturi is a line between a turbine engine compressor or turbocharger and the pressurization system of an aircraft.
A black residue left when a hydrocarbon material is burned in an atmosphere in which there is not enough oxygen for complete combustion.
The airframe component that replaces the turbine engine tail pipe.
Longitudinal pressure waves within an elastic medium, such as air, water, or a solid material, that has been disturbed.
An extensive area of the earth's surface characterized by relatively uniform surface conditions.
The location of the southern spin axes of the earth.
The location near, but not at, the south geographic pole, at which the magnetic lines of flux of the earth's magnetic field enter.
The pole of a magnet at which lines of magnetic flux are considered to enter after leaving the magnet at its north pole.
The negative charge in an electron tube between the cathode and the plate.
A manned vehicle launched by a rocket, usually a two-stage rocket, and carried to an altitude at which It can orbit the earth.
The portionof an electromagnetic signal that is capable of traveling through the ionosphere.
Components used to fill a space between two objects.
A special drill used for cutting holes in graphic structural materials.
The commonly used name for a type of insulating tubing slipped over the end of an electrical wire.
A type of damage in which chips are broken from the surface of a case-hardened material such as a bearing race.
An aerodynamic measurement found by dividing the span of an airfoil by the total weight the airfoil supports.
The length of an airfoil measured between its tips.
The name generally used by the British for a wrench.
A special type of round nut with holes, notches, or projections around its periphery.
The main spanwise, load-carrying structural member in an airplane wing.
A hard, durable finish for wood that is to be kept outdoors where it is exposed to the weather.
An electrical discharge between two electrodes or points within a circuit having a difference of electrical potential.
A step-up transformer used to produce a high voltage.
A device in the ignition system of a reciprocating engine that produces the spark which ignites the fuel-air mixture inside the cylinder.
A threaded bronze or steel busing screwed and shrunk into an opening in the cast aluminum cylinder head of an aircraft engine.
A resistor installed in a shielded spark plug between the ignition lead terminal and the center electrode.
A device placed across a set of electrical contacts to suppress the spark that forms when the contacts open.
A quick test to identify types of ferrous metal.
A form of reciprocating engine in which the fuel-air mixture inside the cylinder is ignited by an electric spark.
A tool that looks much like a knife, but has no cutting edge.
A small coil that rides inside an air gap in a permanent magnet or electro-magnet inside a radio speaker.
A condition of air piracy or other hostile act by a person or persons aboard an aircraft which threatens the safety of the aircraft or its passengers.
Meteorological conditions that are less than those required for basic VFR flight in controlled airspace and in which some aircraft are permitted flight under visual flight rules..
Aircraft operating in accordance with clearances within controlled airspace in meteorological conditions less than the basic VFR weather minima..
A measure of the amount of fuel burned in a heat engine to produce a given amount of power.
The ratio of the density of a material to the density of pure water.

The ratio of the amount of heat energy needed to raise the temperature of a specific mass of material one degree Celsius, to the amount of heat energy needed to raise the temperature of the same mass of pure water one oC.
The ration, by weight, of the water vapor in a sample of air to the combined weight of the water vapor and the dry air.
The ratio of the weight of an aircraft engine to the brake horsepower it produces.
An oil analysis program in which a sample of oil is burned in an electric arc and an examination is made of the wavelength composition of the resulting light.
A security device used with a radio transmitter to make voice transmissions unintelligible to anyone not having the correct descrambling equipment and the correct code for the day.
A type of secondary control on an airplane, a control which does not rotate the aircraft about any of its three axes.
The speed at which light travels in a vacuum.
The speed at which the mechanical vibrations of sound travel in an elastic medium.
Portions of the arrival route between the transition point and the vertex along the optimum flight path for which speeds and altitudes are specified .
A gas turbine engine whose rated thrust is produced at a specified RPM.
A solid with a curved surface, like a ball.
The high-strength steel component in an airplane propeller that attaches to the propeller shaft of the engine and supports the propeller blades.
A transient condition in an electrical circuit in which a pulse of electrical energy with a high voltage and short duration appears in the circuit.
A knot that runs through the depth of a wood beam, perpendicular to the annual rings.
A maneuver of an airplane in which one wing is stalled while the other wing continues to produce lift.
A streamlined housing over the hub of the propeller.
A maneuver in which an airplane descends in a steeply banked, turning flight path.
An instrument used to determine whether or not something is level, or perpendicular to a line that points directly toward the center of the earth.
A finishing material for wood made of a resin dissolved in a volatile solvent such as alcohol.
A type of patch made in an aircraft plywood structure in which the edges of the patch are tapered for approximately five times the thickness of the plywood.
A solderless, crimped-on connector used to join two wire ends.
A special knot used to join two pieces of waxed rib-stitching cord.
A propeller shaft with splines along its periphery that fit into mating splines in the steel propeller hub.
A method of locking a shaft into a wheel or disk.
A longitudinal crack in a piece of wood caused by externally induced stress.

A type of electrical bus that allows all of the voltage-sensitive avionic equipment to be isolated from the rest of the aircraft electrical system when the engine Is being started or when the ground-power unit is connected.
A type of wing flaps in which a part of the under side of the wing or the trailing edge of the wing splits and folds down to increase the curvature (camber) of he bottom of the wing.
A heavy spring-steel washer split at an angle across its face and twisted.
The indication on a helicopter tachometer that shows the rotor clutch is not fully engaged.
A reversible DC electric motor that has two separate field windings; one for clockwise rotation and the other for counterclockwise rotation.
A type of alternating current motor that has a main and an auxiliary winding connected in parallel.
An electrical switch whose operating control is a rocker, split so one half of the switch can be opened without affecting the other half.
A small deflector that can be raised into the air flowing over an airfoil.
A short drawknife with handles on each end.
The feel of the brake pedal when the hydraulic brake fluid contains air.
A surface much like a short stub wing that extends out on the side of a flying boat hull near the waterline.
Self-ignition of a material caused by heat produced in the material as it combines with oxygen from the air.
A method of manufacturing inspection in which only a certain percentage of the products are checked.
A form of electrical resistance welding used for thin sheets of metal.
A smooth, flat, circular area around a bolt hole that provides a good seat for the bolt head or for a washer under the bolt head.
A lighting device that produces a brilliant, concentrated beam of light.
A pipe or similar device used to carry a liquid from a container in a stream that is easy to control.
A form of freewheeling clutch used in the rotor-drive system of a helicopter.
A type of maintenance tool used for cleaning parts.
A device that breaks a liquid finishing material, such as paint or lacquer, into tiny drops and blows them onto the surface being painted.
Small strips of metal mounted on the side of a flying boat hull.
Horizontal structural members between the two floats mounted on an aircraft.

High-carbon steel, a steel containing more than 0.5% carbon, that has been hardened and tempered to give it the maximum amount of elasticity, or the ability to return to its original shape after it has been deflected.
A small auxiliary tab, set into the trailing edge of a primary control surface on a high-speed airplane.
A method used to assure that the control arm of a device being controlled actually reaches its full-travel stop.
Springback, in sheet metal forming, is the tendency of metal to spring back and form an angle less than the angle bent in a brake or forming block.
The lighter, softer part of the grain of wood.
A hole in a mold through which liquid plastic or molten metal is poured to fill the mold.
A type of reduction gear system that allows one shaft to turn at a speed slower than that of another shaft.
Spur And Pinion Reduction Gear System
A gear wheel with teeth radiating outward around its periphery.
A form of constant-displacement fluid pump that used two meshing spur gears mounted in a close-fitting housing.
A sudden increase in wind speed by at least 15 knots to peak of 20 knots or more, and lasting for at least one minute.
Any nonfrontal line or narrow band of active thunderstorms with or without squalls.
A reciprocating engine whose bore and stroke have the same dimensions.
A unit of area possessed by a square having sides of one mil, or one thousandth of an inch (0.001) inch.
The product of a number multiplied by itself.
A number, which, when multiplied by itself, will give a particular number.
The waveform produced by pulsating direct current in which the voltage alternates between zero and its maximum value.
An electronic device that produces alternating current with a square waveform.
A large shear used to make straight cuts across a sheet of metal.
A switch mounted on the shock strut of an aircraft landing gear.
An axial-flow compressor blade whose tip thickness is reduced to give It a higher resonant frequency so it will not be subject to the vibrations that would affect a blade with a squared tip.
A rubber scraper blade mounted on a handle in such a way that the blade forms a T with the handle.
A bottle made of a soft plastic material.
A power riveting tool used to install solid aluminum alloy rivets in a sheet metal structure.
A circuit in a radio receiver that keeps the volume down when no signal is being received.
A small explosive charge that drives a cutter through the seal in a high-rate discharge (HRD) bottle of fire extinguishing agent.
A type of AC motor whose rotor has current induced into it from stationary field coils.
A maintenance manual issued by a manufacturer and approved by the FAA that describes, in detail, specific repairs that are approved for a particular aircraft structure.
A single-piece horizontal tail surface on an airplane which serves the purposes of both the horizontal stabilizer and the elevators.
The characteristic of an aircraft that causes it to return to its original attitude after it a been disturbed from this condition.
A state of the atmosphere in which the vertical distribution of temperature is such that a parcel of air will resist displacement from its initial level.
The fixed horizontal tail surface on an airplane.
Small wing-like horizontal surfaces mounted on the aft fuselage of some airplanes to improve longitudinal stability.
An isotope of an element that does not undergo radioactive disintegration.
The distance between landing points in airline operation.
One disk of rotor blades and the following set of stator vanes in an axial-flow compressor.
The relationship between the longitudinal location of the two wings of a biplane.
High-strength steel wires that connect diagonally fore and aft across the cabane struts of a biplane.
A method of timing the dual ignition of a reciprocating engine.
A location on a body in a stream of moving fluid at which the fluid has stopped - it has no velocity.
A form of nonproductive finish used on wood to color the wood without hiding the grain.
An alloy of iron, chromium, and nickel that is resistant to rust and corrosion.
A method of securing a part in a recess in a metal surface.
An aerodynamic condition in which the angle of attack, the angle at which the relative wind strikes the airfoil, becomes so steep the air can no longer flow smoothly over the airfoil.
A small triangular metal strip installed along the leading edge of an airplane wing near the root.
A system that warns the pilot when the angle of attack of the wing reaches a point that will likely produce a stall.
The amount of torque produced by the rotor of an electric motor when it is fully energized with the correct voltage, but the rotor is held so it cannot turn.
The atmosphere defined in the U.S. Standard Atmosphere, 1962 (Geopotential altitude tables..
Conditions of the atmosphere that have been agreed upon by scientists and engineers who work with the atmosphere to allow them to correct all measurements to the same conditions.
A cadmium-mercury cell made in a specially shaped glass container in which the two electrodes are covered with an electrolyte of cadmium sulfate.
Conditions that have been decided upon by the iCAO (International Civil Aeronautics Organization) for relating all aircraft and engine performance to a given reference.
A preplanned instrument flight rule (IFR) air traffic control arrival procedure published for pilot use in graphic and/or textual form.
Values used when specific weights are not available.
A highly accurate radio-frequency signal broadcast from the National Bureau of Standards radio station, station WWV.
A turn in which an aircraft changes its direction at a rate of 3o per second (360o in two minutes) for low- or medium-speed aircraft.
A wave in the atmosphere that remains stationary in a moving fluid.
Stationary voltage waves existing on an antenna or transmission line that are caused by two waves, identical in amplitude and frequency, but traveling in opposite directions along the conductor.
A pipe protruding upward from the bottom of a tank, or reservoir, that allows part of the tank to be used as a reserve, or standby, source of fluid.
A U-shaped wire loop with sharp points on both ends.
The average length of the fibers of a textile material.
A tool for driving staples through a piece of wood or a stack of paper.
A preplanned instrument flight rule (IFR) air traffic control arrival procedure published for pilot use in graphic and/or textual form.
Aeronautical charts designed to expedite air traffic control route procedures and to facilitate transition between enroute and instrument approach procedures.
The right side of an aircraft or ship as viewed looking forward.
An auxiliary winding in parallel with the run winding in the stator of a single-phase inducting motor.
A device used with either a gas turbine engine or a reciprocating engine that can be coupled to the engine to turn it over fast enough for it to start and run normally.
A combination electrical component installed on some small gas turbine engines.
The amount of torque produced by an electric motor when the rotor first begins to turn.
The condition of a storage battery with regard to the amount of charge in it.
A condition of balance of an aircraft control surface in which the surface balances about its hinge line.
The electrical charge on a body caused by an accumulation of electrons on one part of the body and a deficiency of electrons on another part.
A device attached to an aircraft control surface to discharge static electricity into the air.
Electrical pressure produced by an excess of electrons (a negative charge) or a deficiency of electrons (a positive charge).
A small hole, or port, in the skin of an aircraft at a location where the airflow is not disturbed.
The location on the surface of an aircraft where the static air pressure used in the altimeter, airspeed indicator, and the vertical speed indicator is picked up.
The pressure of a fluid that is still, or not moving, measured perpendicular to the surface exposed to the fluid.
A type of reciprocating engine in which the cylinders are arranged radially around a small crankcase.
The number of revolutions per minute an aircraft engine can produce when the aircraft is not moving.
The characteristic of an aircraft that causes it to try to return to straight and level flight after it has been disturbed from this condition.
A type of test given to such mechanisms as airplane structures.
The amount of thrust produced by a gas turbine engine when the engine is not moving through the air.
A device used to bleed an accumulated static electrical charge off an aircraft control surface and discharge it into the air.
A location on an aircraft identified by a number designating its distance in inches from the datum.
The actual barometric (atmospheric) pressure measured at the observing station.
The part of an electric motor or generator that produces the stationary, or nonmoving, electromagnetic field.
The stationary portion of an axial-flow compressor in a gas turbine engine.
A unit of linear measurement in the English system.
A structural member in a truss that is located in tension only.
An approval issued by the FAA for a modification to a type-certificated airframe, engine, or component.
The condition of an electrical circuit that exists when all of the circuit values are constant.
Water that has been changed into its vapor state by heating it.
A method of liquid cooling a reciprocating engine in which the coolant, normally water, is allowed to absorbed enough heat that it boils, or changes into steam.
Fog formed when cold air moves over relatively warm or wet ground.
A ceramic insulating material used in making insulators for high-voltage, high-frequency radio transmitters.
An alloy of iron that usually contains between 0.1% and 1.5% carbon with other elements.
A mat of fine threads of steel.
A nonferrous alloy of cobalt, chromium, and tungsten.
A break in the bottom of the hull of a flying boat or seaplane float.
A type of stud used to replace a stud that has stripped the threads in a cast housing.
To taxi a float plane at full power or high RPM.
A maneuver used to put a float plane in a planing configuration prior to entering an active sea lane for takeoff.
A type of electrical transformer with more turns in the primary winding than in the secondary.
Solvents in a finishing material that have different rates of evaporation.
A precision electric motor whose output shaft position is changed in steps by pulses from the control device.
A type of relay-operated multipole electrical switch.
A type of electrical transformer with more turns in the secondary winding than in the primary.
A piece of formed sheet metal or extrusion riveter to a larger piece of thin sheet metal to give it rigidity and stiffness.
A petroleum product, similar to naphtha, used as a solvent and a cleaning fluid.
The ratio of the mixture of fuel and air that, when burned in a heat engine, leaves no uncombined oxygen nor free carbon.
STOL performance of an aircraft is the ability of the aircraft to take off and clear a 50-foot obstruction in a distance of 1,500 feet from the beginning of the takeoff run.
A sheet metal cutting tool used to cut the chamfered holes into which flush rivets heads fit.
A method of stopping the growth of a crack in a piece of metal by drilling a small hole at the end of the crack.
A flight plan format which permits in a single submission, the filing of a sequence of flight plans through interim full-stop destinations to a final destination.

An area beyond the takeoff runway, no less wide than the runway and centered upon the extended centerline of the runway, able to support the airplane during an aborted takeoff, without causing structural damage to the airplane, and designated by the airport authorities for use in decelerating the airplane during an aborted takeoff..
A battery composed of several secondary electrical cells.
A weather radar designed to detect hydrometeors of precipitation size.
The registered trade name of an instrument that detects severe weather conditions by measuring the amount and intensity of static electrical discharges within the storm.
STOVL performance of an aircraft is the ability of the aircraft to take off and clear a 50-foot obstruction in a distance of 1,500 feet from the beginning of the takeoff run.
A bar, or a piece of metal, wood, or plastic, used to check another piece of material or surface for straightness, or used to draw straight lines.
An instrument approach in which the final approach is begun without first executing a procedure turn.
An entry into an airport traffic pattern by intercepting the extended runway center line without executing any other portion of the traffic pattern.
A type of hand-held hammer used for forming sheet metal.
DC electric arc welding in which the electrode is negative with respect to the work.
Gasoline refined from crude oil without the addition of any of the additives used in some of the other methods of refining.
A combustor in a gas turbine engine through which the air from the compressor to the turbine flows in an essentially straight line.
A deformation, or physical change, in a material caused by a stress.
A device attached to the surface of a piece of equipment to measure the amount of strain acting on the surface.
A method of hardening metals that cannot be hardened by heat treatment.
An electrical conductor made up of a number of small wires.
Clouds that form in stable air and appear to be in layers.
Low clouds that are predominantly stratiform in nature.
The upper part of earth's atmosphere.
A low, gray cloud layer or sheet with a fairly uniform base.
The flow of a fluid in which there is no turbulence.
A body whose shape is such that fluid moving over it flows in smooth lines with no turbulence .
The ability of a material to resist distortion or deformation caused by an external force acting on it.
A force within an object that tries to prevent any outside force changing its shape.
A form of intergranular corrosion that forms in metals that are subject to a continuous tensile stress.
A type of heat treatment of steel.
A location on a structure where the cross-sectional area of the part changes drastically.
A type of aircraft structure that has a minimum of internal structure and carries all, or most, of the stresses in its outside skin.
A part of an aircraft fuselage structure used to give the fuselage its shape and, in some types structure, provides a small portion of the fuselage strength.
A special light that flashes with a brilliant, short-duration flash.
A device used to measure rotational speed by the use of a stroboscopic light.
The linear distance the piston moves inside the cylinder from the top to the bottom.
A soft, silvery, easily oxidized, metallic chemical element. Its symbol is Sr, its atomic number 38, and atomic weight is 87.62.
A threaded fastener used to attach components to an engine crankcase or other type of casting.
A box through which a sliding or rotating shaft passes.
The registered trade name for an expanded (full of bubbles), rigid polystyrene plastic material.
An assembly of components that is part of a larger device.
Temperatures lower than that needed to cause water to freeze.
The procedure in which a solid material changes directly into a vapor or a vapor changes into a solid without becoming a liquid in the process.
A form of electric arc welding in which a bare rod is used as the electrode.
Less than normal bending of a radar beam, resulting from abnormal vertical gradients of temperature and/or water vapor..
A number or letter written to the right of, and partially below, an abbreviation or a number.
A descending motion of the air in the atmosphere over a rather broad area.
Flight of an aircraft in which all the air passing over the aircraft structure is moving at a speed slower than the speed of sound.
The quality of an object that is less than be considered normal or acceptable.
To use one material or object to take the place of something else.
The wafer of a semiconductor material on which the components of integrated circuits are diffused and deposited.
A small system inside a larger system.
The mathematical process in which the value of one number is taken from the value of another.
The number in a subtraction problem that is to be subtracted.
A term commonly used for a negative pressure, or a pressure below atmospheric pressure.
A component that holds a constant and steady suction, a pressure lower than that of the atmosphere, on a system.
A condition likely to cause internal damage to an aircraft engine.
A condition in a lead-acid storage battery in which both the positive and negative plates are covered with a hard deposit of lead sulfate.
A pale yellow, nonmetallic chemical element. It's symbol is S, atomic number of 16, and has an atomic weight of 32.064.
The answer to an addition problem when two or more numbers are added together.

The principle which states that the sky cover assigned to a layer is equal to the summation of the cover of the lowest layer, plus the additional coverage at all successively higher layers, up to and including the layer in question.
The less porous, usually harder portion of an annual ring that forms in a tree during the latter part of the growing season, the summer of the year.
A low point in an aircraft engine in which lubricating oil collects and is stored or transferred to an external oil tank.
A low point in an aircraft fuel tank in which water and other contaminants collect and are held until they can be drained out.
A small jar located in the vent line of an aircraft battery box.
A lapse rate greater than the dry adiabatic lapse rate, greater than 3oF per thousand feet.
A reciprocating engine that uses an air compressor to increase the pressure of the air before it enters the engine cylinders.
An air pump used to increase the pressure of the air before it enters the cylinders of a reciprocating engine.
A condition of certain chemical elements (niobium, tantalum, vanadium, tin, and others) when they are held at a temperature near absolute zero.
Water in its liquid form at a temperature well below its natural freezing temperature.
An airfoil section that allows an airplane to cruise efficiently at a speed very near Mach one (the speed of sound).
Heat energy added to a refrigerant after it changes from its liquid state into a vapor.
Water that has been heated to a temperature above that at which it normally changes its state from liquid into steam.
The type of circuit used in most modern radio receivers.
Electromagnetic radiation whose frequency is between 3.0 and 30.0 gigahertz.
More than normal bending of a radar beam resulting from abnormal vertical gradients of temperature and/or water vapor.
A solution in which a solid is dissolved in a liquid until the liquid will hold no more.
To replace, or to take the place of, something.
The branch of aerodynamics that deals with flight at a speed greater than the speed of sound.
Flight at an airspeed in which all air flowing over the aircraft is moving at a speed greater than the speed of sound.
The framework of formers and stringers attached to the main truss of a truss-type aircraft fuselage.
One hundred and eighty degrees minus the angle.
Any two angles whose sum is 180o.
The grid in a pentode vacuum tube used to suppress secondary emission from the plate of the tube.
Corrosion that forms on the surface of a piece of metal covered with some form of electrolyte.
A temperature inversion with its base at the surface.
The condition of the surface of a reciprocating engine cylinder wall that has been honed to make it hold lubricating oil.
Strips of aircraft fabric that are doped over all seams and all places where the fabric is stitched to the aircraft structure and over wing leading edges where abrasive wear occurs.
The cohesive force that causes molecules of a liquid to hold themselves together.
Visibility observed from eye-level above the ground.
A surface active agent, or partially soluble contaminant which is a by-product of fuel processing or of fuel additives.
A condition of unstable airflow through the compressor of a gas turbine engine in which the compressor blades have an excessive angle of attack.

An instrument approach in which the air traffic controller issues instruction, for pilot compliance, based on the aircraft position relative to the final approach course (azimuth) and the distance (range) from the end of the runway as displayed on the controller's radar scope.
A nonreusable fitting installed on a flexible hose by forcing the material of the fitting into the hose.
A terminal pressed onto a steel control cable.
An approved plan to minimize the effect of severe weather on traffic flows in impacted terminal and/or ARTCC areas.
The component in a helicopter control system tat consists basically of two bearing races with ball bearings between them.
A method of soldering two pieces of sheet metal together.
An airplane wing in which the leading edge angles backward from the fuselage.
A special type of iron-core inductor used in a filter circuit for an electrical power supply.
A component used to open or close an electrical circuit or to select paths through the circuit.
A type of semiconductor diode whose resistance varies with the voltage across it.
An airfoil that has the same shape on both sides of its center line.
A dimensional check of an airframe to determine that the wings and tail are symmetrical about the longitudinal axis .
A device used to transmit indications of angular movement or position from one location to another.
A type of remote indicating system that uses synchro motors in the transmitter and the indicator.
An alternating current motor similar to an induction motor, except the rotor is either a permanent magnet or an electromagnet excited by an external source of direct current.
The speed of an induction motor at which the rotor follows the rotating field in the stator.
A method of synchronizing the propellers of a multi-engine aircraft.
A powerplant instrument used on multiengine aircraft to detect and display the difference in rotational speed of the various engines.
A chart, such as a weather map, which shows the distribution of meteorological conditions over an area at a given time.
A type of engine lubricating oil made by chemical synthesis (changing) of a mineral-, animal-, or vegetable-oil base.
A type of hydraulic system-pressure control valve.
A component in a large aircraft electrical system used to reduce the AC voltage and change it into DC for charging the battery and operating DC equipment in the aircraft.
A small, movable control hinged to the trailing edge of one of an airplane's primaary flight control surfaces.
An electronic navigation system, operating in the ultrahigh frequency (UHF) range.
An instrument used to measure the rotational speed of an object.
The flexible drive used to connect the rotating magnet inside a tachometer indicator to the tachometer drive gear inside an engine.
A coat of finishing material sprayed on a surface and allowed to dry until the solvents evaporate.
A clean, lintless rag, slightly damp with thinner.
A method of holding a structure together before it is permanently welded.
An arrangement of ropes and pulleys used to gain a mechanical advantage.
The condition of a finishing system in which the material is slightly sticky to the touch.
Small-diameter, soft steel wire used to tie the identification tags to objects.
An aircraft anti-icing system that uses hot air to prevent ice forming on the leading edges of the wings and tail surfaces.
A spar, or small-diameter structure that connects the tail section of an aircraft to a pod-type fuselage.
The cone-shaped section of the exhaust system of a gas turbine engine used to produce the correct change in area of the duct through which the exhaust gases leave the engine.
The downward aerodynamic force produced by the horizontal tail surfaces of an airplane.
The part of the exhaust system of either a reciprocating engine or a gas engine through which the exhaust gases leave the engine.
The small, auxiliary rotor installed on the tail of a single-rotor helicopter.
A small skid mounted on the bottom of the aft end of the fuselage of an airplane equipped with a tricycle landing gear.
A radar system installed in military aircraft to warn the pilot of an aircraft approaching from behind.
A small, swiveling or steerable wheel mounted at the aft end of the fuselage of an airplane equipped with a conventional landing gear.
Wind blowing in the same direction the aircraft is moving.
Small vertical surfaces mounted on the underside of the horizontal stabilizer of some airplanes to increase directional stability.
The condition of balance of an aircraft in which the center of gravity is behind its allowable aft limit.
The portion of an aircraft flight in which the aircraft leaves the ground.
The amount of power an aircraft engine is allowed to produce for a limited period of time.
A referenced airspeed obtained after lift-off at which the required one-engine-inoperative climb performance can be achieved..

With respect to turbine engines, means the jet thrust that is developed under static conditions at a specific altitude and atmospheric temperature under the maximum conditions of rotorshaft rotational speed and gas temperature approved for the normal takeoff, and limited in continuous use to the period of time shown in the approved engine specification..
An aural warning system that provides an audio signal when the thrust levers are advanced for takeoff if the stabilizer, flaps, or speed brakes are in an unsafe condition for takeoff.
Two sets of ball bearings mounted on a shaft in such a way that both bearings support the thrust load.
A configuration having two wings of similar span, mounted in tandem..
A tapered shank sticking out from the blade of a knife or a file.
A line that touches a curve at one point only and does not cross the curve.
The tangent of an angle in a right triangle is the ratio of the length of the side of the triangle opposite the angle, to the length of the side adjacent to (next to) the angle.
A resonant electronic circuit composed of a capacitor and an indicator in parallel.
A hard, gray, or steel-blue metallic chemical element. It's symbol is Ta, atomic number is 73, its atomic weight is 180,948.
A compound of tantalum and carbon in a hard, crystalline form, used for making cutting tools and dies.
A type of electrolytic capacitor that uses tantalum foil for the plates.
A metal cutting tool used to cut threads on the inside of a hole.
A twist of the correct size to drill a hole to be tapped.
A tool used to remove a broken tap from a hole.
A long, narrow strip of cloth, paper, or steel with graduations of inches or millimeters marked along its edge.
A gradual change in the width or thickness of an object along its length.
The relationship between the change in the resistance of a potentiometer or rheostat and the amount of rotation of its shaft.
A type of thread-cutting tap used to start the threads in a hole.
A type of hardware used to fasten concentric tubes together or to fasten a sleeve around a solid shaft.
A propeller shaft with a tapered end that fits into a tapered hole inside the propeller hub.
A hand-held punch that is tapered from its full shank size to a smaller diameter at its end.
A form of antifriction bearing that uses hardened steel rollers between hardened and polished, cone-shaped steel races .
A form of twist drill normally used in a large drill press or a lathe.
A type of wire-wound resistor with connections made to the resistance wire at points between its ends.
The component in the valve train of a reciprocating engine that rides on the lobes of the cam shaft or cam ring and pushes against the pushrod.
The weight of all the chocks and other items used to secure an aircraft on the scales for weighing.
Any of the many objects detected by radar.
The blade of a helicopter rotor identified as the reference blade when the rotor is being electronically checked for balance.
The British name for a hard-surfaced area on an airport where aircraft are tied down and serviced.
A dull surface which forms on some types of metal when oxygen in the air changes some of the metal into its oxides.
A large piece of heavy, waterproof canvas, fitted along its edges with eyelets.
A finishing material brushed or sprayed on the fabric used to cover the framework of an aircraft.
To move an aircraft along the ground or water under its own power, at a slow speed.
A light, similar to the landing light, installed on an aircraft in such a way that it illuminates the runway or taxiway when the aircraft is on the ground in its normal attitude for taxiing.
A paved strip on an airport that parallels the runways.

A time period specified by the manufacturer of an aircraft engine as the maximum length of time the engine should be run between overhauls without normal wear causing parts of the engine to be worn beyond safe limits.

Controlled airspace extending upward from the surface or higher to specified altitudes within which all aircraft are subject to operating rules and pilot and equipment requirements specified in 14 CFR Part 91.
An electronic warning system installed in an aircraft that detects nearby aircraft and warns the pilot, showing the range, altitude, and course of the impending threat.
TCAS (Traffic Alert And Collision Avoidance System)
A TCAS that utilizes interrogations of, and replies from, airborne radar beacon transponders and provides traffic advisories to the pilot.
A TCAS that utilizes interrogations of, and replies from airborne radar beacon transponders and provides traffic advisories and resolution advisories in the vertical plane.

A TCAS that utilizes interrogation of, and replies from, airborne radar beacon transponders and provides traffic advisories and resolution advisories in the vertical and horizontal planes to the pilot.
The official specifications of an aircraft, engine, or propeller issued by the Federal Aviation Administration.

A projected time calculated for the adapted vertex for each arrival aircraft based upon runway configuration, airport acceptance rate, airport arrival delay period, and other metered arrival aircraft.
A colorless, combustible compound, (CH3C6H4O)3PO, that is used as a plasticizer in aircraft dope and an additive in gasoline and lubricating oil.
The position of a piston in the cylinder of a reciprocating engine when the piston is at the top of its stroke and the piston pin, crank pin, and the center of the crankshaft are all in line.
The area in an overhaul shop set aside for disassembling the equipment being overhauled.
A fuel additive that ignites on contact with oxygen.
A synthetically produced, silvery-gray, metallic chemical element. Its symbol is Tc, and its atomic number is 43.
An approval issued by the FAA for the manufacture of a component for installation on a certificated aircraft.
A specialist in one of the technical fields.
A connector, made in the shape of the letter T, for joining either rigid or flexible fluid lines.
The registered trade name for a fluorocarbon resin.
An additive used in aviation gasoline to improve its antidetonation characteristics.
A method used to transmit quantitative information from a vehicle in flight to a station on the ground where this information can be used.
To slide one section of an object into another section or into a slightly larger sleeve.
A precision measuring tool used to measure the inside diameter of a hole.
A brittle, silvery-white chemical element. Its symbol is Te, atomic number is 52, and atomic weight is 127.60.
Trailing edge of the mean aerodynamic chord.
The condition of a metal with regard to its strength and hardness.
A measure of the intensity of heat, or the hotness or coldness of a body or material.
A temperature-sensing device used with a ratiometer-type thermometer.
Glass that has been heat-treated to increase its strength.
A process in the heat treatment of steel in which some of its hardness and brittleness are removed.
An outline pattern made of sheet metal, plastic, or heavy paper that can be traced on the material of which a part is to be made.
The strength of a material that opposes the stresses which try to stretch or lengthen it.
A stress that tries to pull an object apart.
A precision instrument used to measure the tension on a steel control cable installed in an aircraft.
Devices used in the control system of some large aircraft to maintain a constant tension on the control cables as the aircraft dimensions change because of changes in temperature.

A projected time calculated for the adapted vertex for each arrival aircraft based upon runway configuration, airport acceptance rate, airport arrival delay period, and other metered arrival aircraft.
The metric prefix that means a million million, or 1 x 1012.
A soft, silvery-gray, rare-earth, metallic chemical element. Its symbol is Tb, atomic number is 65 and its atomic weight is 158.924.
The device in a computer system that allows the human operator to interface with the computer.
A device that is crimped or soldered onto the end of an electrical wire to allow the wire to be attached to a component or terminal strip.
Airspace surrounding designated airports in which ATC provides radar vectoring, sequencing, and separation on a full-time basis for all IFR and participating VFR aircraft.
A strip of insulating plastic material that contains a number of threads studs to which electrical wires can be attached.
The maximum speed a freely falling object can reach when falling through the air.
A low-powered VOR that is normally located on an airport.
A decimal fraction which can be expressed as a definite number.
Thin sheets of steel protected from rust with a thin coating of lead.
The total infrared radiation emitted by the earth and its atmosphere.
A wide-blade, short-diameter propeller used on a reciprocating engine when it is run in a test stand.
A large, lightweight framework made in the shape of a tetrahedron, a triangular-shaped solid.
An electron tube with four active electrodes.
A soft, bluish-white, malleable, highly toxic, metallic chemical element. Its symbol is Tl, atomic number is 81, and atomic weight is 204.37.
An optical instrument used for surveying and weather observation.
A type of adaptor used in a constant-flow oxygen system to increase the flow of oxygen to a mask being used by a passenger known to have a heart or respiratory problem.
An aircraft anti-icing system that uses hot air to prevent ice forming on the leading edges of the wings and tail surfaces.
A term used to describe one of the limits to the speed at which an aircraft can fly.
A type of circuit breaker that opens an electrical circuit when excessive current flows through it.
The ratio of the change in resistance of a material to a change in its temperature.
A method of heat transfer in which heat energy is transferred from one body into another when the bodies are in direct contact.
A material that transfers heat energy by conduction with very little loss.
A special circuit breaker mounted inside an electric motor.
A process used to dimple, or indent, the hole into which a flush rivet is to be installed.
The ratio of the amount of useful work produced by a heat engine to the amount of work that could be done by the heat energy in the fuel used.
The change in the physical size of a material caused by the material absorbing heat.
A dimensionless number that relates to the change in the physical dimensions of a material as the temperature of the material changes.
A pressure relief valve in a hydraulic system that relieves the pressure which builds up when heat expands the fluid.
A condition that can occur in a nickel-cadmium battery in which the battery overheats because of excess current.
The rapid change in engine operating temperature that occurs when engine power is suddenly reduced at the same time the airspeed, thus the cooling, is increased.
A switch whose contacts are actuated by changing temperature.
The flow of electrons in a vacuum tube from a heated cathode to a positively charged anode, or plate.
A semiconductor device whose electrical resistance varies with its temperature.
A material with a negative temperature coefficient that causes its resistance to decrease as its temperature increases.
An ammeter used to measure the radio-frequency (RF) alternating current flowing in a circuit.
A device used to generate a small electrical current.
A fire detection system that works on the principle of the rate-of-temperature-rise.
The power that would be produced by a turboprop engine under standard-day sea-level conditions if the engine were run at a maximum turbine inlet temperature.
The branch of physics that deals with mechanical actions caused or controlled by heat.
The flow of electrons caused by heat in a metal or in a junction of two metals.
An instrument used to measure temperature.
The release of energy that takes place when the nucleus of one element is changed into the nucleus of another element by the action of heat.
An assembly of thermocouples connected together.
A type of plastic material that becomes soft when it is heated, and hardens when it is cooled.
A type of plastic material that, when once hardened by heat, cannot be softened by being heated again.
A temperature-sensing valve in an oil cooler that opens when the oil is cold and allows it to flow around the core of the cooler, between the core and the cooler jacket.
The component in a vapor-cycle cooling system that meters the refrigerant into the evaporator.
An electrical switch that closes a circuit when it is exposed to a specified high temperature.
A precision measuring tool made of a series of narrow strips of steel.
A solvent mixed with a finishing material, such as lacquer, dope, or enamel, to reduce its viscosity so it can be sprayed.
A lever in which the force is applied between the fulcrum and the weight.
A material, such as microballoons, added to a resin to give it body and increase its workability.
A heavy, silvery-white, malleable, metallic chemical element. Its symbol is Th, atomic number is 90, its atomic weight is 232.
Helical grooves cut onto the surface of a bolt or screw.
Long filaments made by twisting together short lengths of natural fibers, such as cotton or linen, to form a continuous strand.
The linear distance from the apex (peak) of one thread to the similar position on the next thread on a threaded fastener.
An automatic flight control system for an aircraft that controls the movement of the aircraft about all three of its axes.

A drum-shaped cam in a hydromechanical fuel control whose outer surface is precision ground in such a way that followers riding over it as it moves up and down and rotates move mechanical linkages to control the fuel according to a preprogrammed schedule.
An object that has length, width, and depth.
The form of alternating current produced by a generator with three sets of windings.
A full-stall landing of an airplane equipped with a tail wheel.
An electrical switch that has three sets of contacts, controlled by a single operating handle.
A digital logic device used as a switch in an integrated circuit chip.
An orthographic drawing showing three views of a part.
A type of switch that allows an electrical light to be turned on or off at either of two locations.
The intensity at which sound begins to cause pain.
A type of microphone used by a person operating in an extremely noisy area such as the cockpit of an airplane.
A floor- or bench-mounted metalworking tool used to cut across large sheets of thin metal.
The control in an aircraft that regulates the power or thrust the pilot wants the engine to develop.
A type of ice that forms on the throttle valve of an aircraft carburetor when the throttle is partially closed.
Long threaded rods that extend across the crankcase of an aircraft reciprocating engine to hold the crankcase halves together.
The offset in the crankshaft of a reciprocating engine to which the connecting rods are attached.
A part of a mechanism designed and built in such a way that it is not economically repairable.
A type of airplane control wheel that may be moved from in front of the left seat to a position in front of the right seat.
The forward aerodynamic force produced by a propeller, fan, or turbojet engine as it forces a mass of air to the rear, behind the airplane.
A form of bearing used in a mechanism to absorb rotating loads parallel to the axis of the shaft on which the bearing is mounted.
The actual amount of horsepower an engine-propeller combination transforms into thrust.
The horsepower equivalent of the thrust produced by a turbojet or turbofan engine.
An imaginary line, parallel to the propeller shaft of an engine installed in a airplane.
The gross weight of an aircraft, in pounds, divided by the thrust, in pounds, produced by the engines.
Axial loads in a bearing installed in an aircraft engine.
A device in the tail pipe of a gas turbine engine installed in an airplane that deflects some of he exhaust gases forward to produce a rearward thrust.
A small rocket engine whose thrust is used to change the attitude of a space vehicle.
A bright, silvery, rare-earth chemical element. Its symbol is Tm, atomic number is 69, and its atomic weight is 168.934.
A type of machine screw with a flat head in line with the length of the screw.
The loud rumbling sound caused by lightning.
The commonly used name for a cumulonimbus cloud.
A local storm invariably produced by a cumulonimbus cloud and always accompanied by lightning and thunder.
A hot-cathode, gas-filled electron tube in which one or more control electrodes start a flow of electrons between the cathode and anode.
A special type of semiconductor device used to protect a piece of electronic equipment from being damaged by spikes of voltage.
A semi-conductor device used as an electrically controlled switch.
A small coil in series with the collector of a transistor in an oscillator circuit.
A high-strength steel rod used to tie parts of a structure together.
A form of electric arc welding in which the electrode is a nonconsumable tungsten wire.
An interference fit between mechanical parts in which the parts can be assembled only by driving them together with a sharp blow from a 12 to 14 ounce hammer.
The amount of time, measured in seconds, needed for the current flowing through an inductive circuit to reach 63.2% of its final value.
The amount of time, measured in seconds, needed for electric motor to accelerate from standstill to its final no-load speed.
Time Constant Of An Electric Motor
Four digits representing the hours and minutes of Coordinated Universal Time (UTC), based on the 24-hour clock system.
With respect to maintenance time records, means the time from the moment an aircraft leaves the surface of the earth until it touches it at the next point of landing..
A slow-acting electrical relay in which there is a measurable delay between the time current is applied to the relay coil and the time the relay contacts close.
An item installed on an aircraft that must be replaced when it has been in service for a specified number of hours.
A patented maintenance tool used to locate the position of the piston in the cylinder of a reciprocating engine.
A metal disc with a 360o graduated scale marked on its face and a weighted pointer mounted on a bearing in its center.
An indicator light used when timing magnetos to indicate when the breaker points open.
A lustrous, silvery-white, ductile, malleable, metallic chemical element. Its symbol is Sn, its atomic number 50, and atomic weight is 118.69.
A commonly used name for hand-held metal-cutting shears.
Copper wire covered with a thin coating of tin or solder, an alloy of tin and lead.
A flat-headed solid rivet used in commercial sheet metal work.
Thin sheets of steel coated on one or both sides with a thin layer of tin.
A type of extra-flexible electric cord used for the leads in headphones.
A removable cap mounted on the tip of some helicopter rotor blades.
The path followed by the tip of the rotor blades as they rotate.
The rotative speed of a rotor blade, measured at its tip.
A ring, usually made of rubber or rubber compound, that fits around a wheel and serves as a cushion at the point the wheel touches the surface over which it rolls.
Bundles of high-strength steel wire used as a foundation for an aircraft tire.
The temperature of the gases from the combustion section of a gas turbine engine as they enter the turbine inlet guide vanes or the first stage of the turbine.
A strong, brittle, lustrous, silvery-gray, metallic chemical element. Its symbol is Ti, its atomic number 22, and atomic weight is 47.90.
A brilliant white paint pigment that contains no lead.
An information block placed in the lower right-hand corner of an aircraft drawing.
A component in the flight management system of a jet transport aircraft that senses the engine parameters and the power requests and controls the thrust produced by the engines.
The wheels of an airplane are toed in if lines drawn through the center of the two wheels, perpendicular to the axles, cross behind the wheels.
An indicator used in aerial navigation with the VOR, very-high-frequency omnirange navigation system.
A T-shaped handle fitted onto the end of a cable that is used to move some mechanical device.
To alternate between two or more circuit configurations, normally by the operation of a single switch.
A digital building block that changes the logic state of its output each time a clock pulse is received.
An electrical switch with a control handle in the form of a bat, or lever, sticking out of the front of the switch.
The difference between the extreme allowable dimensions of a part.
A liquid hydrocarbon material much like benzene, but less flammable.
A unit of weight in the English system that is equal to 2,000 pounds.
A measure of the cooling effect of an air conditioning system.
A unit of mass in the metric system equal to 1,000 kilograms or 2,204.62 pounds of mass.
Reciprocating engine piston position - See TDC.
The overhaul of the cylinders, valves, and pistons of a reciprocating engine.
A violent rotating column of air hanging down as a funnel-shaped cloud below a cumulonimbus cloud.
An electrical inductor wound around a ring-shaped core made of a highly permeable material.
A force that produces or tries to produce rotation.
A limit placed on a turboprop or turboshaft engine that restricts the amount of power the engine is allowed to deliver to the propeller or to the rotor-drive system.
A hinged link between the cylinder and piston of an aircraft shock absorber.
A tube in an aircraft control system that transmits a torsional force from the operating from the operating control to the control surface.
A precision hand tool used to measure the amount of torque being applied to a threaded fastener by the wrench.
An instrument used with some of the larger reciprocating engines and turboprop engines to measure the amount of torque the engine is producing.
A unit used to measure a low pressure or vacuum.
A device in a spring tab to which the control horn is attached.
The pressure a moving mass of fluid would have if it were stopped.
The temperature of a fluid that is stopped from its motion.
A type of flight practice in which the pilot makes a series of landings and takeoffs.
The first 3,000 feet of a runway beginning at the threshold.
The characteristic of a material that allows it to be deformed by twisting, pulling, hammering, or bending without its breaking.
A terminal facility that uses air/ground communications, visual signaling, and other devices to provide ATC services to aircraft operating in the vicinity of the airport or on the movement area.
Prevailing visibility as determined from an airport control tower.
A rapidly growing cumulus cloud in which its height is greater than its width.
A ring, usually installed on some strong part of the landing gear of an aircraft, to which a tow bar or cable can be attached to move the aircraft on the ground.
A type of ring cowling used over a single-row radial engine.
A numeric beacon decoder equipment/system, designed to be added to terminal radar systems for beacon decoding.
The path followed by the blade tips of a helicopter rotor as they rotate.
The path followed by a blade segment of a propeller in one rotation.
A white cotton flag mounted in line with a wooden pole and attached at both ends.
Small colored reflectors installed on the tip of a helicopter rotor to aid in checking the track of the blades.
A stick with a rubber wick attached to its end.
An engine installed on an aircraft in such a way that the propeller faces the front of the aircraft.
A propeller mounted on an airplane in such a way that its thrust pulls the airplane through the air.
Winds that always blow in the same general direction.
A published route prescribed for aircraft to fly when approaching or leaving an airport.
The traffic flow that is prescribed for aircraft landing at, taxiing on, or taking off from an airport.
The back edge of an airfoil, such as a wing, a helicopter rotor, or a propeller blade.
The part of an electrical pulse that occurs last.
Flaps mounted on the trailing edge of an airplane wing (airplane secondary control.
A second finger installed on the rotor of some aircraft magneto distributors.
The procedure used to square up the Pratt truss used in an airplane wing.
A wood or metal bar on which trammel points are mounted to compare distances.
A set of sharp-pointed pins that protrude from the side of a long wood or metal bar (a trammel bar).
A piece of radio communications equipment in which all of the circuits for the receiver and the transmitter are contained within the same housing.
A device that changes energy from one form into another.
A special type of punch used to mark the center of a rivet hold when the punch is stuck through an existing rivet hole.
An electrical component used to change the voltage and current in an alternating current circuit.
A component in a large aircraft electrical system used to reduce the AC voltage and change it into DC for charging the battery and operating DC equipment in the aircraft.
An active semiconductor device with three electrodes: an emitter, a collector, and a base.
A type of voltage regulator used in an aircraft electrical system to control the output voltage of an alternator.

Controlled airspace extending upward from 700 feet or more above the surface of the earth, when designated in conjunction with an airport for which an approved instrument approach procedure has been prescribed or from 1,200 feet or more above the surface of the earth when designated in conjunction with airway route structures or segments.
That portion of controlled airspace in which aircraft change from one phase of flight or one flight condition to another.
The additional lift produced by a helicopter rotor as the helicopter changes from hovering to forward flight.
The condition of a material that diffuses the rays of light passing through it.
A conductor used to transfer electrical energy from its source to the load using it.
An instrument system which shows the transmissibility of light through the atmosphere.
To send information or data from one location to another.
An electronic device that produces a radio-frequency carrier wave that can be modulated with information or data.
The square stern of a seaplane float.
Flight in which an airplane transitions from subsonic speed to a speed at or beyond the speed of sound.
The condition of a material that allows rays of light to pass through it without being diffused, or scattered.
The airborne radar beacon receiver/transmitter portion of the air traffic control radar beacon system (ATCRBS).
The distance between the center of rivets in two adjacent rows.
A type of mechanical wave in which the material being vibrated moves in a direction perpendicular to the direction the wave is moving.

A system for monitoring the performance of a turbine engine by routine comparison of performance parameters with a base line of the same parameters established when the engine was new or newly overhauled.
A form of thyristor, similar to a silicon controlled rectifier, except it controls current flow in either direction.
A method of determining the location of an aircraft by radio bearings.
A list of materials which can be rubbed together to produce electrostatic charges.
Electrostatic charges built up because of friction between different materials.
A continuous, low-current charge used to keep storage batteries fully charged at all times.
A small transformer-rectifier connected across a storage battery to charge it at a slow rate.
A type of aircraft landing gear that uses two main wheels located behind the center of gravity and a nose wheel well ahead of the center of gravity.
A pulse of electrical energy used to initiate an operation in certain types of electronic equipment.
