The branch of mathematics that deals with the relationships between the angles and the lengths of the sides of a triangle.
A jet-propelled aircraft that has three engines.
A small movable control mounted on a primary control surface of an aircraft.
A method of aerial mapping in which three photographs are taken at the same time of the area being mapped.
A flight condition in which the aerodynamics forces acting on the control surfaces are balanced, and the aircraft is able to fly straight and level with no control input.
The procedure of adjusting the fuel control of a gas turbine engine so the engine produces the correct maximum RPM and idling RPM, and functions properly under acceleration and deceleration.
An algebraic expression that has three terms.
An electron tube with three active electrodes: the cathode, the control grid, and the anode, or plate.
A circuit breaker that opens a circuit any time an excessive amount of current flows, regardless of the position of the circuit breaker's operating handle.
An aircraft with a landing gear that allows it to operate from dry ground, snow or ice, or water.
An airplane with three main supporting wings.
A multiple screw thread in which three threads are cut parallel to each other.
A type of trailing-edge wing flap used on some of the larger, high-performance airplanes.
A type of turbofan engine (gas turbine) in which the fan is the first stage of compression, or N1.
An isotope of hydrogen with an atomic weight of three.
A chemical element with three electrons in its valence, or outer shell.
An air mass with characteristics developed over the low latitudes.
A general term for a cyclone that originates over tropical oceans.
The division between the troposphere, the lower level of the earth's atmosphere, and the stratosphere, the layer of the atmosphere above the troposphere.
The lower level of the earth's atmosphere.

A procedure used in aircraft maintenance in which the operation of a malfunctioning system is analyzed to find the reason for the malfunction and to find a method for returning the system to its condition of normal operation.
An elongated area of relatively low atmospheric pressure.
Airspace surrounding designated airports in which ATC provides radar vectoring, sequencing, and separation on a full-time basis for all IFR and participating VFR aircraft.
The airspeed shown on the airspeed indicator after it has been corrected for nonstandard temperature and pressure.
A special airspeed indicator that modifies the differential pressure measured by its diaphragm to take into consideration free-air temperature and barometric pressure.
The exact height of an aircraft above mean sea level.
The navigational course for an aircraft measured from the geographic north pole.
True direction on the earth's surface measured from the geographic north pole.
The power, measured in watts, actually available in an alternating current circuit.
The direction, with respect to true north, from which the wind is blowing.
A cone with its point cut off in such a way that its top is parallel with its base.
Projections from the cylinder of a retractable landing gear strut about which the strut pivots to retract.
A type of structure made up of longitudinal beams and cross braces.
A form of two-way seal used in fluid power components.
A measure of the fuel efficiency of a turbojet or turbofan engine.
An approval issued by the FAA for the manufacture of a component for installation on a certificated aircraft.
A small hand tool used to make a square cut across the end of a piece of soft metal or plastic tubing.
The number of degrees of pitch or roll an aircraft is allowed before a gyroscope in a gyroscopic flight instrument contacts the stops in its gimbal system and tumbles.
A resonant electronic circuit containing both inductance and capacitance.
A hard, grayish-white, brittle, corrosion-resistant, metallic chemical element. Its symbol is W, atomic number is 74 and atomic weight is 183.85.
A semiconductor diode doped with a larger amount of impurity than is used in an ordinary diode.
A wheel fitted with vanes, or buckets, radiating out from its circumference.
The special series of stator vanes immediately ahead of the turbine.
The temperature of the gases from the combustion section of a gas turbine engine as they enter the turbine inlet guide vanes or the first stage of the turbine.
Another name for turbine inlet guide vanes.
An exhaust-gas-driven air compressor used to increase the power of a reciprocating engine.
A type of reciprocating engine that recovers some of the energy normally lost through the exhaust by using a power-recovery turbine (PRT) in the exhaust.
A type of gas turbine engine that has a set of lengthened blades on the low-pressure compressor or low-pressure turbine .
A form of heat engine that produces thrust by accelerating a relatively small mass of air through a large change velocity.
A form of gas turbine engine that uses one or more stages of turbines to drive a set of reduction gears, which in turn drives a propeller.
A form of gas turbine engine that uses one or more stages of turbines to drive a transmission, which in turn drives the rotors of a helicopter.
The original name for a turbocharger.
A condition of fluid flow in which the flow is not smooth.
The former name for a turn and slip indicator.
A rate gyro flight instrument that gives the pilot an indication of the rate of rotation of the aircraft about its vertical axis.
A rate gyro instrument that shows at a glance when a standard-rate turn is being made.
An adjusting device used in a run of aircraft control cable to adjust its tension.
Magnetic compass error See northerly turning error.
A liquid obtained by distilling the gum from pine trees.
A type of metal-turning lathe in which the cutting tools are mounted in a turret.
A socket wrench with a double hex, or a 12-point, opening broached into its open end.
The ampere hour rating of an aircraft battery when the current drawn from it will drop its voltage to a predetermined cut-off voltage in twenty minutes.
The intervals of incomplete darkness following sunset and just preceding sunrise.
A type of radial engine with two rows of cylinders and a single crankshaft.
A metal-cutting tool turned in a drill press or a hand-held drill motor.
A colored stripe running along the length of a flexible hose.
A type of electrical cable made up of two insulated wires twisted together and enclosed in an outer insulation.
An automatic pilot that uses a canted rate gyro, similar to that used in a turn coordinator, to sense rotation of the aircraft about its longitudinal and vertical axes.
An adhesive packaged in two containers and mixed just before it is used.
An axial-flow turbine engine that has two independent compressors, each driven by its own stage or stages of turbines.
A simple form of reciprocating engine that completes its operating cycle in two strokes of its piston one down and one up.
A fire detection system that uses individual thermoswitches installed around the inside of the area to be protected.
Communications in which two stations transmit and receive information.
The word TYP on a mechanical drawing indicates that the part of the drawing referred to is typical for more than one part.

As used with respect to the certification, ratings, privileges, and limitations of airmen, means a specific make and model of aircraft, including modifications thereto that do not change its handling or flight characteristics. Examples include: DC-7, 1049, and F-27' and (2) As used with respect to the certification of aircraft, means those aircraft which are similar in design. Examples include: DC-7 and DC-7C, 1049G and 1049H; and F-27 and F-27F; and (3) As used with respect to the certification of aircraft engines means those engines which are similar in design. For example, JT8D and JT8D-7 are engines of the same type, and JT9D-3A and JT9D-7 are engines of the same type..
The official specifications of an aircraft, engine, or propeller issued by the Federal Aviation Administration.
A tropical cyclone in the eastern hemisphere with winds in excess of 65 knots.
Patented nylon straps used to tie bundles of wire together.
A measure of quantity equal to 231 cubic inches, or 0.133 cubic foot.
A U-shaped rod threaded on both ends.
The trade name registered by General Electric for type of ultra-high-bypass turbofan engine that drives one or more propellers which have between 8 and 12 blades.
A gas turbine engine in which a fan, either ducted or unducted, has a bypass ratio greater than 30:1.
Frequencies of electromagnetic radiation between 300 and 3,000 megahertz.
The amount of load that can be applied to an aircraft structure before it fails.
The tensile stress required to cause a material to break or to continue to deform under a decreasing load.
Frequencies of electromagnetic radiation between 300 and 3,000 megahertz.
An aeronautical vehicle operated under 14 CFR Part 103 for sport or recreational purposes which does not require FAA regulations, an airworthiness certificate, nor pilot certification.

An aircraft is underpowered when there is not enough power delivered to its propeller or rotor to give it the required performance.

A propeller governor is in its underspeed condition when the engine is operating at a speed lower than the governor calls for.

In a geographical sense means: (1) the States, the district of Columbia, Puerto Rico, and the possessions, including the territorial waters, and (2) the airspace of those areas..
A citizen of the United States who undertakes directly by lease, or other arrangement, to engage in air transportation..
A type of clamp used to hold material being turned on a lathe.

The control column in an airplane on which the control wheel is mounted.
The ratio of the amount of tensile stress applied to a material to the amount of resulting strain parallel to the stress.
A soft, bright, silvery, rare-earth, metallic chemical element. Its symbol is Yb, atomic number is 70, and atomic weight is 173.04.
A silvery, rare-earth, metallic chemical element, Its symbol is Y, its atomic number is 39, and its atomic weight is 88.905.
A specially designed viscosimeter, or cup for measuring the viscosity of a liquid.
The vertical, or yaw, axis of an aircraft.
A special type of semiconductor device that allows electrons to flow through it in one direction, but normally opposes flow in the opposite direction.
The point in the orbit of a satellite or any body rotating around another body, at which the orbiting body is the greatest distance from the object around which it is rotating.
A mild breeze, usually one blowing from the west.
A large, rigid, lighter-than-air flying machine.
The registered trade name for a type of fitting used to put grease into a bearing.
A numerical quantity that has no value.
A reference used in the measurement of temperature.
The adjustment of the pointer of an electrical measuring instrument so that the needle rests over the zero mark on the dial when no current is flowing through the moving coil of the meter.
A condition in which the effect of gravity is cancelled or nullified by the force of inertia.
A method of determining the exact frequency of an alternating current.
A stage of compressor blades installed ahead of the front of an axial compressor'.
An ammeter in a light aircraft electrical system located between the battery and the main bus.
A type of valve lifter in a reciprocating engine that uses a hydraulic device to keep all clearance out of the valve train.
An imaginary line through an airfoil along which air can flow over both sides of the surface of the airfoil and not produce any lift.
A bluish-white, lustrous, metallic chemical element. Its symbol is Z, its atomic number 30, and atomic weight is 65.37.
An alkyd resin primer used to prepare a metal surface to take a topcoat of paint.
A lustrous, grayish-white, metallic chemical element. Its symbol is Zr, its atomic number is 40, and atomic weight is 91.22.
A type of directional radio beacon used to mark a specific location along an airway or along an instrument approach course.
A west wind or the westerly component of a wind.
Numbers placed along the edges of large aircraft drawings to identify the location of a part on the drawing.
A name for Greenwich mean time, or universal time.
The registered trade name for a type of nondestructive inspection used to find flaws that extend to the surface of a metallic or nonmetallic material.
